petition.title: Bill of Rights Legislation
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
In this session of Parliament the proposed Bill of Rights will come before the Senate to be debated.
We, the undersigned, would like to voice our protest at the proposed Bill.

1. Because of the haste and secrecy with which this legislation was passed through the House of Representatives despite the fact that it will adversely affect areas of immense importance to liberty and freedom and is contrary to the spirit of the Australian Constitution.

2. The Bill is based upon the United Nations International Covenant of Civil and Political Rights which has been rejected both by the United States of America and Great Britain but accepted by the Warsaw Pact countries. We therefore believe there is a potential threat to our national security through making treaties of this kind with foreign nations, many whom do not practice the principles that they have covenanted to uphold.

3. Because our Australian Constitution states that ``whereas we the people'' give you the government these rights, the Constitution limits the right and power of government. The proposed Bill of Rights reverses this totally and states that ``we the government, give you the people these rights''. This totally reverses the nature of government in this country.
4. Our rights and the principles of freedom are now protected by current legislation, Common law and the present Constitution.
5. Because it transfers the power of interpretation of legislation from the Parliament of Australia (the democratically elected institution) to the Courts (unelected body of people).

6. Because the Bill of Rights will be administered by the Human Rights Commission which is an unelected body of people with powers which are outside and not subject to the normal processes of law-no appeal, closed hearings, no legal representation.

7. That the implementation of the legislation through a process of new educational initiatives will result in the centralised control of education and this will inevitably lead to the destruction of States' rights and just as inevitably the centralised control, by government, on human behaviour.
We therefore request that you vote to reject this proposed Bill of Rights in any shape or form being introduced in Australia.
Yours humbly

speech.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill, which seeks to amend the Air Navigation Act 1920, is twofold. Firstly, it will enable Australia to ratify the Protocol signed in Montreal on 10 May 1984 amending the Convention on International Civil Aviation. This Convention is known as the Chicago Convention. Secondly, it will give effect in Australian law to the provisions of that Protocol.

The origins of this Bill can be traced to the tragic event that took place on the first day of September 1983, when Soviet military aircraft intercepted and shot down a Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 aircraft with the loss of all 269 persons on board. The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) convened an extraordinary assembly in May 1984 in Montreal to discuss measures that could be taken to prevent a recurrence of such an incident. Australia played an active role at this meeting, where unanimous agreement was reached by the 107 countries participating to amend the Chicago Convention through the inclusion of a new article, known as Article 3 bis.

Article 3 bis represents a significant step by the international community to ensure greater safety in international aviation by requiring states to refrain from using weapons against civil aircraft flying in their air space. In return, states are required to ensure that civil aircraft under their jurisdiction operate flights over foreign countries for legitimate aviation purposes only, as envisaged in the Chicago Convention.

To implement the first part of this obligation, the Government is taking the necessary administrative action to ensure that weapons are not used against foreign civil aircraft operating in Australian airspace.
Notice of Motion

The second part of Australia's obligation, which is to prevent aircraft under Australian jurisdiction from operating overseas in any manner that is not in accordance with legitimate civil aviation requirements, must be implemented by legislation. The Bill incorporates this requirement.

The Bill also contains provision to enable Australia to ratify Article 3 bis and to have it included as a schedule to the Act. This is consistent with the practice that has been adopted in the past regarding ratification of amendments to the Convention.

The proposed amendment to the Air Navigation Act which will give effect to Australia's above-mentioned obligation will apply to Australian registered aircraft, or foreign registered aircraft operated by an operator whose principal place of business or permanent residence is in Australian territory, which fly over the territory of another country. If an aircraft is flying without the authority of that country or is being used for a purpose inconsistent with the aims of the Convention, then it must comply with an order to land or with any other instruction that is given. The Bill also reflects the requirement of Article 3 bis for Australia to take appropriate measures to prohibit the deliberate use of its aircraft in these circumstances.

The pilot in command of an aircraft who breaches the above requirements may be prosecuted under this legislation and if found guilty, would be subject to the penalties prescribed. These penalties are maximum penalties, and are consistent with those applying to breaches of the Air Navigation Act generally. However, the pilot may decline to obey a direction if he believes that compliance with that direction would endanger the safety of the aircraft and persons on board. There may be other parties involved in the offences, such as the operator, and action against these ancillary offenders could be taken under the provisions of the Crimes Act.

It is important to recognise that there is nothing in the proposed legislation which derogates from obligations which any other law, including the law of a foreign country, might impose. An Australian aircraft, for example, which is flying over the territory of a foreign country is required to obey a direction legally given by the aeronautical authorities of the country concerned, just as a foreign aircraft flying over our territory is required to obey a lawful direction given by us.

Australia has undertaken to prosecute offenders in the specific circumstances laid down by Article 3 bis. If a pilot refuses to obey a direction to land given by an overseas country it could be difficult for that country to prosecute the pilot, once the pilot is outside its jurisdiction. However, the Bill does stipulate that a person convicted of an offence by a foreign country cannot be convicted in Australia for the same offence under this legislation.

Because of the importance the Government attaches to this issue, the Bill provides for the legislation to become effective by proclamation prior to the entry into force of Article 3 bis. The Government wishes this legislation, which will enhance the safety of civil aviation, to come into effect as soon as possible. The Protocol itself will come into force when one hundred and two counties have ratified it, which is approximately two-thirds of ICAO's membership. Before the legislation is proclaimed, the Government will ensure that the aviation publications issued for the use of pilots clearly explain these new requirements in the case of interception of Australian controlled aircraft operating overseas.
The proposed amendments will have no financial impact on Government expenditure.

The Government, the Opposition, Pilots' Associations and indeed the Australian people generally, have denounced the use of force against civilian aircraft. It is fitting, therefore, that every endeavour be made to promote the safety of international civil aviation. The passage of this Bill and the ratification of Article 3 bis will be a tangible demonstration to the international community of our strong and continuing commitment to this objective. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

debate.title: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 19 March, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —Before the debate on the Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill was adjourned yesterday I was saying that the Hawke Government has failed the test on each of the three requirements of successful economic policy for the private sector. The three requirements that I mentioned were: Firstly, that policies should be stable and predictable; secondly, that they should encompass restraint and discipline in matters such as government spending, taxing and borrowing; and, thirdly, that the policies need to be balanced. I pointed out that this Government's policies have not been stable or predictable; nor has there been any exercise of restraint or discipline. Government spending has sky-rocketed and so has taxation. Government borrowing has escalated enormously to the extent that the annual interest bill alone on that borrowing now exceeds what we spend on the defence of this nation. Every child born in 1986 will start life with an individual debt of $6,800 imposed on it by the Government. The Government's economic policies, to which Senator Button as the third most senior Minister in the Hawke Government is obviously a major contributor, have not been balanced. Because of the Government's inherent inability to control its spending, due basically to the fact that it is so dominated in its policy making by Simon Crean and Bill Kelty of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Government has had to place unwarranted and dangerous reliance on monetary policy to try to keep--
—We try to cut spending and you whackers in here knock back the legislation.
—The Government is responsible for government spending, not us. The Government has had to place unwarranted and dangerous reliance on monetary policy--
—You are responsible for stopping the elimination of waste in spending.
—Is the Minister denying that he is placing undue reliance on monetary policy?
—I am stating the fact that you whackers in here knock off legislation to cut expenditure.
—It would assist the debate if Senator Short addressed his comments through the Chair and did not exchange repartee or abuse with the Minister. Senator Short is on his feet and he has the floor.

—The cost of the Government's policies has been disastrous to every Australian and the path of growth that it has been trying to follow is about to take a damaging downturn. The policies of this Government have led to the highest real interest rates for more than 50 years, the lowest value of the Australian dollar in at least 50 years--
—And it is going to go lower.

—It is going to go lower under the existing policies; the honourable senator is quite right. The policies of this Government have led also to a balance of payments deficit which is running at an annual rate of $14.5 billion, which is the equivalent of 5 per cent of our total gross domestic product. By comparison, in the United States of America, where the deficit is considered to be chronic and unsustainable, the balance of payments deficit is 3.5 per cent of GDP. If the United States balance of payments is chronic and unsustainable, what on earth is ours?
—It was 6 per cent when Howard was Treasurer.

—Not the balance of payments deficit. We have an inflation rate twice the average of our main trading partners and four times greater than that in Germany and Japan. We have had an increase both in total unemployment and in long term unemployment. The rate of unemployment in the 36 months that the Hawke Government has been in office has been higher than in all but four of the 86 months that the Fraser Government was in office. But the real weakness of this Government has been in its abdication of responsibility to the ACTU. We do not have a Labor led government in Australia today; we have an ACTU led government. The ACTU calls the shots on virtually every major economic policy issue, despite the fact that Simon Crean and Bill Kelty were not elected by the people of Australia to govern this country.

speech.para: Senator Button made an interesting speech a month ago to the Industry Research Symposium in Adelaide. With much of that speech, I hasten to add, I agree and think that it was a good speech, but he said, among other things, that the Government took credit for having changed the policy environment in Australia in a way that assists industry. I regard that as a considerable misstatement of the real position. He pointed to the floating of the dollar under this Government, and I agree with the merits of that. He pointed to financial deregulation and the admission of foreign banks. I agree with that, although I would point to a fact that is often forgotten, that the real generator of those moves was the now Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, when he was Treasurer.

Senator Button then pointed to taxation reform as having improved the environment for industry. I do not know what on earth he was talking about because we have had no taxation reforms or any proposals for reform. What we have are proposals of a ragbag nature left over as the only bits and pieces of the so-called reform with which the ACTU was prepared to let the Government emerge from the National Taxation Summit last year. The proposals are unco-ordinated and totally anti-business. They increased the taxation burden on business very heavily indeed, and for Senator Button to say that the Government's taxation reforms have assisted the business climate is an odd statement for him to make.

Senator Button also said that the Government was responsible for an improvement in the industrial relations climate. Some things should be said about that. First, it is open to serious question just how much the industrial relations climate has improved while this Government has been in office. The statistics in that area are quite deficient. But more to the point one would expect the industrial relations climate to have improved mightily, given the Government's sell-out to the union movement on virtually every policy issue. It has been a non-stop, fast track one-way street of benefits flowing to the unions in terms of the shift of power to the unions, in placing them in a privileged position, and in providing them with benefits that have not been provided to any other section of the Australian community.

The king hit, of course, is the deal that has been done between the Government and the ACTU on the productivity claim and its flow-on into superannuation. In doing that deal the Government and the ACTU have treated the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with contempt. They have, in effect, said to the Commission `You are nothing but a rubber stamp, you will do what we say', regardless of the merits, the logic or the economic impact of the proposals. To his great credit the new President of the Commission, Mr Justice Maddern, has refused to be so treated. However, it remains to be seen just where the final outcome will be. If it goes through, the productivity-superannuation deal will cause great damage to Australian industry. Australian industry is already experiencing cost disabilities which are making it increasingly difficult to achieve sustainable international competitiveness. I think it is agreed on all sides of this Parliament, and widely throughout the community, that an improvement in our international competitiveness is imperative for the future of industry, our living standards and for the future of every Australian.

The disabilities under which industry is suffering are due largely to the taxing, charging and regulatory policies of government and to wage related costs far in excess of most other countries. The cost pressures on industry are increasing. If the ACTU's demands are met, the prospect is that in the 12 months to this coming November direct labour costs alone will increase by no less than 14 per cent-and that increase excludes labour on-costs.
The Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia, in a pamphlet issued recently, has given examples of the additional on-costs. It has also said:

. . . that what the ACTU is seeking in its productivity claim is a 3 per cent `wage equivalent', that is, the amount of money which the ACTU want distributed in the form of new or improved superannuation schemes is to be calculated on the basis of how much it would cost an employer if the employer had to pay the 3 per cent as a wage increase. The 3 per cent will, therefore, contrary to what the ACTU has said in the past, cost an employer more than just 3 per cent of the ordinary weekly wage because it is payable on overtime, shift penalties and other on-costs.

On top of the above claims the ACTU is seeking to have the wage fixing principles `relaxed' to make it easier for unions to gain wage increases outside of indexation and changes to employment conditions.

These are vital issues for the Australian economy. They are issues which the Confederation of Australian Industry picked up and commented on in a release just last weekend. I quote from the Confederation's release dated Sunday, 16 March, in which the Director-General of the CAI Industrial Council said:

It is hard to believe that the Government is taking the problems of this economy seriously when it can support a productivity-based increase at a time when the only question about the 1986-87 financial year is whether Australia is heading for a mild slowdown in activity or for a major recession.
It is an absurdity almost beyond belief to find CAI in the midst of an argument over productivity distribution when each day brings more news of an impending economic downturn.

Those comments by two of the leading industry associations in Australia are on vital issues for Australian industry. I was glad to hear from the Minister, Senator Button, in his second reading speech, that one of the main purposes of this Bill is to enable the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to devote more time to policy matters affecting industry. The present Minister needs to do that. I have to say to Senator Button-I am sorry that he is not in the chamber at present-that, as the third most senior Minister in the Hawke Government, he is not producing policies from that Government which will assist industry to restructure, to become competitive, and to provide opportunities for growth in investment and employment.

Frankly, the Opposition is asking the Minister, on behalf of those industries for which he has ministerial responsibility, to lift his game and to ensure that the rhetoric of his Government is matched by its performance in relation to what we all agree, I think, are commonly accepted objectives for where we want to see Australian industry heading in the future. To the extent that this Bill will assist him in that regard, on behalf of the Opposition I say that we support the Bill-subject to a couple of minor, technical amendments which I foreshadowed yesterday and which we shall take up in debate in the Committee of the Whole.

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —We are debating the Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986. The Australian Democrats support this Bill, as it is an attempt to rationalise the Customs Service workings. The Opposition has circulated some amendments. I propose to comment on those amendments during the Committee stage, after I have had the opportunity of hearing the comments of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) upon them.

speech.para: This Bill transfers to the Comptroller-General of Customs some powers previously held by the Minister. The Minister is thus freed from some of the more mundane duties of his office and will now be able to concentrate on more important matters. That is how it should be in a well-run, modern government, where the Minister is free to concentrate on policy decisions and is removed as much as possible from administrative tasks, which are, essentially, left to the bureaucracy to implement. In passing, I will say that the load that Ministers carry in parliament is quite horrendous. The more they can be freed to make the right sorts of policy decisions, the better our government will be, whether it is government by the Australian Labor Party or by the Liberal Party of Australia. The Minister still retains significant powers in customs administration. These include the extension or variation of bounty assistance-a very important matter-the proposing of tariff alterations, decisions on import tenders and anti-dumping duties. These areas are all important in political and policy terms. They must be retained by the elected representative of the people.

However, customs administration brings to my mind more important issues. I will spend a moment talking about such things as the balance of payments problem facing this country and this Government's apparent inability to do anything about that problem and some of the other urgent problems facing the economy. In 1984-85 Australia faced a record balance of payments deficit-a deficit of $10,000m-odd. This year, despite a 20 per cent devaluation in our currency, the situation is no better. There has been some reduction in imports caused by tight monetary policy but the export situation has deteriorated even further. This is despite the 20 per cent devaluation. We still cannot sell our produce overseas. One is therefore forced to ask: What is the reason for this? Put quite simply, we are putting our resources into production of goods with a very low value-added component. We are still predominantly a primary exporter at a time when primary exports are faced with world gluts.

The wheat market around the world has collapsed. Coal is threatened by falling prices. Base metals have never really recovered from the recession in the 1980s. This is the essential problem that we face with export commodities. Our exports are worth less and our import bill grows unabated. By any reckoning, we are living beyond our means. Despite what the Government would like to think, there are no easy answers to this problem. We cannot right things simply by changing our monetary or fiscal policies. We have, I am afraid, very severe structural problems in our economy. Over the last 20 years we have allowed the manufacturing sector to decay. We are now tied to a very high level of imports. No matter what happens to our export markets we must still import manufactured goods simply because we cannot do without them.

The manufacturing base that we had once has now been eroded. This is a great tragedy for our young people who need jobs and for the country as a whole which desperately needs export income. To solve the problem we must have a renaissance in manufacturing industry. Although the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has been instrumental in implementing some very worthwhile initiatives in industry, they are nowhere near enough, as Senator Short mentioned, and we need a renaissance-a major objective-to get out industries export-orientated. We must forget about the old concept of developing manufacturing industries to replace imports. We have to develop industries that are export-orientated. I have said in this place many times that to do this we have first to take note of employee participation. We have to tap the potential of the work force to contribute to the efficiency of industry in this country. Until we do that we will never get industries that are internationally competitive.

talk.start.para: —What about training managers?

—By all means. It is a common problem. I believe we have management which looks on the work force as essentially something that has to do what it is told, but we also have a work force which looks upon management as something which is a boss. Those in the work force think that they should not use their brains to make money for the boss. There is, unfortunately, a confrontationist attitude in industry rather than an attitude of co-operation. Unless we get that co-operative attitude so that we can tap the brainpower, the resources and the real skills of the entire work force from management right down-it needs a fundamental change of attitude-we will not be internationally competitive. That cannot be done overnight. There are various initiatives that should be put in force such as employee share ownership, profit sharing and small group activity set up to discuss day to day problems along the lines of Japanese industry, where there are cellular organisational structures where performance in industry can be measured on a monthly basis so that everybody knows how they are performing in relation to a budget that is put forward.

speech.para: I do not want to dwell on that aspect as I have spoken on that many times in this place. I want to mention in particular another aspect which I believe is equally important. We have to have co-operation between management and the work force. We also have to have co-operation between governments and industry. This co-operation between industry and governments is very much in the Government's corner. One important aspect of this is that we must direct investment to the manufacturing sector. We must modernise it. We must expand it. The present situation, brought about by government incentives, is that we favour making paper profits-stock market speculation-rather than genuine investments in plant and machinery.

Let us look at some of the facts. Since 1981-82 the stock exchange index has increased by 70 per cent or more and profits in companies generally in industry have increased by 118 per cent in real terms, yet investment in plant and machinery is actually lower than it was in 1981. It is lower not only in real terms but also in absolute terms. Money is not being directed to productive wealth creating manufacturing resources. It is being misdirected and the Government must shoulder a large measure of the blame for this situation. We see before our very eyes at the moment the largest company in the land-a company controlling 8 per cent of our total exports, controlling three of our major industries and employing over 50,000 people-being taken over through the medium of a $2 billion loan from overseas.

talk.start.para: —Are you talking on the trade practices legislation or the Customs legislation?

—I am talking on the problems of our balance of payments, which are very much related to the whole question of imports and tariffs. If honourable senators will just bear with me, I am covering ground that was also covered to some degree, but not properly, in my view, by Senator Short a moment ago. At present the Government is doing nothing about righting this situation which encourages a very elite group of investors to make paper profits by stock market manipulations-a situation that was very analagous to that which happened in 1928, when paper profits were being made and investment into productive resources was being neglected. One of the major reasons for our balance of payments problem is simply this: We have an ever increasing--

—I rise on a point of order. We are finding Senator Siddons's contribution quite confusing as it is without his continual referring to trade practices-type legislation, matters which will shortly be before the Parliament. I would like to draw your attention to the fact that he should be speaking to the Bill.

—There is no point of order. I allowed Senator Short a reasonable amount of latitude in the comments he made to the same Bill some time ago. Senator Siddons is addressing similar problems. I will allow him to continue, but draw his attention to the fact that this Bill is a Customs Bill and, whilst the Chair is prepared to allow a certain amount of latitude when Customs and import-export related matters are discussed, I ask Senator Siddons to keep within the bounds of the Bill.

—I make the point that the Customs Bill relates to imports. That is the critical problem. The Government has addressed this problem to a minor degree in this Bill-which we support. I am merely making a plea for the Government to look at the overall situation in much greater detail and come up with an initiative that attacks some of the deep-seated problems in our import-export areas. Before the point of order was taken, I was making the point that 30 per cent of our exports now go to pay our interest bill. We are like a family that, having sold a house, is now renting a house and buying things on time payment. That can only go on for so long. We are living beyond our means. We are having a great problem in servicing our debts. We have very little else to sell by way of industry to foreign interests to attract foreign money into the country. We have to take note of where we are heading and do something about the fundamental problem of living beyond our means. We have to do something about exporting more and reviving our manufacturing sector. The Democrats support this Bill. It is an area that needs a lot more attention by the Government. We look forward to the Minister taking up some of the critical challenges that lie before this country.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —The Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986 enables senators to raise general questions about the operations of the Australian Customs Service, which has been done by other speakers in this debate. Specifically, the Bill is said to contain provisions which will enable the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to concentrate more on the policy aspects of the legislation and regulations made under the Customs Act than on the day to day operation of the legislation. I raise a matter which has been on the plate for some considerable time. I am pleased that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has come into the chamber, as an opportunity has how been presented to me to raise again a matter that I raised in late 1983 with the Minister by way of a question without notice. On 10 November 1983 I asked the Minister whether he was aware that a Soviet-built vehicle named the Lada was being sold in Australia and that it was reported that component parts of the vehicle were being manufactured in Soviet prison camps. On that occasion I asked him:

speech.para: How does this square with Article 16 of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulation which prevents the import of vehicles into Australia if they were made in whole or in part by prison labour?

I leave aside the rhetorical question I asked on that occasion and get to the point. The Minister responded that he was aware that a Russian light commercial vehicle was imported, and he was aware of that because `Senator Harradine told me at a quarter to two this afternoon'. I followed that up on 7 December when I indicated that I had not received a response from the Minister. The Minister asked me whether I could give him some indication of where people might look to obtain the facts. I then sent the Minister a letter in which I included an article from a Canadian journal which indicated the type of area which the Minister's Department could look at. I have not received a response from the Minister to that letter from that day to this.

I think it a very important matter, not only from the point of view of our indigenous motor vehicle manufacturing industry but also from the point of view of the commitment of everyone in this chamber to ensuring that there is no forced labour and in particular, so far as this country and its imports are concerned, that Article 18 of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations is rigorously enforced. Since that time late last year it has become evident from statements made by Mr Avraham Shifrin, a Jew who had been a prisoner in the Soviet Union for 15 years and who presumably had come out from the Soviet Union, that Lada and Niva cars are built partially by slave labour and that, for example, rubber tyres are made by prisoners from camp No. UZH-15/2 in Bobruisk which is in Byelorussia; that steering wheels and chassis are manufactured at Sosnovka, one of the seven strict regime camps on the Dubrovlag route east of Moscow. We should bear in mind that the assembly plant for Lada vehicles, which are imported into this country, is situated in the city of Toghatigrad which is some 1,000 kilometres east of Moscow. The steel springs and metal fittings, according to this source, are made by prisoners from the intensive regime camp at Kochatovka in the Tambov region. A top security camp at Votkinsk, a very interesting name, in Udmurf contains child labour and is used to make locks and springs. A range of spare parts is manufactured by prisoners from the ordinary regime camps at Arzamas south of the city of Gorki. Here we have a situation in Australia where these vehicles are being imported--

talk.start.para: —How many are imported?

—I am not sure, Senator. But even if only one were imported containing elements of slave labour, it should attract refusal under Item 16 of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. I did have the figure previously but I just cannot remember it.
—Do you know whether we import from Thailand, Senator?
—Do you mean motor vehicles? I do not think so.
—No, anything.
—I am not sure.
—I wonder whether you would widen the category to include all those places that use child labour.
—If there were such a case, most certainly I would.
—You would include the lot of them?
—Item 16 is not specifically designed for the Soviet--
—You are not making your own comments. You are just giving an example?

—Item 16 has been used recently to prohibit importations from Wormwood Scrubs. There was some publicity about the seizure of speakers by prisoners in the old Dartmoor prison. I think the Minister probably is aware of that.
—I have difficulty in determining which you would least like to work in-Wormwood Scrubs or a factory in South Korea.

—I am making no comment about that; the regulations are there. I am pointing out the fact that the regulations do not distinguish between, for example, compulsory labour in Dartmoor prison and compulsory labour in the Soviet Union. Apparently the only discrimination that is involved is that Customs officials are not sufficiently switched on to answer a complaint that I raised in this chamber as far back as 1983. Since that time information has been provided by a Jewish person who was incarcerated in prison in the Soviet Union for 15 years. That person ought to know all about it. One does not have to go overseas to get that information. On this very day in Canberra there is a person named Dr Cronid Lubarsky, who is in Australia for a period of one month. He is in Canberra now. He is a veteran of prison camps in the Soviet Union. He is an astronomer who once worked on Russia's unmanned space mission to Mars. He is now the editor of a fortnightly news bulletin on internal affairs on the Soviet underground dissident movement. In 1972, after the KGB raided his flat in Moscow and found piles of banned literature, he was sentenced to five years in the camps, going first to Camp 19 in Mordovia.

—That would happen here if you had your other hat on. What about somebody who had piles of banned videos in his flat here? That person would go to gaol in Australia wouldn't he, if you had your other hat on?
—Under what provision, Senator?
—Under the criminal law.

—That is an interesting statement that I might even incorporate into the report when we come to it. It is an interesting statement that we will come to when we are talking about the right to privacy in the Bill of Rights. the Minister would appreciate that, although there is no right to privacy explicitly in the American Bill of Rights, it is implicit. Under that implicit provision of the American Bill of Rights any laws in the United States which prohibit the possession of even the worst types of pornography are not valid. I am glad the Minister raised that. We will come to that matter when we deal with the Australian Bill of Rights Bill. However, the Minister has made me digress.

speech.para: At present there is here in Canberra for two days a person who has experienced treatment in labour camps. He himself has been an eye witness to forced labour in the manufacture of goods destined for the West. He is in Canberra today. In Camp 19 in which he was incarcerated in Morovia prisoners were put to work preparing cases for cuckoo clocks to be exported to Britain and other Western countries. When he eventually got to Europe he saw these cuckoo clocks and recognised the cases that were made in the prison camp. Forced labour was used to make those cases.

I feel as though I am being put on the defensive by the Minister in relation to the comments which I have made. I make no apologies for standing here on behalf of the workers of this country and demanding that the Australian Customs Service get off its backside and investigate these things. I make no apologies about that. I make no apologies for speaking on behalf of the workers in the vehicle industry. Many of their jobs are threatened by imports generally. Specifically, if this practice is allowed to continue that will mean that these workers are not only threatened but insulted as well. Their rights are being insulted. If the rights of workers in any country are insulted they are insulted in all countries. I regard this as a very serious matter indeed. I regard it as very serious that the Minister has not answered questions about this matter which I raised in 1983. I challenge him to get his Department to look at this problem, to investigate it thoroughly and to obtain from the manufacturers of the vehicles concerned a detailed list of the component parts and where they are manufactured. I challenge him to submit this to our embassy in Moscow to establish the facts of the situation. I would have thought that that was a reasonable request. It is a major matter of principle, in my mind.

We talk about the rights of the worker in this country. We talk about the right and freedom of workers not to be put in the position of forced labour. However, I raised this matter two years ago and still have no answer. I have mentioned the former Russian astronomer who, in fact, lived under a regime which forced him to manufacture goods for export to the West. I believe that it is very important that all information possible be sought by the Customs Service from Soviet officials in regard to the component parts of those particular motor vehicles and that this information be checked out. I believe that we owe it not only to the workers of Australia but also to our fellow human beings who are forced into a position of forced labour to do something. The Department has sat on its backside for the last two years and done nothing about it. I believe it is time that it did something about it.

speech.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: in reply-It is very evocative of Senator Harradine to talk about departments sitting on their backsides and to make the highly rhetorical allegations which he has just made in his little touch of flamboyance this morning. Of course, the situation is extremely difficult. In my view it is not the function of a customs service in the broader sense to canvas all the issues which Senator Harradine has tried to hang on the provisions in the legislation, which has been there since 1902 and which is now being reviewed by the Australian Customs Service.

speech.para: Senator Harradine says that nothing is being done about this issue. There may well be a disputed set of facts. When I was in the Soviet Union last year I inquired at the Australian Embassy about this question. Officers from the embassy and officers of the Australian Trade Commissioner Service had been to the Lada-Niva factory. The Lada-Niva car is the trojan horse by which Senator Harradine wheels in a whole lot of other arguments. Those officers had been to that factory. To say the least, they doubted very much the allegations made by Senator Harradine and others in this chamber. I make the quite practical point that in respect of components it would be an impossible burden to place on any customs service to ask it to go through a motor vehicle and make an assessment of where all the components have been made.

talk.start.para: —That is not what I said. I said to ask the manufacturers where they had been made. That is the first step, surely?
—That has been done.
—That has been done, with what result?
—They are not satisfied that the allegations which the honourable senator has made are correct. I put it as low as that for the purposes of this discussion.
—It will be interesting to see what FOI comes out with.

—The honourable senator can pursue that to his heart's content. Getting back to the main topic of the debate here, which is the legislation before the chamber, I wish to address one or two questions raised by Senator Short-the main issues which have been raised. The purpose of the legislation simply is to put into legislative effect decisions which have been made and debated in the Parliament already. The principal basis of the Bill is to transfer the Minister's administrative powers under legislation administrated by the Australian Customs Service to the office of the Comptroller-General of Customs. Since 10 June 1985 that has been vested with the general administration of the Australian Customs Service. The question of the appropriateness or suitability of that transfer of power was judged principally on an assessment as being either administrative, that is concerning the day to day running of the Customs Service, or something more sensitive than that perhaps involving political issues or impinging upon economic or other Government policies. That was the broad set of criteria which was used. It does not need me to say that the issues have been identified as much as possible in that way with the administrative functions, the day to day decisions, going to the Comptroller-General of Customs and the other matters residing in ministerial discretion.

speech.para: Senator Short also raised a number of general questions about the changes which have been made to the Customs Service and what followed as a result. I think it is fair to say that there is a very good working relationship between the Customs Service and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. Guidelines in relation to co-operation between the two organisations have been tabled. I think the Customs Service has a very high degree of international standing and it has been a major participant in international Customs activities. Recently significant changes have been made to cargo clearance arrangements which have resulted in the majority of cargoes now being available within four hours as distinct from the several days it was previously. The business regulation review unit in my Department has estimated that the cost savings to industry and the community as a result of those changes will be of the order of $40m. The Customs Service has also launched a proposal for an integrated cargo control and clearance system which, by automatic data processing technology, will replace a lot of the paperwork associated with importing goods.

In addition, I believe that the Customs Service has had some very successful operational results in a number of instances of drug importation into Australia which have been widely publicised. That is not to say that everything is satisfactory. It is far from satisfactory. The particular problem which has attracted attention is the industrial disputation at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport, which subsequently flowed to Melbourne Airport for a while, which involves a ban on body searches. The ban arises from the changed regulations for body searches of incoming passengers.

I believe the position adopted by the Customs Officers Association of Australia to be quite incorrect. We have sought to give the authority to conduct body searches to a senior officer in consultation with the Customs officer at the desk. Every Customs officer will not be entitled of his own volition, where he is interfacing with a passenger, to say: `I think you ought to have a body search'. That search has to be in conjunction with the authority of a senior officer. That is the essential element of the change. We think it is highly desirable. That change, of course, has been discussed in various ways in this chamber.

Senator Short made a couple of other points concerning section 119 relating to the power of the Minister, which will now go to the Comptroller-General, to grant or to refuse to grant to the master of a ship a certificate of clearance for departure from Australia or the pilot of an aircraft where such a certificate of clearance is not forthcoming from a collector of Customs in the usual course. I just want to make the point that the number of such certificates issued daily is enormous. Those which are refused, resulting in a special application to the Minister-or as is now proposed to the Comptroller-General-need to be processed as quickly as possible. It is considered that the Comptroller-General is much better placed than a sometimes itinerant or otherwise involved Minister to provide speedy clearances in respect of ships and aircraft in that sort of situation. I make the point also that the decision by the Comptroller-General in these matters is reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Senator Short also raised a point relating to Part XI of the Customs Act which deals with Customs agents. A whole range of the Minister's powers under this Part are proposed for transfer, essentially again because it is considered that matters relative to the administration of Customs agents licences fall within the ambit of the Comptroller-General's responsibility. Again, they concern day to day matters. In addition, I note that all the decisions taken for the purpose of this Part of the Act will be subject to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Further, with regard to the suspension, revocation or non-renewal of Customs agents licences, the Comptroller-General's powers in these areas-as was the case with the Minister's powers-are exercisable only after consideration of a report on the issue by the National Customs Agents Licensing Advisory Committee. That Committee has on it representatives of the Customs Agents Association. The transfer of these powers is still subject to the constraint that action to suspend, revoke or not renew an agent's licence can only be taken following the consideration of a report by the National Customs Agents Licensing Advisory Committee and once such a decision or action is taken it is reviewable by the AAT. I make the point that the proposed transfer of power here is supported by the Australian Customs Agents Federation and has been consistent with the general thrust of the Bill to remove essentially administrative functions from the ambit of the Minister and place them in the hands of the Comptroller-General.

I understand that Senator Short also raised a point relating to sub-section 26A (5) of the Customs Tariff Act 1982 and the corresponding sub-section 6a (8) of the Excise Tariff Act. These sub-sections impose an obligation on the Minister-proposed to be changed to the Comptroller-General-to publish a notice in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette for the information of the public advising of new rates of duty and the goods to which those rates apply following the automatic indexation of these duty rates as provided by the respective sections. There is a mandatory obligation to notify in the Gazette the new duty rate and that follows the legislative application of the section. Again, it is considered that such a notification requirement is an administrative function which should be transferred to the Comptroller-General, in accordance with the general thrust of the Bill.

I generally thank honourable senators for their support of the legislation. Senator Short has indicated that, at the Committee stage of the Bill, he will move three amendments to the legislation. In a sense, they are technical amendments which I think we would readily concede are consistent with the spirit of the legislation and may well be improvements. The Government will accept those three amendments.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

proctext.para: The Bill.

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —by leave-I move:

speech.para: (1) Page 5, Schedule, proposed amendments of the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980, proposed amendment to sub-section 20 (1), leave out the proposed amendment, insert the following amendment:
Paragraph 20 (1) (r)-
Omit `Minister', substitute `Comptroller-General'.
(2) Page 6, Schedule, proposed amendments of the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980, proposed amendment to sub-section 20A (1), leave out the proposed amendment.
(3) Page 9, Schedule, proposed amendments of the Customs Act 1901, proposed amendment to paragraphs 273GA (c), (h) and (j), after `(c)', insert `(e), (f),'.

The amendments are designed to correct, from what the Minister said, two oversights in the Bill, both affecting rights of review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The first two amendments relate to pages 5 and 6 of the Bill, the first one to sub-section 20 (1) of the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980; and second amendment to sub-section 20A (1) of the same Bill.

The Bill as proposed would amend sub-section 20 (1) of the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980 by omitting `Minister' wherever occurring and substituting `Comptroller-General'. Sub-section 20 (1) specifies that certain decisions under the Act are subject to review by the AAT. While the Bill will transfer from the Minister to the Comptroller-General the power to require bounty claimants to give security, reviewable by the AAT under paragraph 20 (1) (r), powers relating to the registration of premises and persons, likewise reviewable by the AAT under sub- section 20 (1), remain with the Minister. Accordingly, the Bill would remove this right of review. This is a simple oversight and the proposed amendment No. 1 would substitute `Comptroller-General' for `Minister' only in paragraph 20 (1) (r), thus preserving the right of review in respect of those decisions remaining with the Minister.

The Bill would also omit the words `Minister or the' from sub-section 20A (1), the provision requiring a decision-maker to include a statement as to the right of review by the AAT in a notice given to persons affected by a decision. As the Minister remains a decision-maker, this amendment is superfluous and proposed amendment No. 2 would omit it.

The third amendment relates to paragraphs 273GA (c), (h) and (j) of the Customs Act 1901 to omit `Minister' and substitute `Comptroller'. These paragraphs provide for rights of review by the AAT in respect of certain powers which are to be transferred from the Minister to the Comptroller-General. However, the powers to make, revoke and vary quota orders under sections 132B and 132C would also be transferred by the Bill, and paragraphs 273GA (e) and (f) providing for the review of decisions under those sections should therefore likewise be amended to omit `Minister' and substitute `Comptroller'. Proposed amendment 3 would accomplish this.

speech.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —The Government is happy to accept the amendments. They are constructive and consistent with the general debate on this legislation. I referred earlier to some comments made by Senator Harradine. I had some inquiries made during the course of the debate. The question related to investigation by Customs into the subject of Lada-Niva cars and componentry. In dealing with that question I referred to discussions I had in Moscow last year, I said with embassy officials and trade commission officials. Certainly one of those present was the senior trade commissioner in the Soviet Union. The senior trade commissioner had not long before then made a visit to the Lada-Niva factory and had made some inquiries about this matter. In October 1984 he presented the Customs Service with a report which included this passage:

speech.para: To the extent that it has been possible to do so in the USSR-
that is a question which has some difficulty about it-
specific inquiries and observations have revealed no discernible use of slave or convict labour in the manufacture of the cars.

There were in fact two inquiries made, one in writing and one by a visit to the manufacturer in respect of which the trade commissioner reported to the Customs Service. In the absence of other material it has to rely on that letter in exercising its duty under the relevant section. Of course that is unsatisfactory, but that situation will always remain unsatisfactory until the section is reviewed. I thank senators for their support.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —The position is unsatisfactory. As the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) said, this particular matter had been raised with the trade commissioner on his observation after a visit to the Lada-Niva factory. In nothing I said, and I was repeating what had come out of the Soviet Union, was there any suggestion that at the Lada-Niva factory in Toghatigrad there was slave labour.
—I know precisely what you said.

—I was talking about component parts and referring to specific places which had been nominated by reputable persons who had come from the Soviet Union and who had been in prison camps there where specific component parts had been manufactured-to give three examples, rubber tyres, chassis and springs. The letter I wrote to the Minister was back in 1983. I had heard nothing from him since that time until now. The point has been made that were specific details are alleged by Soviet prisoners, surely that information should be followed up specifically in respect of those prison camps. Clearly this has not been done. Surely it is in the interests of Australian workers and in the interest of international human rights for the Customs Service to ask the manufacturers of Lada vehicles where their spare parts are made. Obviously that has not been done in writing.

speech.para: It should be done in writing so that if further evidence comes from prisoners in the Soviet Union, it is clear that the information given to our officials in Moscow would then be proven to be incorrect and action taken. But, quite frankly, since reputable people have raised the issue, not only in general terms but have also specified the camps where the particular components are being made, surely in fairness to them and to the manufacturing industry here, in order to discharge their obligations under article 16 of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations, the Customs Service should require a written statement from Lada as to the source of the manufacture of spare parts. That is the next step to which we ought to move, and, as the Minister said in reporting what the Senior Trade Commissioner said, in so far as it is possible to do so in the Soviet Union--

talk.start.para: —Of course, I agree. What are you talking about?
—That is right; it is very difficult.
—You cannot overturn the Soviet system on the basis of Article 16 of the Customs Regulations.
—I am not suggesting that.
—You are.
—No. What Senator Button has just said is that the Trade Commissioner went down to the Lada factory. It is a very serious matter.
—Of course it is a serious matter, but your argument cannot be taken seriously. That is what I say.
—Why not?
—Because you cannot overturn the Soviet regime on the basis of a Customs regulation in Australia, much as you would like to do that.

—Order! I suggest that remarks be directed through the Chair. I remind Senator Harradine that we are dealing at present with technical amendments, which I should like to dispose of. If he wishes to follow up this matter later in the debate, that is fine.
—I thought that we had disposed of the amendments.

speech.para: Amendments agreed to.

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —I should like some clarification on section 183 of the Customs Act. It relates to this Bill. It relates also, I think, to some of the Minister's comments in response to my remarks during the second reading debate. I am not sure that I have got the matter quite clear and I seek clarification. As I understand it, under the existing legislation, the Comptroller-General of Customs has various powers in relation to suspension, revocation and non-renewal of Customs agents' licences. Under section 183CQ of the Customs Act, the Comptroller-General may give notice that he believes that a Customs agent has not performed his duties in a satisfactory manner. Any notice shall state in part that the Comptroller-General intends to refer to the National Customs Agents Licensing Advisory Committee for investigation and report to the Minister the question whether the Minister should take action in relation to the licence under sub-section (1) of section 183CS. Where the Comptroller-General gives notice in accordance with section 183CQ, he shall refer the question of whether the Minister should take action in relation to the licence under sub-section 183CS (1) to the Committee for investigation and report to the Minister.

speech.para: Section 183CR gives the Comptroller-General the power to suspend a Customs agent's licence for an interim period. Such suspension has effect until the suspension is revoked by the Comptroller-General or the Minister has dealt with the matter in accordance with section 183CS, whichever first occurs. Under the proposed changes in the Bill that we are debating, to transfer the Minister's powers to the Comptroller-General, the powers of the Minister under section 183CS will become the powers of the Comptroller-General. The relevant sub-section of section 183CS is sub-section (2). It would appear that the Comptroller-General would then have the power to review his own decision.

Section 273GA of the Customs Act, about which we were talking earlier, in sub-section (1) (k), provides for all decisions in relation to Customs agents' licences under Part XI of the Customs Act to be appellable to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; that is, the decision of the Comptroller-General to give a notice under section 183CQ is reviewable-as I fully accept-by the AAT. His decision to refer the matter to the Committee is reviewable by the AAT, as is his decision to suspend a licence for an interim period. That review mechanism appears to get over the problem of the Comptroller-General reviewing his own decisions, but I would appreciate the Minister's verification, or otherwise, of what I have said. It is a point that has been raised with us by the Customs Agents Institute. I understand that, as the Minister said in his reply to the second reading debate, the Customs Agents Federation has no problem with the proposal. However, there seems to be some confusion on the part of the Institute on this matter, and I would appreciate clarification. If my understanding, as I have just stated it, is correct, I should not be pressing the matter further. If my understanding is incorrect, the Opposition would like to suggest a technical amendment.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —Senator Short's understanding is absolutely correct. The Comptroller-General of Customs may act-if I may put it thus for the purposes of comment-for preliminary suspension. The matter then goes to the Committee. After the Committee has reported to him, he may then review his own decision in light of the Committee's report. All of the steps are subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —Senator Button indicated that it was my argument that could not be taken seriously, not that the issue could not be taken seriously. My argument does not go to the question of Item 16 of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations overturning the whole of the Soviet system. My argument is simply that, once questions have been raised about the manufacture of particular goods and those questions involve the use of slave labour or compulsory labour, it surely is a requirement of departmental officials of the Australian Customs Service to take every step possible to check out those questions that have been raised. Senator Button says that those questions are raised by me. They did not originate from me; they originated from persons who had been working under the regime of the Soviet Union. The questions were raised not in a broad-based, broad brush manner; they were raised naming specific camps in which specific items of component parts were manufactured.

speech.para: In my view, what has thus far been done to check that out is insufficient and would, of course, get the answer that was obtained by the Senior Trade Commissioner. Indeed, to be fair to him, he indicated that it was in so far as his task in the Soviet Union was concerned. But I venture to suggest that if the specific questions were asked of the manufacturer and of the importer and a specific requirement were made of both the manufacturer and the importer to answer those specific questions, there would be a record in the Department of those answers, which then could be made freely available to the Senate or to the Parliament generally, or to the public. Persons who have experience of the slave labour system of the Soviet Union could be in a position to challenge them. That is all that I am saying. It has to be done in a specific manner. If people are not prepared to answer the specific allegations, it would be proper for the Comptroller to refuse entry of those goods.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
