debate.title:
HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION BILL 1985
HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1985
HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985
AUSTRALIAN BILL OF RIGHTS BILL 1985

proctext.para: Consideration resumed from 18 March.
AUSTRALIAN BILL OF RIGHTS BILL
Clause 8 (Australian Bill of Rights).
Article 4 (Effect of Bill of Rights on existing rights and freedoms).
(Quorum formed)

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I do not want to delay the debate on Article 4. I simply say that in the days since we last debated the legislation I have had time to carefully read what the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) has said as justification for reconciling the two paragraphs. One gives every person the right without discrimination to equal protection. The second finds no clear support in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights for discrimination in favour. As I understand it, the Minister admitted first that there is no clear statement inside the Covenant-he said that we must take a risk in these things-and finally said that the matter is implicit and will be found in an interpretation of the words `equal protection of the law'. The Minister is really arguing that an American body of law and American court decisions allow this form of affirmative action in terms of the general principle that every person has a right without discrimination to equal protection of the law.

speech.para: Whilst I am aware of the American body of law, I believe that it is a pretty flimsy basis for this kind of principle. I do not believe that one should bring forward a Bill of Rights which, step by step, shows that it is precariously based. If we are to publish this Bill of Rights as an inspirational document, it ought to be published not caveat emptor, but with the utmost faith. In other words, those who read it have the right to believe that the Government is putting this forward secure in the knowledge that it has a constitutional head of power that is most unlikely to be contaminated. If that were not so, why would we do it? Yet step by step, as we saw with the previous Article, Article 3 (1), there is really no constitutionally sound head of power in the Article.

I do not want to dilate on this matter because we have had a very interesting and useful debate. I thank the Minister for what he has said but I find no comfort in it. I do not believe that the Australian people should rely on either risk-taking or on some belief that perhaps an argument in our courts would necessarily reflect the American courts. There is an ample body of evidence to show that from time to time our courts do not think the same way and do not accept American precedents. In any case, I come back to the fundamental. There is no sense in having a Bill of Rights, no sense in putting forward this so-called inspirational document, unless it can be put to the people as a document containing 32 articles which stand firmly on their own. We should be able to argue that people can rely on the articles. If, as has thoroughly emerged from virtually every paragraph, the whole of this Bill of Rights is to be litigated in endless arguments before the court, we do not have a Bill of Rights at all; the Australian people do not know what are the limitations and parameters of their rights. The only thing to do is what most people cannot do-test them. I put it firmly to the Minister that any legislation that paragraph by paragraph is found to be totally uncertain should not be put forward to the people as offering them any security or comfort. As I described it, it is a piece of wormwood in many ways because everywhere we probe we find holes, uncertain ground. We find that we cannot be sure that there is a head of power. While thanking the Minister for his explanation, I find no comfort in it.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —I do not want to take that as an invitation to open up the whole argument once again about what a Bill of Rights is about and why generalised guarantees are justified. I simply make the point that inevitably when one is dealing with innovative legislation of a kind for which there are few or no precedents in our own legal tradition it is inevitable that there will be a debate of this kind, and questions of the kind that Senator Sir John Carrick is raising, put in issue in the course of the parliamentary consideration. I think that is not in any way itself an indication of defects in the legislation, it is just something that flows naturally from the very innovative and unique, in the Australian legal tradition, character of this legislation. That is an argument we had on the second reading and I do not think it is useful to track back over it.

speech.para: I would like to add another word or two, though, on the subject of the justification for Article 4 (2), in the light of what Senator Sir John Carrick has said this morning. On Tuesday when we last debated this I said that Article 4 (2) of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 was implicit in the equality provisions of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. I want to make clear that I was doing so on the basis essentially of a conceptual argument about the necessary character of an equal protection guarantee, making the point that it is a necessary part of that concept that it be able to accommodate rational discrimination and differentiation of treatment based on reasonable objective discernible grounds, and that to that extent the concept of a positive discrimination or benign discrimination was indeed conceptually compatible and really part of the concept of equal protection. I was not calling in aid United States of America authority on the basis of an appeal to authority as such, but really simply to indicate that in the United States, as elsewhere where this particular principle is embodied in domestic systems of law, the courts have had no difficulty in accepting the principle that equal protection of the law does accommodate and allow benign discrimination in appropriate circumstances.

A further point that I want to make now, having checked the matter further, is that the fact that this concept is implicit in the equality provisions of the Covenant does in fact emerge clearly from the travaux preparatories relating to the Covenant. The report of the work of the Third Committee at the seventeenth session of the General Assembly of the United Nations had this to say about one of the equality provisions in Article 2 (1) of the Covenant. I remind the Senate that the reports of these committees are in fact the summary form Hansard reports of the debate which preceded the agreement about these various clauses. What was said in that report was as follows:

It was expressly emphasized by several members of the Committee that special measures for the advancement of any socially and educationally backward sections of society should not be construed as `distinction' within the meaning of Article 2. The Committee agreed that that interpretation, to which there was no objection, should be specially mentioned in the report.

While that passage relates, of course, to the prohibition on distinction mentioned in Article 2 (1) of the Covenant, I think that idea is clearly equally applicable to the prohibition on the word `discrimination' as it appears in Article 26 of the Covenant. As I indicated previously, there is some degree of cross-pollination between articles 2 and 26 of the Covenant and some of the different equality concepts appear in both of them.

I make the further point that that view expressed by the Third Committee is perfectly consistent with the prevailing view at international law that equality provisions of the kind embodied in articles 2 (1) and 26 are not intended to proscribe protective measures designed to safeguard the rights of groups in need of special protection. The development of that view at international law is described in a very informative article entitled `The Meaning of Discrimination in International and Municipal Law' by Dr W. A. McKean in 1970, in Volume 44 of the British Year Book of International Law, at page 177 in an article.

As a matter of domestic Australian law, the Government took the view in drafting this section as it now appears that there would be some danger, having regard to the rather literal approach to interpretation which has been a characteristic of the common law of statutory interpretation, that domestic Australian courts might just be minded to construe Article 4 (1) as prohibiting any difference of treatment. Any such literal interpretation, if applied to that Article, would obviously make that paragraph far too broad if it stood alone. It is probably unlikely that the courts would so construe the clause insofar as certain negative treatment of particular people is concerned, but they might regard it as uncertain in its operations insofar as laws singling people out for special positive benefits are concerned. There is a danger that laws conferring special benefits on the disabled and so on might conceivably be struck down by a literally minded court. Because of that danger of misconstruction of Article 4 (1), it was decided to spell out in Article 4 (2) what that Third Committee expressly said was meant by the equality provisions in the International Covenant.

I think that against that background it can be appreciated that 4 (2) in no way adds to or alters the effect of the Covenant provisions but merely reflects the intention of the drafters. So I do call in aid a further head of authority, apart from just running the straight conceptual argument, and that head of authority is the people who drafted the language in question to which the courts can, of course, have regard in interpreting its effect. On that basis, I do not really think there is any serious reason to doubt that Article 4 (2) will be held to be constitutionally valid.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —I do not see what all the argument is about because, as I see it, the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 does not need to rest on the external affairs power.
—That is a new line. What can it rest on if it is not the external affairs power?
—I just make the point that, whilst we might be arguing that here and the Minister might say that it rests on the external affairs power, the Bill does not say that.
—It does not need to.

—Yes, but what the Minister says does not matter since the High Court of Australia can validate the legislation or particular provisions within it under one or a number of powers. Kitto J. summarised the principles in Fairfax v Commissioner of Taxation, when he said:

speech.para: A speculative inquiry as to which of the main topics touched upon by legislation was the main pre-occupation of those who enacted it has nothing to do with the question of constitutional validity under s.51.

Under that section the question is always one of subject-matter to be determined by reference solely to the operation which the enactment has, i.e. by reference to the nature of the rights, duties, powers and privileges which it changes, regulates and abolishes; is it in its real substance a law upon ``with respect to'', one or more of the enumerated subjects, or is there no more in it in relation to any of those subjects than an interference so incidental as not in truth to affect its character.

I am not a lawyer but that is the advice that one has to try to get in these sorts of things, when one is trying to grapple with what might happen in the High Court on these particular questions. Clearly the objects outlined in clause 3 of the Bill do not only refer to this Bill as implementing the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. It goes broader than that. Therefore, it is arguable that the court could take a view that, no matter what we say here, it need not rely for its validity on the external affairs power.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —I am indebted to Senator Harradine for reminding me of the Fairfax case, even if I mention to him--
—Were you in it?

—I was not in it. I mention to Senator Harradine that it is a courtesy that one lawyer gives to another to indicate that he is reminding the other lawyer of a case which it is perfectly possible that, firstly, the lawyer has never heard of or, secondly, if he has heard of he has forgotten. In deference to Senator Harradine's bush lawyerly qualifications, I am employing a similar courtesy in this debate. I was going to make the point in passing that His Honour, Mr Justice Kitto, was one of the more robust strikers down of Commonwealth law for failure to be justified by reference to one or other heads of Commonwealth power and the suggestion that one could embark upon a speculative adventure of the kind that Senator Harradine is, in effect, inviting us to do, based on Mr Justice Kitto's observations, has a certain irony for anyone who is familiar with these constitutional principles.

speech.para: That is all very well. It is perfectly true that the law has to be looked at on its own merits. It does not matter what label it happens to be wearing; it is whether or not a connection can be found of an appropriate kind with some head or other of Commonwealth constitutional power. That is perfectly true. The difficulty is, I suggest, to find some label to justify either this legislation as a whole or individual clauses of it other than the external affairs power. There may or may not prove to be additional support for particular clauses, for example--

talk.start.para: —You are only applying it to the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth has absolute power to do that. It does not need the external affairs power.

—To the extent that an executive inquiry power is given, as Senator Walters will no doubt be anxious to tell us again in relation to State public servants and so on, and to the extent that it has the potential to be applied, I suppose, at some stage in the future should Parliament ever be so minded to extend it to the States, it is important that these principles be sorted out and that we have legislation that will stand up in whatever context it might be challenged. I do not prolong the debate. I simply acknowledge the point that Senator Harradine is making, but say with the utmost respect that I do not think it is of any great help in justifying this exercise.

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —The Minister has frequently used the phrase `benign discrimination'. It would be helpful, to me certainly, if he would tell me what that phrase means. It seems that the meaning of the phrase itself could be argued in the courts. On my understanding of its meaning, let me take the case of two people who apply for a significant job. One person is disabled. The other is not disabled and has significantly more talent. However, the disabled person gets the job. In other words, there has been an affirmative action. There has been a discrimination in favour. As I understand it, fundamentally there has been a major discrimination against an Australian citizen-the person who has failed to get the job. I do not understand how, on the one hand, we can assert that there are equal rights and, on the other hand, discriminate in favour. Nothing in the second paragraph of Article 4 says that one can discriminate against. Does benign discrimination imply that it is all right to do so, provided there is no victim? Suppose that there is a victim. Where in paragraph 2 of Article 4 is there anything to suggest that, in discriminating in favour of somebody, one can justify one's discrimination against somebody else? I ask for a simple explanation.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: — The expression `benign discrimination' is one for which I have a personal affection as I used it in this Article, to which I referred earlier.
—Did you coin that phrase?

—No, but I pre-dated this seminal Article. De gustibus non est disputandum. It is a purely arbitrary choice whether one accepts that language or the language of positive discrimination. Affirmative action is, I think, a different concept again, but one in the same family. There is no particular magic attached to it. The whole argument about benign discrimination, obviously, is at its most intense when what we are talking about is not simply singling someone out for a benefit, such as a disabled pension or something of that kind, but where a disbenefit to someone else necessarily is associated with the action in question, such as the sort of situation Senator Sir John Carrick put forward. It has been most vigorously argued in the context of quota legislation which has been enacted in some American jurisdictions, most notoriously, and which has the effect of giving guaranteed places, whether for jobs, university courses or whatever to members of particular allegedly disadvantaged minority groups in society, the corollary of which has been that others, who are perhaps better qualified for the job or place in question but who are not of that minority status, have missed out. That has been the subject of litigation and so on in the United States under its constitution. Ground rules have evolved, which I do not want to go into now, for dealing with that subject.

speech.para: If one is going to discriminate benignly against someone in a way which generates direct, immediate and obvious disbenefits for someone else, the argument has to be that, if that is justified, it has to be justified by some very clear, overriding and obvious principled justification, and there can be many arguments in practice about that. It would be a question for the courts to resolve here, I suppose, as in the United States, whether any particular claimed justification for the discrimination satisfied the particular criteria that are set out in the Bill-that it is a discrimination set in train for the purpose of redressing any disabilities particularly suffered by that class or arising from discrimination against it. One would have to establish all those logical connections.

I hasten to add that no policy proposals are in the pipeline in relation to women, blacks or anyone else so far as Commonwealth legislation is concerned which would raise these questions in a stark way in the forseeable future. I simply make the point that this situation can arise and, to the extent that it does, it is justifiable in principle, given the way in which equal protection guarantees have traditionally been interpreted in every jurisdiction where they have existed. We can have a long argument about the philosophical justification for benign discrimination in the various circumstances that I have posited. But that is an argument that is better held in the context of working out whether any particular exercise in benign discrimination is justified in all the circumstances of the case. That is where such an argument should be had, rather than in the present context, where this Article simply acknowledges the existence of the principle and the desirability of its being carefully thought through in any real world situation that might arise.

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I was not in any way seeking to argue the philosophical justification or otherwise of affirmative action in any particular case. I am concerned that the Minister has found it necessary to make a disclaimer that the Government did not intend to do certain things. That very disclaimer backs up my assertion that the Minister must therefore, see the ability under this provision for a government to do what I have described. Whether doing so is good or bad is not the question. I am trying to extract the meaning of `benign discrimination', not argue whether it is good or bad. I think the Minister has said that the phrase `benign discrimination', which he has grappled to his bosom as his own, and which I accept as his personal acquisition, has not in itself any legal meaning. It may be immortalised; I wish him luck. He has suggested that I be immortalised for the word `journey'. We all have our little quirks. Let us continue to have them. I welcome his. My objection is that the expression is very partisan. It indicates that it is benign because it helps the disabled, but it disguises the fact that it could be malign because it discriminates against another who, on all other grounds, may be much more skilled and a much more justifiable selection for a position. What really is being said-and we have to be very careful of euphemisms in this-is that we are inventing another John Stuart Mill principle, and it may be good or it may be bad. What we are saying, as I see it, is that, in the interests of human concern to assist the disabled, we are willing to deny a fundamental right to someone who is not disabled even though that person may have qualifications far above those of the disabled person. As I say, I am not adjudicating; I am simply saying that we should be careful what we are saying in terms of euphemisms and that a Bill of Rights is of no use at all if all it does is to recite platitudes which, stripped down, mean something else.

speech.para: I now discover that really it would be possible under this Article to do what the Americans, rightly or wrongly, have done in enforcing a situation in which certain disadvantaged and disabled people shall be given preference over others. That is an argument for policy. What we are really trying to do is find where the ceiling rests in this situation and what it allows. Am I right, first of all, in my restatement of a fifth principle of John Stuart Mill when I say that what this really says is that we can justify denying a freedom to an individual, even though that individual may have on every other ground the right to that freedom, if we assist a disabled person? Is that the principle?

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —The concept of benign discrimination has a whole variety of applications right across the spectrum. There are some very easy cases-for example, rural subsidies, widows' pensions, and measures to assist the physically or mentally handicapped-about which there is no controversy and where there is no obvious counterpoint. At the other end of the spectrum are the very hard cases involving quotas and so on established for particular jobs whereby people are singled out for preferment or advantage based purely on some criterion which might arguably not be the most appropriate criterion for determining who fills that place. That is the classic quota exercise of a kind which in fact has now been struck down by the United States Supreme Court as incompatible with the equal protection objective. I am referring to the Bakker case, in which a white applicant for a university position, better qualified in terms--
—Reverse discrimination.

—Reverse discrimination is another way of putting it, as is benign or positive. This applicant was discriminated against in the sense that he lost his place to a less well qualified member of a minority group. That is the hard case of benign discrimination or reverse discrimination which I was simply being honest enough-maybe that is an undesirable trait to adopt in this debate-to use to indicate that there are very real difficulties of principle about that, and I acknowledge the force of what Senator Sir John Carrick is saying.

speech.para: Then there are, between the easy cases and the hard cases, many middle order cases of which, I suppose, in the Australian context, the clearest example would be Aboriginal land rights legislation. The honourable senators can think of the Northern Territory land rights legislation enacted by the Fraser Government. Aboriginal land rights legislation is what I describe as a middle order case because, while, on the one hand, it is a clear example of the application of the principle, within the language of Article 4 (2), of discriminating in favour of a class of person for the purpose of redressing any disabilities particularly suffered by that class or arising from discrimination against that class, it is not as simple a case as the rural subsidy or deserted wives' pension case, nor is there an immediately visible person who misses out as a result of the favoured treatment being given. There is a class of people, white Northern Territorians, who would argue that they have missed out by virtue of the special or favoured treatment being given to Aboriginal people in the operation of this legislation. It is an argument that one can well understand; one hears it all the time.

What I suppose this legislation is trying to put beyond doubt, and what Article 4 (2) is therefore saying, is that the courts must recognise that there is this extra legitimate dimension to equal protection rights and that it is compatible with discriminatory legislation which is nonetheless based on some objective, fair, reasonable and discernible principle. I suppose that in a particular case, were someone minded to challenge the validity of the Northern Territory land rights legislation calling in aid the equal protection clause, Article 4 (2) is there as a directive to the courts to respond in an appropriate way and to give recognition to that particular example of non-equal protection. Simply to pick out a hard case of the application of the benign discrimination concept is not, I think, to meet the concerns that the Government has felt about all this and the reasoning which has led us to incorporate that language in the Bill.

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —To follow that up for a moment, when I was a member of the Fraser Government, which brought in Aboriginal land rights, I was not aware that we were relying on the Covenant to do that. We seemed to be able to do it without any need for a Bill of Rights or anything else. It seemed quaint to use it, if I may say so. Equally, in many of the things in which I have participated over the years the principle of Article 4 (2) has been a principle of affirmative action that I have espoused and willingly wanted to implement without going to the Covenant.

speech.para: I think that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) may understand me. I am probing this because of my fear that a Bill of Rights in writing will limit something that we have taken for granted in the past. I am probing it not because I do not find virtue in Article 4 (2)-of course I do, in many cases-but because I believe, first of all, that it is unconstitutional, which could be a disaster in itself, and, secondly, that it could be restrictive in itself. The Minister said that the case that I put up was a hard case. I am well aware that such cases make bad laws. I do not regard it as a hard case; I regard it as one of many cases. After all, let us take the American situation of disadvantaged people being given rights in colleges and universities. Time and time again others with much higher academic qualifications were knocked back. I am not arguing whether that is right or wrong. I am asking whether this Article allows that kind of situation or does not allow it. I ask the Minister to respond to that.

speech.speaker: Jessop Sen D.S.

talk.start.para: —I too want to refer to Article 4 (1) and Article 4 (2). Of course, everyone should have the right without any discrimination to equal protection before the law, which I would have thought already existed, but it appears to me that the second part of Article 4 suggests that, if any anyone is unequal, he or she ought to be made equal in some way or other, because the Article says:

speech.para: Nothing in this Bill of Rights affects the operation of any earlier or later law by reason only of the fact that the law discriminates in favour of a class of persons for the purposes of redressing any disabilities particularly suffered by that class or arising from discrimination against that class.

Senator Evans referred to land rights for Aborigines in the Northern Territory. What about the example of Aboriginal people who can attract especially low rates of interest on housing loans, as exists in other parts of Australia? It seems to me that people in the lower socio-economic group, people in other ethnic or racial groups, European or what have you, could conceivably use this Article to suggest that they should not be paying 17 per cent interest but should also be entitled to a home loan at an interest rate of 4 1/2 per cent to 5 1/2 per cent. That to me shows the absolutely ridiculous nature of this human rights legislation. The Minister may have a logical, rational, reasonable answer to that point.

talk.start.para: —Article 4 (2) does not state that there is an obligation on governments or anyone else to legislate or to take other action in favour of anyone around the place who can plausibly claim to have suffered some disability and for which he or that group requires redress. I repeat that 4 (2) does not create any obligation on anybody to do anything. All that 4 (2) says is that, if government makes a policy decision embodied in legislation to give some favourable treatment to a particular class of persons, based on some rational considerations relating to the past experience of that group, that particular law will not be struck down as offensive to the principle of equal protection of the law. That is all that 4 (2) is about.
—It is affirmative action then?

—I thank Senator Sheil. I have acknowledged that it is affirmative action, if he wants to use that particular expression, which is an imprecise one. I do not think that assists us. The reason it is necessary to give some acknowledgment of this albeit that it is probably implicit in the concept of equal protection law, as I have argued all along, is that the equal protection concept is one that, read absolutely literally, would imply that all people should be treated exactly the same no matter what differences there are between them. I have argued, and it is recognised in most jurisdictions, that in fact that is not the way in which the equal protection concept is applied. Equal protection means that prima facie everyone is to be treated exactly alike unless there are reasonable, rational, objectively discernible grounds for treating them differently.
—I suggest that they ought to be unequal.

—But that is the way our whole legal system operates. For instance, taxpayers are treated differently depending on the level of income they receive. That is a discriminatory treatment, if one likes. It is not equal protection of the law to set rates at 46 per cent for some people, 30 per cent for others and 60 per cent for others. But it is a rational ground of distinction on which to base the rate of tax. There are innumerable other examples; the whole legal system is full of them. Equal protection is not a blunderbuss that carves a way through any sort of legal provision which discriminates affirmatively or negatively, for or against, a particular group of people. The equal protection principle is simply one that states that any law is at risk if it does treat people differently unless there is some rational ground for doing so. That is inherent in the principle of equal protection. It is further spelt out in 4 (2) to deal with one particular class of issue that arises very often and which is so often misunderstood that it was felt desirable to try to articulate it in terms of the legislation itself. But there are no basic issues of principle here that are as offensive as Senator Jessop and others seem to think is possible.
—Do I understand from what the Minister has said that this applies to any law, State or Federal, or just purely Commonwealth law?

—To the extent that the Bill is directed only to Commonwealth law and that courts can strike down only a Commonwealth or territory law that is inconsistent with the legislation-it cannot strike down a State law that is inconsistent-in that sense, of course, it is applicable only to Commonwealth law. As Senator Walters will remind me, with all of the inexorability of the sun rising in the east and setting in the west, there are aspects of the Bill which do allow the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to investigate what goes on at the State level. But in terms of the robust primary operation of the Bill as outweighing and overruling inconsistent legislation, no, that is not applicable to the State.

—I ask the Minister a question out of genuine interest and curiosity. When he was referring to Articles 4 (1) and 4 (2) he talked about a rational explanation for discrimination. Article 4 (1) states that every person has the right without any discrimination to the equal protection of the law. What would be the situation with the different age at which males and females receive pension entitlements and retirement benefits?
— That is a good question, and it is one that has exercised--
—My mum rang me.

—It is the first evidence of the honourable senator's humanity that we have had for a long time in this chamber. That is a good question as to whether the traditional distinction between men and women with regard to a whole variety of benefits and provisions around the place conferred by Commonwealth legislation is in fact consistent with the equal protection concept. It has been argued out and litigated in the United States of America, I think. There it has been held that for a whole variety of reasons those age differentiations are in fact permissible. I have been reminded, to employ again that lawyerly convention-I did not know but I have been reminded-that there was some litigation in Europe before the European court under the European convention in which Britain was arguing in favour of discriminatory pension systems as between men and women, based on--
—Arguing in favour of it?

—It was arguing about the legitimacy of discriminating in the way that we do. The court in question held that it was an illegitimate discrimination. Maybe this is one of the corollaries of this which will give the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, budgetary nightmares to contemplate. But, under this legislation, it is capable of being overridden, of course. We are not talking about an absolute overriding constitutional guarantee. But that is an excellent example of the kind of issue that governments will be forced to confront as a result of the passage of the Bill of Rights, and so we should confront it. As Senator Walters will acknowledge, it is pretty hard, when one thinks about it, to justify that tradition of discriminating between men and women in terms of eligibility age for a pension. No doubt Senator Walters, with her infinite capacity to rationalise everything, will say that it is impossible that there could be anything in this Bill that could possibly be of any use to anyone. No doubt she will leap to her feet and tell us that in a moment. But it is an example of people or governments being forced to go back to first principles and defend these things. If they cannot be defended in principle, one must at least make a conscious and overt decision for practical reasons, for compelling budgetary reasons or something else, to override them, but at least one has to acknowledge that there is an issue of principle there. It is a good question and I hope that I have given it a frank answer.

—Will the Minister just answer very simply, in not many words, who decides which of the groups, which class of people, has the ability to have discrimination in favour of them? Is it the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, is it the law or what is it? I just want to know whether the Commission actually decides whether one group is eligible and another is not.

— Article 4 (2) is really written as an instruction to the courts in the exercise of their power under this legislation, or the power that they will have in five years time when the legislation comes into effect in this way. It is an instruction to the courts to uphold the validity of laws that have already been enacted or that may be enacted in the future that single out classes of people that arguably satisfy this description. I suppose it gives some guidance to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission if the Commission is reporting upon the legitimacy or otherwise of some particular law that presently exists or is proposed. The Commission would undoubtedly have regard to Article 4 (2) and could look at the criteria and say what it thinks of them. But it should be noted that what we are talking about is not an open invitation to some group or other in the community to claim that it ought to be singled out for special treatment. What we are talking about is a protective device to protect actual laws that have been enacted, a policy decision having been made to give some favourable treatment to some particular group.
—Therefore, the Commission could decide that that class of people really should not be discriminated in favour of and the law could override the Commission in that regard.
— The Commission cannot decide anything on these matters.
—Well, it could strike down a law which it believes--
—The Commission cannot strike down anything. The Commission does not have powers to do anything of the kind.
—It can make that decision. It can make that report to the Minister.

—Order! Can we have just one speaker at a time and not a cross-chamber conversation, please. Senator Evans, have you grasped enough of Senator Walters's question to be able to answer it coherently or would you like her to repeat it?

—The Commission does not decide anything. The Commission reports and makes recommendations. To the extent that the Commission is asked to make a report about the operation of some law which raises this question, yes, the Commission could say that in its opinion the particular group which was singled out for favourable treatment is not one that satisfies this particular description and the law accordingly does not appear to be justified under Article 4 (2). That is possible, but it is Parliament which has the last word, because if Parliament does not like what the court does, under this whole scheme the Parliament would have the capacity to override it.

—As I understand it, this Article also could apply to unionists. Indeed, quite legitimately it could be said that unionists are a class of people that are discriminated in favour of and that is by reason of redressing a disability because they are paying union dues while other employees in the same business or industry are not paying union dues. Therefore, it could indeed be classed as a group which needs discrimination in its favour. I can see tremendous problems associated with my scenario. Can the Minister tell me whether the Human Rights Commission already has had approaches made to it to the effect that there has been discrimination against people for not being union members? What is the situation in that regard? These people feel that in their employment area they have been discriminated against purely because they are not union members. What are the decisions which have been taken in this area?

—I think this is a matter which is better addressed under the clause concerning freedom of association. I am not sure what the experience of the Human Rights Commission has been in relation to complaints being made to it or reports which in fact it has issued.
—You can find out?

—I can find out in due course, but I do not think I can find out in the next two minutes. Perhaps I can find out and be armed to answer questions of that kind when we get to the clause which will undoubtedly attract some discussion about the trade unions, the right to join them and the implications of not being a union member. May I suggest that we leave that until then.
—We can leave that, but what about the other part of my question?
—I am sorry, what was the other part of the honourable senator's question?
—Would it be permissible for unions to be considered a class of people which should have laws discriminating in their favour under this particular Article?

— There are two separate questions. One question is whether it is legitimate under the principle of equal protection for laws to treat people unequally, based on certain characteristics-whether it is age, sex or union versus non-union membership, in the case of preference clauses and so on. That is one question which arises in any ordinary application of the equal protection principle. Another question is whether Article 4 (2) has some specific application which deals with one particular kind of unequal law. Article 4 (2) is not the only exception to the principle of absolute equality of treatment. There is a whole heap of unequal treatments that can be justified other than by reference to Article 4 (2). I am sure that the question would hardly even arise, in even the most adventurous unionist's breast, of seeking shelter under the protection of Article 4 (2). I cannot imagine that that would be so. I cannot conceive of a context in which that could arise.

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I asked the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) several questions. I asked him under what head of power we had brought in the land rights legislation. Also I asked him what heads of power were used for the various affirmative action and benign discrimination measures undertaken over the years. I did so because I want to know whether those heads of power which exist now might be constrained by the Bill of Rights. May we have a simple answer to those questions?

— The only land rights legislation we passed is for the Northern Territory. As such, it is based on the combination of the Territory's power under section 122 of the Constitution and, I suppose, the Aborigines'-people of any race-power under section 51 (xxvii). The social security legislation, which almost by definition is discriminatory as between different classes of persons, is based on section 51 whatever it is of the Constitution which gives the Commonwealth power to legislate in respect of old age and other classes of pension. I do not think it could be said that a constitutional issue would here arise. If the Bill of Rights legislation which we are now seeking to pass is a legitimate constitutional exercise of the Commonwealth's power and some prohibition or some element of the Bill of Rights is in conflict with another law which is also passed in legitimate use of the Commonwealth's constitutional power, it is simply up to the courts to resolve any inconsistency between the two laws in question. It is not a question of overriding the Constitution in all of this; it is just a question of the ordinary application of legal principles in the interpretation of conflicting Commonwealth laws.

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —Fundamentally, my worry is this. We seem to have got on pretty well, without a Bill of Rights, by using the section 51 powers of the Constitution which the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) has just referred to. We seem to have been able to fly fairly widely under that. I approve of that. I am worried about whether the Government is absolutely convinced that the wording and the nature of this Bill of Rights will not in any way conflict with what we have done or cause endless litigation to determine what it is all about.

— Senator Sir John Carrick keeps on wanting us to have a second reading argument in the interstices of the consideration of particular clauses. I do not believe that any mainstream Commonwealth legislation, in any area which is manifestly acceptable to the Australian community, will be put at risk by the operation of the Bill of Rights. It may be that there have been particular insensitive applications of Commonwealth law in the past, particular regulatory provisions which have excluded women from particular occupations, or things of that kind, which may well turn up. I am inclined to think that instances of unreasonable unequal treatment are more likely to turn up in the interstices of State law than in Commonwealth law, but to the extent that they do turn up it is important that they be able to be the subject of argument under the Bill of Rights. To the extent that people can identify problems of this kind, I am sure as often as not the Commonwealth will be only too happy to correct them without the need for extensive and expensive litigation. One of the utilities of the Bill of Rights is that it forces governments to look again at the statute books and to look again at their executive practices to ensure that things are operating in accordance with proper principles and are not just left to possible chance misapplications in an unfair way, as has happened often enough in the past.

speech.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: —I would like to come back to the discussion the Committee has been having about the constitutional justification for Article 4 (2). Senator Evans has admitted, and it is quite clear, that in fact there is no explicit provision in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights to support the inclusion of Article 4 (2) in the Bill of Rights. There has been debate on other aspects of Article 4 (2), but in relation to the question of its justification he has argued that it is implicit in the provisions in the Covenant which talk about equal protection of the law-as he has said, in a somewhat confused way, with which I entirely agree. He claimed that Article 4 (1) of the Bill of Rights makes the position more clear than the provision in the Covenant. That may or may not be so. It is not a very easy concept to make clear and it is not a very easy concept even to understand clearly. We know that is certainly a concept which leads to endless litigation and always will. This is the sort of objection that we will continually have to article after article in this Bill of Rights. There is no doubt that there will be-as happened in the United States of America-an enormous amount of use of the Bill of Rights by people trying to establish that there is something wrong in the law because it does not provide equal protection.

speech.para: Senator Evans, in justifying Article 4 (2), has relied on the implicit meaning of the Covenant. Of course, what he really is primarily relying on is a large amount of American case law and his own article which he has referred us to relies on such case law. I regret to say that I have not yet had the time to refer to that Article. I make the terrible confession that I have never actually read it but I hope to repair that serious omission in my legal education when I get time. I want to ask Senator Evans whether he relies entirely on the American jurisprudence and his own article and other implicit meanings that may be read into the Covenant. I ask him whether he relies solely on that or whether he relies in any way on the severability provisions contained in clause 47 in Part VI of the Bill which states:

If this Act exceeds the powers of the Parliament by reason of the inclusion in the Bill of Rights of a particular provision or particular provisions, this Act is intended to operate as if that provision, or those provisions, as the case may be, were omitted from the Bill of Rights.

I do not recall-I cannot pick it up in Hansard quickly-whether the Minister has used that as a way of overcoming the problem. If the courts decided that it was not within the Government's power for some reason, would clause 47 be of any assistance to the Government?

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: — Clause 47 is there as an expression of the Parliament's desire that a sub-clause which is found to be unconstitutional be severed and that the remainder of the Bill stand. In the absence of a clause such as clause 47 it is possible for the courts to take the view that they have not been given sufficient guidance as to Parliament's intention or will in this matter and, accordingly, they might strike the whole thing down. The reason clause 47 is there is to ensure that, if the courts reach a decision about some part of the Bill, they will sever it to the extent possible.

speech.para: I certainly have never mentioned clause 47 as an affirmative justification for any clause or sub-clause of the Bill. I have taken a very strong position, and will again when further baubles are offered in later amendments, that we ought not to embark on any adventures in relation to this Bill which would attach to it provisions which are manifestly unconstitutional or manifestly at risk constitutionally. I have taken that view all along and I will continue to take it throughout this debate. I have certainly argued for Article 4 (2), not on the basis that it is a kind of optional extra which might be a nice idea to have there and it does not matter if it gets thrown out at the end of the day as being unconstitutional, on the ground that it is necessarily implicit in the concept of equal protection. I further stated this morning, and it may be that Senator Durack was not in the chamber at that point, that I derived some assistance in that respect not only from the United States cases-which I certainly was not relying on as a forcible authority without more, but just as a supplementary assistance-but also, and I sought encouragement and support for this, from the paragraph in the report of the Third Committee at the Seventeenth Session of the General Assembly of the United Nations. I will repeat it for the record because I do not think Senator Durack could have been in the chamber; in other words, to the extent that special affirmative action measures were consistent with the concept of that distinction, no. There has been a consistent thread through all this that, while it is not based on any actual language in the Covenant-to that extent it might be thought to be a slightly risky enterprise to put it into the Bill of Rights-it is so bound up in the notion of equal protection in the way in which that concept has been construed and applied and the way in which it was clearly present in the minds of the drafters of this legislation that it is justified in its own right constitutionally.

talk.start.para: —I am sorry, perhaps I did not make my question clear. I know that the Minister has been arguing forcibly-we have listened to that argument for a long time-that Article 4 (2), its proper interpretation and all the rest of it, can be justified under the Covenant. What I am really concerned to know is whether the Minister argues that, in the event that all those arguments fail, the inclusion of Article 4 (2) will not be fatal to the Bill. In other words, by using clause 47, it will not be fatal to the Bill: Does the Minister argue that?

—I do argue that and I do not accept the suggestions of the Australian Law Council to the contrary that Article 4 (2) is somehow so inextricably connected with the mainstream fabric of the Bill that it will bring the whole edifice tumbling down if it should go; implausible, in my argument, as it may be that it would go.

—I just wish to take that further. The Minister has argued already that the further we get away from the language or the provisions of the Covenant the more risky the exercise becomes from a constitutional point of view. The Minister has argued that very specifically in relation to the addition of the word `disability' in Article 1 which the Committee has agreed to. The Minister has expressed a great deal of nervousness about our moving away from the words of the Covenant. Presumably now we can say that, if we can find something implicit in the Covenant, it will be all right. The Minister has said that Article 4 (2) is implicit. I would have thought that Article 4 (2) is very much a further removal from the words in the Covenant than the addition of the word `disability' in Article 1 (1). What the Minister is doing in Article 4 (2) is incorporating into the Bill of Rights a concept which has very wide ramifications. He did not like the words `affirmative action' but the sort of effect that Article 4 (2) will have will justify affirmative action in whatever form it may take. I know that this Government uses words in the way it wants them to be used by calling a Bill an affirmative action and equal opportunity Bill, which is not affirmative action in the ordinary sense of the words. It would even go so far as to cover a genuine affirmative action in the American sense of quotas. Therefore Article 4 (2) goes a very long way and has wide ramifications in regard to the powers of parliament, what it can do at various times and what it has done. It is a major departure, if it cannot be justified under the Covenant, of the arguments Senator Evans is advancing. Then I was interested to hear that he still thought that it would not affect the whole of the Bill because of the operation of Clause 47. I would point out that the argument he used in cautioning us and warning us and opposing the addition of the word `disability' in Article 1 was perhaps rather beside the point.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —Just for the record, I would remind Senator Durack that I said, in the context of the debate about disability, that that was a very minor example. I did not think there was any particular risk associated with the insertion of the word `disability'. I said that I was simply making the point at that stage foreshadowing a point that I would be making with much more vigour in the context of some later amendments that were proposed.

speech.para: The other string to my bow in relation to disability was that it seemed to me to be an arbitrary selection of one particular additional status ground when there are so many others jostling for potential attention, such as age, marital status and so on. There were other considerations than simply the notion of adding extra language to the Bill. I acknowledge the other points that Senator Durack made, but do not think I can add anything useful by way of answer to what I already have said in earlier replies.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —I have a couple of minor points. The wording of Article 4 (1) differs from that in Article 26 of the ICCP in that it uses the singular and not the plural. I wonder why the Government did that. I do not think the use of the singular does what the Covenant intended. The use of the plural surely would seem more appropriate when providing for equality.

speech.para: My second point follows the question asked by Senator Crichton-Browne. Senators who were not present when he was here should realise that the question related to Article 4 (2) and its application or possible application on the question of pensionable ages as between men and women. I have a similar question relating to the laws associated with the lifting of weights for workers, which in many areas is different as between men and women. My concern is that Article 4 may affect the protective provisions of those laws. I point out that under the Sex Discrimination Act protective weight-lifting limits for women will become unenforceable automatically as from 1 August 1986.

talk.start.para: —Was there not mention of this in the BHP case recently?
—I am not familiar with that case, but I will be interested in it. To give an example under the Tasmanian laws, and there are other examples--
—We hope to finish this part of the Bill by 12.45. May we try to get this clause before that time?
—If the Minister can give me an answer now.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —As to the singular and plural point, it is basically a matter of drafting style. I do not think there is any significance attached to it. We have used the concept of `every person' all the way through. I have already indicated that in drafting articles 26 and 1 of the Covenant into the language of this Bill of Rights, we have taken the concepts and reshuffled them, as it were, between those two articles. In the course of that the drafting has been expressed in the way it is. I will have a look at that question, but I do not honestly believe there is any significance attached to it.
—Will the Minister give me an answer to the other one later?

—As to the Sex Discrimination Act, which in effect rules out weight restrictions of the traditional kind which cannot be justified in any rational way other than as an employment discrimination mechanism in the past, they would be rubbed out and continue to be rubbed out by the primary effect of the equal protection clause in 4 (1). One would not have to sneak in with the help of 4 (2) to justify that particular equality principle applying.

speech.para: Article agreed to.
Progress reported.

speech.speaker: Missen Sen A.J.

talk.start.para: —I desire to speak on this, the day before the Afghanistan national day, about the conditions of Afghanistan people and our reaction to them. I did speak last year on the first day of Afghanistan's spring, which is recognised as its national day. I think it is important that we should constantly keep before the Australian people, and particularly the Australian media, the fact that Afghanistan is suffering a travail which has gone on now for six years of warfare which the Soviet Union has imposed upon that country. The valiant efforts of the mujihadeen have been such that they have resisted throughout that period attempts to subjugate them. We have made various gestures at various times in the past. We, in fact, boycotted the Olympic Games and our leaders have constantly said that we are at one with the Afghan people. I think that we should bear this in mind as we come to this matter today.

speech.para: I want to refer to the situation which is, I think, well known to honourable senators. The leader of the Afghan community in this country, General M. Nawaz Waziri, the President of the Afghan-Australian Islamic Cultural Association, in writing to me on 5 February 1986, had this to say:

. . . After the Russian invasion, the Afghan nation was confronted with countless problems such as homelessness, helplessness, tragical events. The bloody Russians did a lot of aggression to the innocent people of our beloved country. They used all kinds of power and razed to the ground hundreds of thousands of houses of people, Mosques, bazaars, towns, villages, and burnt up the harvests of the people and over four million people were forced to leave their beloved country and become refugees.
That situation continues today, with many people remaining outside Afghanistan. Something like one-fifth of the population has had to leave that country.

I think it is interesting in this regard to refer to remarks which were made by Mykola Mochvan, a former soldier of the Soviet Union Army who defected in Afghanistan. Writing in the autumn 1986 edition of the Australian-Ukrainian Review, he had this to say:

This war is being waged against the Afghan people by the leaders in the Kremlin and their Afghan quislings. The victims are the Afghan people and the young men of the Soviet Union who are forced to spill their blood for the imperialist ambitions of their masters in Moscow.

The governments of the democratic states expressed their outrage at first with loud protests and threats of economic sanctions against the Soviet aggressors. Today, we see the same governments and their most principled statesmen engaging in friendly talks with the tyrants of the Kremlin.
The tragedy of the Afghan nation is made worse by the silence of world public opinion.
This man, a Ukrainian, points out in the article that the problems are the same as those that his own people in the Ukraine have found over an even longer period of domination by the Soviet Union.

Thirdly-and I speak only very briefly of the travail and destruction that have taken place-I want to say something of the Soviet aggression in the light of international law. This has been referred to in a recent edition of Afghanistan, the first publication by the Australian Relief Committee for Afghanistan, of which I have the honour to be a patron. An article by Peter McMullin, the Chairman, points out that the intervention by the Soviet Union in Afghanistan has been in contravention of the principles of the Universal Declaration of the Rights of Peoples proclaimed in Algiers on 5 July 1976, which expresses ideals widely shared by an increasing number of men and women throughout the world.
Mr McMullin adds:

More specifically, the Soviet intervention clearly violates article 5 of this Declaration, which states that every people has the imprescriptible and inalienable right to self determination and to choose its own political status in complete freedom without any external interference.
He refers also to the following decision of the Permanent Peoples' Tribunal on Afghanistan held in Stockholm in May 1981:

The Tribunal-condemns the Soviet Union for Violation of the laws and customs of war-declares that such violations are closely linked to the inalienable rights of the Afghan people and that respect for the fundamental rights of peoples constitutes a sine qua non condition of the respect of elementary human values inherent in the laws of war.

We know that the United Nations Organisation has made a number of declarations of the same nature. There is no doubt that this is a war against the people, one contrary to international law, and one which we must constantly keep between the people and before the people so that we can persuade the Russians to take a different course.

I want also to mention today questions of aid and of migration. I think they are relevant and that we should consider them in co-ordination with what we are doing for the people of Afghanistan. We are, in Australia, giving some support-the Americans of course, are giving much more-to assistance to refugees. Three and a half million of the people of Afghanistan are in Pakistan and 800,000 are in Iran. They have to be supported and in due course have to be placed somewhere if this war is not going to be ended by some type of agreement. We, in Australia, in 1984-85 gave $4,939,000, nearly $5 million, mainly in food aid, particularly wheat, to the World Food Program. We also joined in the water drilling project of UHNHR. I think we have made a useful contribution but I would hope that our contribution will be greater because, clearly, there is a grave need to assist these people who are living in great poverty, in Pakistan particularly.

I want to turn now to another matter where I am very concerned that the Australian Government is not showing the same type of recognition. That is the question of the migration of Afghans to this country. I desire to put into the record certain letters because they show both the fears of the Afghan people here in Australia and the response of the Australian Government, which is not good enough at all. In the first place, an organisation known as Khodaye Khedmat Garran wrote, in very special terms, to the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) on 13 and 15 July, 1985 respectively. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letter which they sent.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
KHODAYE KHEDMAT GARRAN
P.O. Box 1429M,
Melbourne, 3001
Australia
Telephone: (03) 596 7576
Mr Bill Hayden,
Foreign Minister,
Parliament House, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600.
Dear Honourable,

As you know the crisis in Afghanistan getting worse, the Afghans people are really in trouble and suffering from post regim and communist, since, the invasion of Afghanistan some peace lover countries around the world do accept the Afghans as refugee and have had some sort of contribution for them every year.

However, we are aware that the Australian Government do accept some refugees from the other countries, and they have had contribution yearly to settle in Australia. I do believe that you have seen the situation personally in May this year and did talk with the Afghan Chief In Pakistan, we do appreciate that you condemned the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan and called for withdrawal of Soviet forces. Also the aid given to the Afghans proud people and Free Fighters. I am wondering why the Australian Government has no attention and some contribution for the Afghans potential refugees and innocent people? There are a few people who come under S.H.P. Family re-union and refugee programs, which is absolutely not good enough.
By the way, our request is from the Australian peace lover Government please, solve our big problems and give contribution for them as same as other countries to settle in Australia yearly.
Trusting in your sympathetic consideration of this particular matter.
Yours sincerely,
Sherehad Marshall.
Chairman.

talk.start.para: —In that letter they point out that some people need, want to and are trying to migrate to this country and urge the Government to take appropriate steps. The matter was referred by the Foreign Minister to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs for his particular attention. The Honourable Chris Hurford, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, replied on 28 August, 1985. I seek leave to incorporate that letter in Hansard.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
MINISTER FOR
IMMIGRATION &
ETHNIC AFFAIRS
The Hon. Chris HURFORD, M.P.
Parliament House, Canberra, ACT 2600
REF/VB:MT
Mr Sherahmd Marshall
Chairman
Khodaye Khedmat Garran
PO Box 1429M
MELBOURNE, VIC. 3001
Dear Mr Marshall

Thank you for your letter of 15 July 1985 in which you enquired about the resettlement of Afghans in Australia under the refugee program. You also wrote to the Foreign Minister, Bill Hayden, on this matter.

Let me first assure you that the Government is committed to diversification within the Australian refugee and humanitarian program with particular attention to the Middle East and Latin America. For administrative purposes my Department processes applications by Afghans under the Middle Eastern program. Australia, however, does have regional interests in Asia as well as an on-going interest in refugee situations in Eastern Europe.

Although a specified number of places is allocated annually to the broad program categories in order to facilitate efficient administration of the overall program, it is not generally the practice to allot specific places for individual nationalities. This allows for maximum flexibility in responding to changing situations.

In order to achieve our aim of a globally-based program, Australia must utilise the limited number of available resettlement places for those most in need. Applications are therefore assessed on a case-by-case basis and applicants individually must establish a claim to refugee status or humanitarian consideration and fall within one or more of the priority categories for inclusion in the Australian program. I am aware that Afghan refugee numbers, particularly in Pakistan, are large but the number considered by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) to be in need of resettlement outside the region is not large. I understand a majority are rural people who are in need of temporary refuge until such time as they can safely and freely return to their homeland.

In separate correspondence you expressed concern about a number of recent unsuccessful applications for resettlement by Afghans. It must be understood that individual applicants from whatever countries need to establish an eligibility on their merits and against specified criteria. The program does not give automatic entry entitlement to nationals of any given country nor to those who have relatives in Australia.

Australia already considers individual Afghans for humanitarian resettlement and we will continue to consider deserving cases deemed by the UNHCR or comparable authority to be of concern and in need of permanent resettlement elsewhere. I trust this letter resolves some of the concerns raised in your correspondence.
Yours sincerely
CHRIS HURFORD

talk.start.para: —In particular, in that letter the Minister points out that there are plans for the resettlement of a number of people from Asia and one would think that an effort would have been made to include some of those in Pakistan, who have been trying to get to Australia, and who have been for many years. There is talk in that letter of the fact that these people are very often of a rural background and perhaps would not settle into Australia but, unquestionably, those who have sought to come here are people of considerable education and training, who would be a great asset to Australia and would fit very largely into our community. The fact is that, since that time, 150 people have been interviewed. They are carefully selected. They are people who have qualifications that would fit them for Australia. We sent over from our embassy in Syria someone to specially interview them but only 10 have been admitted to this country. The rest have been excluded. They have received letters which indicate that they are not to be included in the Australian population. I think it is deplorable. The result of this is that I wrote on 7 February 1986 to the Hon. Chris Hurford deploring the situation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of that letter.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
The Hon. Chris Hurford MP
Minister for Immigration & Ethnic Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA A.C.T. 2600
Dear Minister,
Re: Afghan Community and Migration to Australia

I have recently had discussions with three representatives of the Afghan Community in Melbourne. They are Mr Mohammad Nawaz Waziri, President of the Association, formerly a General in the Army of Afghanistan; secondly Mr Mohammed Moyen Bajawray, former Kabul University Lecturer and Secretary of the Afghan Community Association (P.O. Box 128, Elwood, Victoria 3184); and Mr Sher Ahmad Marshal, former official of the Ministry of Education as co-ordinator of Refugee and Migrants Committee Affairs. They are very concerned at the treatment which Afghan applicants, now mostly in camps in Pakistan under very trying conditions, are receiving in relation to migration to Australia. I understand that last year there was an indication that some hundred or so applicants would be allowed to come to Australia. The people who put applications in were people of high qualifications, but only ten have been granted. I have before me letters of rejection from the Department to a number of people who have brothers and sisters in Australia and who have been told to review their options, including ``refugee resettlement elsewhere with the assistance of the UNHCR''. It seems to me that there are many people who have family connections in Australia and we are quite wrongly sloughing them off. In view of the actions which the Australian people have taken over Afghanistan and the horror which we all feel towards the invasion and the attempt by the Soviet Union to tyrannise these people, I find it impossible to understand why your Department adopts such an inconsistent attitude.

Various applicants last year were interviewed by Mr Paul Smith of the Syria Australian Embassy who went to Pakistan to interview them, and in fact interviewed more than 150 Afghans during that period, but most have been rejected and I think for quite inadequate reasons.

I am very impressed by the responsible attitude of those who saw me and by the efforts which have been made by members of the Afghan community to settle in this country. There are not very many of them but they are proving good citizens and I think that the rejection out of hand of these applications is particularly offensive.

Let me give examples: In regard to Mr Bajawray, he has been here for three years and will get citizenship in a few weeks. His sister, whose husband died in the fighting, has been turned down by the Government and she has been told try elsewhere. Mr Bajawray also has a brother in Pakistan. Of Mr Marshal's family, three members are in Melbourne and are all Australian citizens, and the applications for his father-in-law and mother-in-law and their children have likewise been turned down. Mr Waziri has been living in Australia with his wife and two children and his two sisters-in-law. All are permanent residents but for less than two years. His attempt to sponsor his brother-in-law, Mohammad Aref Moh-Seni who is 32 years old and a graduate of the University in Engineering, has likewise been turned down. Reference has also been made to the case of Dr Feda Mohammad Eqbal, who is Mr Marshal's first cousin. He is an excellent doctor and speaks good English. He was turned down by Mr Smith who interviewed him in Pakistan. These are only some of the examples where I suggest an unfeeling attitude has been adopted, particularly as it must be patently obvious to members of your Department that they are unable to return to Afghanistan without real risk to their lives.

I suggest that the present applications have only been for educated persons and they would obviously provide excellent citizens for Australia. I would suggest that if you would look at the experience of the 40 families or so in Melbourne, roughly 170 people living in Victoria, you will see that many of them have purchased homes and that they are a hard-working and able group in the community. There is a bigger number in Sydney. I understand that something like 95% of them are working and more than half of them are buying their own homes.

I am aware of the letters written by Mr Marshal, who was Chairman of the group known as Khodaye Khedmat Garran which has now amalgamated with the general community. He wrote to you on the 15th July 1985 and to the Foreign Minister on the 13th July 1985. In case they are not immediately available to you, I enclose a copy of this letter to the Foreign Minister, which is in the same form as the letter written to you, and his reply of the 6th August 1985. I know that in the reply which they received from R. A. Stainsby, Assistant Representative (Legal) of the UNHCR, dated the 22nd July 1985, he said that you were announcing Australia's Humanitarian Programme and there were 750 places allocated to persons from the Middle East under that programme. This was to include some Afghan refugees and some Afghan humanitarian cases. Apparently this has amounted so far to ten persons in all. I am, of course, aware of your reply to Mr Marshal dated the 28th August 1985. In that letter you state that a majority of the Afghan refugees are rural people in need of temporary refuge until such time as they can safely and freely return to their homeland. To begin with, of course, it is likely to be many years before this can come about but in any event the applicants who have so far sought resettlement in Australia have not been rural people but educated people who can obviously fit very well into the Australian community. You maintain there that you will continue to consider deserving cases deemed by the UNHCR or comparable authority and in need of permanent resettlement here. I suggest to you that most of the people who have applied so far fit into that category and I would strongly urge that the Government once again acts in a way in which the Australian people have expressed their views on this subject, and show a great deal more consideration to the resettlement of Afghan refugees.
I would hope for an early reply so that I can communicate it to the Afghan community in Victoria.
Yours sincerely,
Alan Missen
Senator for Victoria

talk.start.para: —I set out in that letter not only the detailed arguments but also the position of various people who have sought to migrate to this country. Some have families and are still in Afghanistan, living in very extraordinary circumstances and in great danger to themselves. I refer to the earlier correspondence, to which no proper response has been made by the Minister, and regret that this has not led to us doing something in reality towards bringing into Australia a number of people who would fit into this country. We will be showing, in our demonstration of migration policies, what we should be doing and what we have been saying in our foreign affairs policy.

speech.para: I made the same arguments, the same criticism of the Government, last week in regard to similar circumstances arising with the Tamils of Sri Lanka. I have spoken previously of the situation with regard to Irian Jaya. I believe that we must show by our policies consistency between foreign affairs declarations and decisions made by our Migration Department. I should just add that I wrote a further letter on 10 February because of additional material that I obtained from the Afghan community. I forwarded to Mr Hurford a letter to me of 5 February 1986 from the Afghan community and I seek leave to incorporate that in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator Alan Missen,
Senator for Victoria,
400 Flinders Street,
Melbourne, Vic. 3000.
Dear Mr Alan Missen,
Thank you for your letter of 5th December 1985, and giving us the opportunity to write to you regarding the Afghan problems.

I am absolutely certain that Your Excellency is well informed of the existing situation in Afghanistan. After the Russian invasion, the Afghan nation was confronted with countless problems such as homelessness, helplessness, tragical events, The bloody Russians did a lot of aggression to the innocent people of our beloved country. They used all kinds of power and razed to the ground hundreds of thousands of houses of the people, Mosques, bazaars, towns, villages, and burnt up the harvests of the people and over four million people were forced to leave their beloved country and become refugees.

According to the abovementioned circumstance, an Afghan woman by the name of Fatemah Bajawray with her children is among one of those thousands of families encountering calamity, hardship, and a miserable life. The husband of the abovementioned unfortunate woman was martyred. Her father-in-law or her husband's father, because of the Russian atrocities, has already taken refuge in Pakistan. The small town in which this innocent lady lived with her children was completely destroyed and converted into a big ruin as the result of Russian bombardment and she has no accommodation any more. Since her husband was killed during the bombardment and especially when her son joined Freedom Fighters, the woman and her children's life have become liable to a great danger and threat. As the result of such unfavourable conformation and difficulties, they were forced to leave their country.

Unfortunately, after a short time, the woman's father-in-law passed away, and the whole family were left in distress and misery in Pakistan. There is no one bearing the responsibility of taking care of them and they are unable to return to Afghanistan.
She has no mother, father, sister, father-in-law, or mother-in-law and all her children are below nineteen. There is no job availability and no proper education for her children.

Her only hope are her brothers, one of whom is in jail in Afghanistan because of his highly influential and religious family, and another one, who is in Australia as a permanent resident and citizen, and who has sponsored the mentioned woman and her children, as he feels great responsibility for them. Unfortunately, she was turned down in an interview that took place in Islamabad; a copy of this letter is attached.
