Our Association is certain Your Honour is very well informed with the Afghans' problems.
We have great hope that you would kindly pay humanistic attention to those Afghans like we have mentioned in this letter, who really live under miserable conditions.
Hopefully these problems will be overcome by your efforts.
I look forward to hearing from you.
With every best wishes,
Yours sincerely,
Gen. M. Nawaz Waziri,
President.

talk.start.para: —I just want to say in general that I believe in this respect we are not doing what we should in accordance with our statements and our previous record in regard to the Afghan people. I believe we have to improve our decisions in this regard and find a place for, particularly, those who can fit into our community. There is a long record, since 1850 or so, of Afghan people settling in this country. They have become industrious citizens. The people I have met in the Afghan community seem to me to be admirable citizens who are settling well into this country. Most of them have jobs and are working to obtain houses here. They are people who are making an excellent name and indeed strengthening the Australian community. I therefore urge members of the Parliament and of the media, in particular, to draw attention to the Afghans' travail and to the fact that it is their national day tomorrow. I hope that the Government will take urgent and useful steps to bring more Afghans to this country, thereby demonstrating that we support them in their particular problems.

speech.speaker: Jones Sen G.N.

talk.start.para: —As honourable senators are well aware, the Bjelke-Petersen National Party Government of Queensland has, to say the least, not had a happy time of late. Indeed, it is true to say that it has reeled around like a collection of drunken sailors from crisis to crisis. We have just witnessed the Lindeman Island fiasco, where only a fierce groundswell of public opinion prevented a virtual give-away of a national park to a company of which Sir Edward Lyons, a discredited crony of Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen, is the Queensland Chairman. I think it was an example of people power being able to reverse a decision taken by the Government.

speech.para: We have serious charges now before a court against a former departmental head who for many years was Sir Johannes's Press Secretary, and against the wife of a former departmental head. There is an enormous outcry against the outrageous electoral gerrymander in Queensland, which means that the National Party could rule in its own right, without the Liberal Party, on a mere 35 per cent of the vote. I think it is small wonder that the people of Queensland are comparing Bjelke-Petersen to Marcos in the Philippines. He feels it wise to buy silence and a proliferation of writs has been issued against State Labor Party Opposition members, also officials of the party-litigation that, I might add, has been paid for by the long-suffering Queensland public, not the people taking the action.

The word around Queensland is that, while Marcos rigged the election result, the National Party in Queensland does not have to because the election has been rigged prior to any result becoming known. Now, while these are by and large problems of suffering Queenslanders, there is also a factor brought about by the mismanagement of the Bjelke-Petersen Government that is very much the concern of all Australians. I refer to the pathetic Queensland economic performance under the guiding hand of the pitiful apology for a treasurer, none other than Sir Johannes himself. Here is the proof of the appalling economic performance so damaging to the national effort-proof supplied by the Commonwealth Bureau of Statistics.

talk.start.para: —On a point of order: I think that reference to a member of another Parliament in these terms goes beyond the arrangements that we have in this place for debate on matters of public interest. I regret, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I have to draw your attention to the matter. I would have thought that the honourable senator would have accepted the situation as it exists between the parties. I would ask him to withdraw those comments about a member of another Parliament and to proceed in a more orderly manner.

—Senator Jones, I was talking to the former occupant of the Chair at the time, but the point has been raised that it is rather unethical to refer offensively to a member of another Parliament and if you have offended Senator Archer I suggest that you might consider what he has had to say.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am not sure whether you are asking me to withdraw or whether you are saying that I should give way to Senator Archer's point of view. In actual fact I was referring to the Premier and Government generally of Queensland. I thought under normal circumstances one could refer to the Government of another State without infringing any standing orders.
—The reference was specifically about a certain person, in a certain position. I request that it be withdrawn.

interject.speaker: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —I draw the honourable Senator's attention to standing order 418, which states:

interject.para: No Senator shall use offensive words against either House of Parliament or any Member of such House, or of any House of a State Parliament, or against any Statute, unless for the purpose of moving for its repeal, and all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on Members shall be considered highly disorderly.
I suggest at this stage that Senator Jones should withdraw.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I will withdraw, but I thought you said that you did not hear my remarks. It seems quite unusual that you should ask me to withdraw and yet not hear the remarks passed. Anyway, let me refer to information from the Commonwealth Bureau of Statistics, which I will relate to the performance of the Government of Queensland totally.

speech.para: Of the 18 key economic indicators, as released until March 1986, Queensland had the worst result in seven, the second worst in four and was below the Australian average in 15. Queensland recorded the worst result in the following: The unemployment rate of 10.3 per cent for February, 1986 was the highest in Australia and average weekly earnings of $377.20 for males were the lowest in Australia for the month of August, 1985. Mr Acting Deputy President, I suppose some of the facts as put down will offend some of the senators listening.

Also, Queensland recorded the lowest number of overtime hours, at 6.21, worked in August 1985. Residential building completions for the September quarter, 1985, recorded a negative growth rate of 21.1 per cent compared with the same period a year before, while the Australian total grew by 4.8 per cent. Bankruptcies for 1984-85 compared with the previous financial year had their highest growth in Queensland. In the three months to the end of January 1986, new telephone connections fell by 10.5 per cent in Queensland compared with those for the same period a year ago. Again, Queensland's rate of industrial disputation was the highest in Australia, with 427 days lost per 1,000 employees for the 12 months to November 1985. The Australian average was only 237.

Queensland recorded the second worst result in the following areas: In the three months to the end of January 1986, the number of new dwelling units approved dropped by 14.5 per cent. New fixed capital expenditure for the year to the September quarter 1985, as compared with the same period a year before, grew by 8.4 per cent in Queensland, well below the total growth rate for Australia of 15.2.

The job vacancy rate in Queensland for August 1985 was 0.8 per cent and household income per capita in 1983-84 was $9,675. I repeat, in Queensland, household income per capita in 1983-84 was $9,675. Queensland was below the national average in retail sales growth for the three months ended December 1985, in new motor vehicle registration, for the three months to January 1986 in growth of residential building under construction at the end of September quarter 1985, and in growth in the number of tourist guest nights in hotels and motels for the September quarter 1985. It was a litany of disaster.

My reason for painting this picture of the Queensland economic gloom is simple. Despite the obscenities of the Lindeman Island exercise and the blatant gerrymander, I firmly believe that the forthcoming State election will be largely fought on the Bjelke-Petersen Government's incapacity of handle the economy. I believe equally firmly that despite the gerrymander the growing realisation of the Queensland public as to just how far down the track of total economic disaster Sir Johannes and his gang have led the State will be sufficient at election time to send the National Party and the Government in Queensland to where it belongs, the political wilderness. I believe that the people's power in Queensland will remove the Government and return to the Treasury benches of that State government that will perform in a way in which Queensland expects its government to perform.
Sitting suspended from 1.07 to 2 p.m.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the paper circulated by the Chairman of the Caucus Economic Committee, Mr Bob Brown, in which Mr Brown warns that the Government's present economic policies will result in rising unemployment and a deceleration in economic growth. Mr Brown also states that, as the Treasurer's J curve has not turned up fast enough, the Government should impose selective import quotas linked to domestic production as a means of slowing down imports. Does the Minister agree with Mr Brown's analysis of the economy and his suggestion on quotas?

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —I suppose that I have said on a number of occasions here that economic growth is clearly slowing and that is a result, in part, of government policy in connection with interest rates. The national accounts figures for the December quarter tend to illustrate that point, in part-although there are some qualifications about those figures. I have not seen Mr Bob Brown's analysis of the situation, but the comments that he makes are not inconsistent with comments made by others and are within the Government's purview and under consideration by the Government now, as they have been for some time.

answer.para: As to the solution that Mr Brown proposes, I am not, again, familiar with the methodology that he suggests to implement that proposal, but if it is anything like the methodology suggested in a paper by Dr Theophanous, about which I was asked last week, I would repeat the same sort of comments as those I made then.

talk.start.para: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation aware of the case of Mr Peter Langley, who was refused transport on a pre-booked Qantas Airways Ltd flight from Hong Kong to Sydney on the ground that he had not given Qantas advance information that he was a paraplegic? Will the Minister inform the Senate of the full circumstances of this case, and will he assure the Senate that steps will be taken to ensure that disabled persons have the same ease of access to Qantas flights as any other person?

answer.speaker: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

talk.start.para: —I am sure that all honourable senators would agree that this was a very unfortunate incident as a result of a misunderstanding and an apparent lack of prior notification by the airline which booked Mr Langley's forward passage. This resulted in embarrassment to him and in a degree of inconvenience. Senator Morris would be aware that Qantas acts as a publicly-owned commercial enterprise and that it makes all its decisions based upon normal commercial procedures.

answer.para: However, in the case of Mr Langley, I am sure that all of us regret that the incident took place. In defence of Qantas, however, I have to say that the airline looked after Mr Langley in Hong Kong and arranged for him to board a Cathay Pacific flight some two hours later. I think that one is obliged to apologise to him for the embarrassment caused, although these matters are not within the Government's purview because Qantas has a commercial charter and has independence in the way in which it operates.

I take advantage of the opportunity provided by this question to say that prior notification of disability is important from the point of view of the airline as well as that of passengers. I hope that the publicity that has occurred on this occasion will serve as some sort of notice to airlines and passengers that they should take special steps to see that these sorts of occurrences do not take place in the future. It is pretty clear, unfortunately, that the system broke down. I am sure that Qantas has learnt its lesson over this matter, and I am assured by the Minister I represent in this chamber that Qantas will be taking steps to ensure that such incidents do not occur in the future.

talk.start.para: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to a question asked by Senator Peter Baume on 20 February last, in which he asked whether the Government would agree to exempt charities from the fringe benefits tax. The Minister gave an assurance that he would seek an answer to that question from the Treasurer. I also refer the Minister to a statement by a spokesman for the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Mr John Brown, in which he said that to exempt charities from the fringe benefits tax would create loopholes for people to use in abuse of the system. I now ask the Minister whether his failure to provide an answer and an assurance from the Treasurer that charities will be exempted from the operation of the fringe benefits tax is because the Government has no intention of excluding them from it-in which case, is this not contrary to the assurances regarding the treatment of charities provided to the Australian Democrats back in November 1985?

—I have some recollection of that question but I concede that my recollection of it is imperfect. I did not think I said that I would try to get an undertaking from the Treasurer that charities would be exempt. As I recall it, what I said was that I would get the facts clarified and get an answer from the Treasurer. I am afraid that I have not got an answer yet. I am sorry. I shall approach the Treasurer again.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. The question refers to the commercial for a breakfast food that is currently being shown on television, which includes shots of the Australian Institute of Sport and in which the product is promoted by a member of the staff of the Institute. Under what arrangements, financial or otherwise, was the commercial made?

—The Australian Institute of Sport has entered into a commercial sponsorship arrangement with Kellogg Australia Pty Ltd in developing the new product Sustain. In return, the Institute of Sport receives a royalty payment. The making of the commercial incurred no cost to the Institute of Sport.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that joint Australian-United States air exercises will be carried out at Williamtown air base between 5 and 10 April? Has the Department of Defence broadcast on some Newcastle radio stations a statement that local residents will be subjected to extreme noise levels during those exercises? What maximum A-weighted sound pressure level does the Department expect at ground level near residents' homes? Will the Department consider the request of local residents that these exercises be conducted so that extreme sound levels occur over farmland or, preferably, out to sea? If not, why not? Does the Department keep accurate records of sound pressure levels to which communities are exposed during such exercises and are these freely available to interested parties?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —Yes, the Minister for Defence tells me that Exercise Pitch Black, involving both Australian and American military forces, will be conducted in the Royal Australian Air Force Base Williamtown area between 4 and 21 April 1986. However, the period when aircraft activity will be significantly different from normal day to day activity levels has been restricted to 9 to 11 April. Even in this period RAAF planning has taken cognisance of other activities that need to be accommodated, and the concentrated air activity periods have been restricted to the following times: Wednesday 9 April, 0930 to 1200, 1400 to 1630, and 1830 to 2100, local time; Thursday 10 April, 1200 to 2130 hours.

answer.para: As to the second part of the question, no, Department of Defence personnel have not made any broadcasts on Newcastle radio stations. However, a Press release was made by the Air Staff at RAAF Base Williamtown to areas between Newcastle and Brisbane. People living in the rural areas between RAAF Amberley and RAAF Williamtown have been warned of the likelihood of low-flying, simulated enemy military aircraft passing overhead during 9 to 11 April as they try to approach Williamtown without being detected by our radar. Members of the public wishing to report progress of such aircraft may ring 048-286081. I repeat the number, and `Cheerio' at the same time: 048-286081.
This is a very boring answer although I have no doubt that it is of utility to people in the area.

talk.start.para: —You have improved it no end.
—Question Time is for those opposite. I will continue.
—Incorporate it.
—I am happy to do so. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the remainder of the answer.

answer.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

3. The maximum A.-weighted sound pressure level that the Department of Defence expects at ground level is in the region of 100 DBA. This level will exist for only a short period of time as the aircraft passes over the area and then only when aircraft are at low level. As far as is practicable, residential areas will not be exposed to overflying aircraft although total avoidance of dwellings is not possible.

4. Although at least 25% of simulated attacks will be from over the sea, it is not possible to conduct Exercise Pitch Black purely over farming areas or out to sea as the aim of the exercise is to test the Australian Air Defence system, and to provide realistic operational training for strike (F111) crews. The Air Defence system is established to protect valuable military and other land targets such as RAAF Base Williamtown. The aim is not only to exercise military aircraft, but also many other land-based elements such as CRUs (Control and Reporting Units) responsible for the radar control of defensive fighter aircraft, and Army Air Defence units with Rapier and Redeye missiles. The exercise, and the need to conduct it in as realistic an environment as is possible, is essential to maintain the required level of training and proficiency in the Australian military.

5. The Department of Defence does not maintain records of sound pressure levels experienced during exercises; however, sound pressure assessments in answer to Question 3 have been made from measured aircraft engine noise signatures. As these assessments are associated with aircraft performance, the information is classified and is not available for general release.

question.block.title: ISOLATED PATIENTS TRAVEL AND ACCOMMODATION SCHEME

talk.start.para: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of the following resolutions passed by a recent women's conference in Mount Isa: First, that the isolated patients travel and accommodation scheme is inadequate, inefficient and needs total review with community liaison input; secondly, that there needs to be more flexibility built into the system to take account of the complexities of transport arrangements in isolated areas; and thirdly, that not the least of the problems is the long delay in payment of claims in many cases? Will the Minister recommend an urgent review of the isolated patients travel and accommodation scheme, which is apparently failing to meet the needs of isolated women and their families?

—I had not previously been informed of the resolutions from the Union of Western Women's health and family planning workshop concerning the isolated patients travel and accommodation scheme. However, for some time the Government has viewed with concern the wide-ranging scope of criticisms which have been directed from many quarters at existing arrangements. As a consequence, a working party comprising Commonwealth, State and Territory officials was established to study the rationalisation of patient transport generally, including the role of IPTAS. The purpose of establishing a working party was to seek broad ways and means to improve the existing patient transport assistance arrangements, particularly in the delivery aspects. It was not intended that the working party undertake an in depth review of IPTAS. In any case, the time frame and available resources of the working party would have precluded such an in depth review. The working party has now completed its report. This will now be considered at the 1986 Australian Health Ministers Conference, which is to be held early in April. Of course, I cannot pre-empt the results which may flow from the Australian Health Ministers Conference consideration of the working party report. However, I assure Senator Reynolds that should an in depth review of IPTAS result there would be community participation in such a review. It would address administrative issues such as the prompt settlement of claims.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Territories aware of current delays being experienced by people awaiting connection of electricity by the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority to new houses, which can be as long as 12 weeks? Does the Minister realise the hardship, expense and anguish that this causes the families concerned? Does the Minister agree that this impost adds to the burden already suffered by new home owners, in addition to the burden of the present high interest rates? What does the Minister intend to do to have this serious problem of supply of electricity rectified?

—I have looked through the brief that the Minister for Territories has supplied to me. There is no reference in it to the serious problem raised. I will seek an early response and convey it to Senator Reid.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In view of the fact mentioned in the Four Corners program of 11 March that the Sandinista Government is now obliged, because of serious economic problems, to impose prescription charges for the first time at its previously free and highly successful clinics, would the Australian Government consider assisting Nicaraguans with direct medicinal aid?

—Australia has not embarked on a major aid program in Central America. However, it has provided some assistance to the region, notably for refugee relief activities in Nicaragua and El Salvador, through the International Committee of the Red Cross and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, and for various local aid projects through the small discretionary aid fund administered by the Australian Ambassador in Mexico City. This assistance has included some medical supplies. The Government will look at the possibility of providing through these means further medical supplies that may be sought by Nicaragua. Another means by which medical supplies could be provided would be through an arrangement between Australia and Nicaragua based non-government aid organisations. A goodwill visit to Central America by Australian NGOs is scheduled in May, as a result of which they may be participating with local NGOs in an expanded assistance program in Nicaragua, to include community health and sanitation. The Australian aid program includes the facility for government funding support of approved NGO projects.

—Can the Leader of the Government in the Senate explain why it has become necessary to establish a country task force when there are so many rural representatives in this Parliament who have been trying to tell the Government for some time what is wrong with the policies that it has forced on the town and country people of rural Australia? What is the Minister's response to suggestions that this is merely a highly expensive superficial and political exercise designed to boost the Australian Labor Party's poor standing in rural areas?

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —I hope that this will not come as too much of a shock or surprise to Senator Bjelke-Petersen but it is a political exercise. After all, we are all politicians. It is just that some politicians are of better quality than others and the rural representatives in this Parliament have, traditionally, not been of as good quality as the average contributors to both parties in political debate.
—Ours are better.

—Of course. Many of the problems with which this country is confronted today have been inflicted on us by a series of structural problems for which the National Party is probably the most easily identifiable contributor.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting-

talk.start.para: —It is all very well for Liberals to interject. Every one of them knows that that is true. Senator Withers knows that it is true. He has been one of the most intelligent contributors to debate in this Parliament over the last three years. He has said absolutely nothing. Over many years this Parliament has been inflicted with National Party pork barrelling and structural assistance programs for rural industries which are the cause of many of today's problems. If the task force to which Senator Bjelke-Petersen refers can make a contribution to intelligent debate on issues in the rural community, as distinct from the contribution which the Queensland Government, for example, seems prepared to make to the future of the sugar industry-if they can contribute some sensible views in their peregrinations around rural communities-that will be very helpful. Of course this is a political exercise. That is what we are all about. I suppose that the honourable senator is concerned about its likely success. I think that there will be a lot of success.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. In view of the daily revelations about the appalling state of the Queensland economy I ask: How do Queensland unemployment figures compare with the national figures since the last Queensland State election, which was held on 22 October 1983?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —As Senator Jones has said, the last Queensland election was held in October 1983. In only three of the 28 months for which unemployment figures are available since then has the Queensland rate not been above the national average. The last of those three months was February 1984, more than two years ago. So for all of the last two years the Queensland unemployment rate has been above the national average. From memory-I think the figures are not quite comparable because one is seasonally adjusted and the other is not-the national figure at present is 8 per cent and the Queensland figure is 10.3 per cent. Moreover, let us look at youth employment, particularly in view of the Premier's election policy speech which was delivered on 22 September 1983. He said:

answer.para: Your Government will continue its attack on the problem of youth unemployment.

What has happened since then is that the youth unemployment rate in Queensland has risen from 19.6 per cent in October 1983 to a massive 24.6 per cent in February 1986, the most recent month for which figures are available, of course. The Queensland youth unemployment rate has gone up a full 5 per cent and, over the same period, the national youth unemployment rate has fallen by 5 per cent. We find that on the question of youth unemployment, and for almost every economic indicator that one could think of, Queensland is dragging the rest of the economy down. It does have higher figures than the rest of the country on some things; for example, bankruptcies, industrial disputes, unemployment levels, venereal disease and teenage pregnancies. On any measure that most sensible people would regard as something desirable and something to be aspired to--
Honourable senators interjecting-

talk.start.para: —I did not hear what Senator MacGibbon said. It was probably some comment about VD or teenage pregnancies, seeking an explanation as to why Queensland records the highest figures on those two matters of any State, and does so consistently. On almost any indicator that most sensible people would regard as being desirable, Queensland is tailing the rest of the field and dragging the rest of the country down.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and relates to his answer to a question yesterday in relation to the Government's refusal to accept the amendment proposed by the Opposition parties and the Australian Democrats to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill relating to its retrospective operation, in which the Minister said that the Government's view `has the unanimous support . . . of the veterans community'. I ask the Minister: Is it not a fact that the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council, representing some 15 veterans bodies, along with the associated organisations, mainly the Partially Blinded Soldiers' Association, have expressed their strong support for the retrospectivity amendment of the coalition to that Bill? Is the Minister not aware that the Partially Blind Soldiers' Association described the retrospectivity position of the Government as `outrageous' and that the Regular Defence Forces Welfare Association described the position as equivalent to `removing the goal posts during the middle of a game'? When will the Minister acknowledge that there is much opposition, despite his misleading of the Senate yesterday--
—Order! Will the honourable senator bring his question to a conclusion.

—There is much opposition in the veterans community to the retrospectivity position. I ask the Minister to revise his position in this matter before increasing opposition throughout the veterans community and within his own back bench forces him to end up dropping this Bill altogether?

answer.speaker: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

talk.start.para: —I will not acknowledge that there is any difficulty as far as my own Party's back bench is concerned. It, like the Government, wants the passage of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill forthwith. As far as the veteran community is concerned, I have correspondence from organisations associated with the Australian Veterans and Defence Service Council indicating support for the passage of the Bill, a view which was unanimously agreed to at a veterans summit meeting some six weeks ago. It is true that one person, claiming to act on behalf of the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council, has repudiated the agreement made at the veterans summit, which was addressed by myself, Senator Macklin and Mr Fischer. Nevertheless, I have on the record the unanimous view of the veterans community at the peak council level.

answer.para: I have never suggested that every veterans organisation in Australia agrees-if we take all the unit associations there would be anything up to 100 such organisations-any more than the Returned Services League of Australia would suggest that its 600 sub-branches necessarily fully and unanimously agree with the views taken by their national body. Nevertheless, that grouping, which includes Legacy, the War Widows Guild and the TPI Association, which I addressed last week, unanimously called for the passage of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill. Therefore, it is competent for the Government to take the view that it has the overwhelming support of the veteran community with respect to the Bill. So far as the Partially Blinded Soldiers' Association is concerned, it represents a point of view of the State Branch of New South Wales. It does not represent the viewpoint of the national body. Are we to take that view as representing the view of the veterans community? It wants no Bill at all, not even the improvements which the Bill seeks to put into place as a result of the long consultative processes which began when Senator Messner was the Minister in setting up the consultative council and which has continued right through my three years as Minister.

I find it incomprehensible that Senator Lewis should take the view of a person who writes to both the Opposition and the Government suggesting that there should be no Bill at all when we have, in the presentation of the Bill, improved a number of areas for veterans. As Senator Lewis knows, as one who has consulted me extensively on the Bill representing his shadow Minister in this place, a whole range of improvements contained in the Bill were not provided for in the original Repatriation Act. On the basis of that the Government sought to make sufficient changes and priorities within the legislation to enable it to recognise, for example, the rights of those people not covered by the Repatriation Act who served in Vietnam and many other improvements in the Bill, such as for war widows who remarry, and so on, on the basis that there would be a re-arrangement of the funds saved in order to pay out funds in more deserving cases, including the one I referred to yesterday on the children's education scheme.

The Government makes no apologies. It is not prepared to apply the retrospectivity aspect to the legislation, which will cost something in excess of $25m a year. I would prefer, and I am sure the veterans would prefer-in fact, it is the view of the veteran community, without any argument at all-that sort of saving to be spent in the area where it is badly needed, that is, in improving the hospital system, having regard to the age component now of the veteran community.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Walsh in his capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer. The question is simply: Are interest rates falling?

—I can only assume from the titters across the way that the notorious innumeracy of the Liberal Party of Australia and the Country Party-the National Party of Australia, as it is these days-is manifesting itself again because the short answer to the question is yes. The figures I have show that the 90-day bank bill rate on 10 February was 18.85 per cent and on 19 March, just over five weeks later, it had fallen to 16.25 per cent. That is a decline of 2.6 percentage points on 90-day bank bills. The yield on 10-year bonds on the same date, 10 February, was 14.47 per cent. On 19 March it was 12.83 per cent, a fall in the yield on 10-year bonds of 1.64 percentge points. Notwithstanding the ill-informed titters across the aisle, the fact is that over the last month interest rates have fallen quite appreciatively and, indeed, at an extremely rapid rate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is it a fact that 133 out of the 504 beds at the Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital are currently closed due to the severe shortage of registered nurses and that up to 50 veterans a day are being turned away? Is it a fact that the Federal nursing award is, on average, from 10 per cent to 20 per cent, or $2,000 to $4,000, lower than the Victorian State award? In addition to the British nurse recruitment program, what other action is the Minister taking to liaise with his ministerial colleagues to overcome this acute problem which exists in various degrees at all repatriation hospitals across Australia?

answer.speaker: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

talk.start.para: —I do not necessarily disagree with the figures cited by the honourable senator. I am prepared to accept that a considerable number of veterans are not able to be accommodated in our repatriation hospital at Heidelberg. The problem exists in most of the repatriation hospitals because of the acute shortage of nurses and the difficulty that creates so far as the operation of many of the beds and wards is concerned. The Government is very concerned about the problem. I have had numerous conferences with the Royal Australian Nursing Federation. Even the Prime Minister has been involved in discussions in an attempt to resolve the difficulty of the award rates with respect to the nurses employed at Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital. We have taken the matter to the Australian Council of Trade Unions because the current guidelines with respect to anomalies preclude the matter being resolved at the Public Service Board level.

answer.para: A case is being presented to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to try to resolve the impasse that has been reached in respect of the salaries of nurses at Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital. Compared with nurses at private and State hospitals, nurses at the Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital are seriously underpaid. However, the anomalies system that operates at the industrial arbitration court level has not given us any opportunity to resolve the matter. The Department of Veterans' Affairs and I are concerned. We recognise the plight which exists. We recognise the inequality of the wage structure at Heidelberg. We have done everything within our legal power to resolve the situation. It can be resolved only on the basis of undertakings the Nursing Federation will have to make to the Arbitration Commission.

talk.start.para: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction seen Press reports that the St George Building Society has arranged a $1 billion facility through the Chase Investment Bank in the United States `at no cost to the Federal Government' in order to provide housing loans at a fixed interest rate of 13.5 per cent? Can the Minister comment on this initiative?

—I have not seen a detailed account of the scheme referred to in Senator Sibraa's question, but I am sure that my colleague the Minister for Housing and Construction, Mr West, will give it careful consideration. He is aware, as the Government is aware generally, of the great pressures on the housing market and of the difficulties that Australians are now experiencing in getting housing finance. As I think I informed the Senate earlier this week, the Cabinet will be giving very detailed attention next week to a package of measures designed to assist Australians into home ownership and to relieve pressures on the rental market. Whether this scheme will form part of that package is not for me to say. However, I am sure that the Minister for Housing and Construction will be giving very careful attention to this proposal, as he will to any other constructive proposal that can be considered, in a very serious and comprehensive effort by our Government to address the problems in the housing industry.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and follows his confident answer to Senator Cook that interest rates are falling. If that is so, why does the Government not pull the upper limit off housing loan interest rates because it is on a sure thing?

—Housing interest rates, as I thought even Senator MacGibbon would know, are presently regulated at a level lower than they probably would be, even after the very appreciable falls in interest rates that have taken place in the last five weeks and to which I referred in answering Senator Cook.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. Is it true that moves are currently under way in Western Australia to terminate the lease held by a Mr Montague in Oobagooma station and Tarraji Rivers station in Western Australia? I understand that both stations form part of a defence training area near Derby. Can the Minister advise whether these moves are being initiated by the Commonwealth Government and, if so, why?

answer.speaker: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

talk.start.para: —In 1978 the previous Government took steps to acquire 566,000 hectares of land at Oobagooma and Tarraji Rivers stations in Western Australia. The purchase was made by the Government on a walk-in and walk-out basis. The purpose of the purchase was, as Senator McKiernan has said, to establish a joint service defence training area. Arising out of that, the Government has taken steps to resolve the earlier walk-in and walk-out decision which applied in respect of one section of the area and over which the Army has care, control and management. It has a caretaker looking after it. In order to make the effective purchase the previous Government agreed to a lessee leasing the other two sections at Yampi in Western Australia.

answer.para: Following receipt of a management appraisal of the stations prepared by professional property consultants, the Government has taken steps to end the lease arrangements with the former lessee. A notice to quit was taken out on 12 December 1985. The Government took this step because our legal advice was that the termination of the lease was justified on a number of grounds relating to the conditions of the lease. However, I am not able to say anything more about the subjective matter because I understand that it will have to be resolved in the Western Australian Supreme Court.

talk.start.para: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I preface it by saying that I note with interest that the Treasurer has announced a special $1 coin for the International Year of Peace, many of which I am sure will end up in the collections of coin collectors. I ask: Now that the $1 coin has proven to be so successful, will the Treasurer examine the possibility of introducing both a $5 and a $10 coin and also have his Department examine changing the size of all Australian coins with a view to reducing their size to an amount of metal more in line with their present value?

—In the last part of Senator Townley's question he seems to be suggesting that we should go back to minting golden sovereigns or their equivalent. I really do not think that is a very sensible idea because the value of metals changes as well as the face value of coins. That proposition should not be taken seriously. A more sensible suggestion might well be the minting of a $5 or a $10 coin. The dollar coin replaced-three years ago I think-dollar notes. The chief reason for that was that dollar notes had a very short life-I think it was about six weeks. The coin was much more durable. I think that as a general rule the lower the denomination of the note, the shorter its useful life. Senator Townley suggested that many of the dollar coins probably went into glass jars on the mantelpiece or something like that. I think that is highly likely. Perhaps that is an additional reason why we should consider minting $5 and/or $10 coins. The coins that go into glass jars on the mantelpiece effectively become interest free, voluntary loans to the rest of society by the people who fill glass jars with coins. If we were to mint a $10 coin, one could perhaps get quite an appreciable amount in voluntary but interest free loans from the public. I will certainly pass on Senator Townley's suggestion to the Treasurer.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and follows the question which was asked by Senator Bjelke-Petersen this afternoon. I ask: Has the Leader's attention been drawn to a farm poll in today's issue of the National Farmer? Does this poll indicate that rural residents are deserting the National Party of Australia in droves? This being the case, can the National Party claim to represent the interests of rural Australia? Would the Leader expect the National Party's standing to erode further following the work of Labor's country task force which was referred to earlier today?

—I take a point of order, Mr President. Under no conceivable circumstances can the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce be required, in terms of his ministerial responsibilities, to have any responsibility for the National Party, telephone polls or for any comments about the National Party, since none are related in any way whatsoever to his portfolio responsibilities.

—Order! There is no point of order. The question was addressed to Senator Button in his capacity as Leader of the Government in the Senate. A portion of the question related to Government policy and therefore the question is in order.

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I think the question was directed to me in that capacity, as you have pointed out. That makes me responsible for everything and, in a sense, at the same time totally irresponsible, and enables me to say what I want to about this.
—I hope you are quotable on that point of being responsible for everything.

—And irresponsible at the same time, I said, Senator. But let me go to the specifics of the question. It is true that in a survey published in today's issue of the National Farmer, the fortunes of the National--
—You read it, do you?

—Of course I read the National Farmer. I just explained that I am Leader of the Government in the Senate. Any Leader of the Government in the Senate who did not read the National Farmer would be remiss indeed. Let me say that indeed the point made by Senator Colston seems to be borne out by that survey published in today's issue. That survey, a farm poll of February 1986, shows a slide in the fortunes of the National Party of Australia from 54 per cent at the time of the last election to a 43 per cent intended vote for the National Party today. The Liberals do not seem to fare much better, with a decline from 31 per cent to 26 per cent whereas the performance of the Labor Party, with a decline from 7 per cent to 4 per cent, is relatively much better. That is a poll conducted among farmers-not in rural electorates but among farmers. One would expect in the normal euphoria of Australian politics that the Australian Democrats, who are not well represented here today, would anticipate that they would pick up some of that decline, but unfortunately for them that is not the case. The same sorts of figures are reflected in the leadership of the National Party where the decline has been more significant than the decline in the fortunes of the Party itself and those of the spokesman on primary industry issues for the National Party in the House of Representatives.

answer.para: All I was seeking to say earlier in answer to Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question was that, whatever noise we get from the National Party section of the chamber, farmers are clearly not satisfied with the quality of the intellectual leadership they are getting from the Party which has claimed to represent them over many years, and indeed has, which is why the farmers have been in so much trouble. The farmers are obviously very concerned about that. Of course, those concerns are reflected much more widely in rural communities. So Senator Colston is quite right in the point that he sought to intrude subtly into his question. I agree with that. The point which was made earlier is amply supported by those figures.

talk.start.para: —I address a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the Minister say whether any International Year of Peace funds have been allocated either to the United Nations Association of Australia or the Medical Association for the Prevention of War, or both of those organisations? Is the Minister able to confirm or deny that the present visit to Australia by the anti-nuclear activist, Dr Helen Caldicott, who has been going around the countryside preaching doom and destruction to children and adults alike, has been funded by either or both of these organisations with IYP funds? If so, is the Minister concerned that Dr Caldicott is making statements which are in direct conflict with established Government policy on peace, disarmament and arms control, such as her calling for the removal of the joint defence facilities, in contravention of the guidelines set down for the provision of IYP funds to organisations? If IYP funds from any source have gone to finance any aspect of Dr Caldicott's visit, what action will be taken by the Federal Government to recoup the funds and ensure that there are no future breaches of the guidelines?

—I do not have any information as to whether Dr Caldicott's visit is being funded in any way out of the International Year of Peace program. I will endeavour to find out and give an answer accordingly. Until I do, I do not think it is appropriate to say anything more about the other matters that Senator Kilgariff has addressed.

—My question is to the Minister for Education. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to statements from the Queensland Minister for Education, Mr Powell, supporting the establishment of a private university in Queensland? Does the Federal Government share the Queensland Minister's enthusiasm for this proposal? In view of similar moves towards profit-based education by groups in the Northern Territory and Western Australia, can the Minister advise whether the Federal Government would consider providing any assistance to private universities and the students attending them?

answer.speaker: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

talk.start.para: —Yes, my attention has been drawn to reports that Mr Powell, the Minister for Education in Queensland, seems to be enthusiastic about proposals for profit making private universities. I know that this fad is also being pursued by some people in the Northern Territory. I think I have made it clear before, but I would like to make it quite clear now, in response to Senator Black's question, that our Government will not support the establishment of private universities in this country. Our Government, for reasons that I do not really have time to go into now, does not believe that such proposals would be in the interests of either those students who would have access to those universities or other students throughout Australia.

answer.para: We are opposed to the establishment of private universities. Because we are opposed to such a development, we would not provide any assistance by way of Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission funding for such institutions; nor would we be prepared to provide the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance for students who attended those institutions; nor would Commonwealth agencies for accreditation of tertiary courses be prepared to accredit those courses; nor do I believe that vice-chancellors of existing public universities would be prepared to admit such an institution into their group. So I believe there would be no point in a State government deciding, by legislation, to establish such an institution and call it a university since the government which has responsibility for funding and administration of universities, namely, our Government, would not be prepared to accept such a development.

I should make it quite clear also that our Government is not opposed to private support for university activities in Australia, be that support in teaching or research activities. If there are private benefactors and wealthy private interests around, either overseas or in Australia, who wish to support university activities, we would certainly be very pleased for them to do so. For example, we are encouraging industry funds to support research in universities and in institutes of technology. We think it is highly desirable that industry play a larger role in supporting research activities in our universities since industry stands in a very favourable position to benefit from the products of research.

We would also be pleased to see wealthy private interests donating to university trusts, establishing chairs and things of that nature. Therefore, we are quite positive towards support by private sources for properly regulated and properly run public university activities at teaching or research level. We will not facilitate in any way-in fact, we will take measures to prevent-the establishment of institutions set up for profit which would not operate in the interests of any students at all and which would certainly, in the longer run, undermine the very high standards we have established in our university sector.

talk.start.para: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs been drawn to a recent report in the Melbourne Sun-News Pictorial to the effect that Colonel Gaddafi has instructed three Libyan diplomats in Australia to return home? Two of those diplomats are said to be from the Libyan People's Bureau in Canberra and one from the Libyan Cultural Centre in Melbourne. I ask whether this report is accurate. If so, what reasons have been given for the action? Have the three left Australia? If not, when will they leave? Will the Australian Government allow the three to be replaced? Does the removal from Australia of the Director of the Libyan Cultural Centre mean that that centre will be closed? If not, why not?
—I do not have an answer on that question. I will seek one and let the honourable senator know.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister assisting the Prime Minister on Youth Affairs able to say what the result of analyses carried out on the Priority One: Young Australia national phone-in has been? Can the Minister advise whether the phone-in and its result are likely to alter the Government's plan of action for the Priority One program?

—This question involves some detailed figures. I thought I had an answer to it. However, I do not at the moment. Therefore, I will seek the information for Senator Elstob and provide it as soon as possible.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Communications assure the people of north Queensland that the Government does not intend to downgrade the weather forecasting services by removing briefing officers from Rockhampton, Mount Isa and Cairns?

—I do not know what the plans are for the removal of weather officers there or anywhere else. However, I can tell Senator Boswell that if he is concerned about services in general in country areas he had better quick and lively scuttle the Opposition Leader's plans to privatise services. I would not be at all surprised if Mr Howard has in his back pocket privatisation list privatising meteorological services along with Australia Post, Telecom Australia, Trans Australia Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd and everything else which he has said at various times that he, as a Liberal Prime Minister, would privatise. Should that happen Senator Boswell would have a great deal to complain about if he purports to represent the people of northern or outback Queensland because they would not even have a telephone or postal service.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. My question was not directed towards the answer that I am receiving. Mr President, I point out to you that the Minister is not answering the question. I ask you to call him to order.
—Order! There is no point of order. I call the Minister for Finance.
—Mr President, I had actually finished my answer except to say that I will see whether Mr Duffy has anything to add to my answer.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to a report in yesterday's Melbourne Herald-in fact on the front page-that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Neil Brown, believes that the Commonwealth Government car service is `extravagant'? Can the Minister, as the Minister responsible for managing government expenditure, provide information to the Senate on whether improvements might be made to the current position?

—The recent history behind the matter reported in yesterday's Melbourne Herald is of course that the tactics committee of the Liberal Party had, with a brilliant sense of timing, decided to release their waste watchers stunt the day after it had been published that its Deputy Leader had been caught with his fist well and truly in the taxpayers' pocket.
—Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw that comment in respect of a member of another place.

—Certainly, Mr President, I withdraw. The day after it had been revealed that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition had been running up a $10,000 a month bill-I repeat that, it is not a slip of the tongue, a $10,000 a month car pool--

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. It has been made quite clear by Mr Brown that he has challenged those accounts and that there are definite errors in them. The Minister would know that. He is deliberately using false information in Question Time for political reasons. He should be called to order.
—Order! There is no point of order. I call Senator Walsh.

—Mr President, I am aware that it has been claimed that the figures are false. However, so far as I know, absolutely no evidence has been produced to support that claim. I turn more directly to the point of Senator Maguire's question and Mr Brown's claim that there is room to alter and improve the Commonwealth car service. I think that is probably true. I agree with that. There is room to improve it, particularly to reduce the costs. In particular, Mr Brown should start by curbing his self-indulgence and reducing his demand on the Commonwealth car pool.

question.block.title: LOCAL GOVERNMENT: GENERAL REVENUE SHARING ARRANGEMENTS

talk.start.para: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services say whether the Government will introduce legislation before the end of this autumn session to replace the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act to establish a general revenue sharing arrangement for the next four to five years, or will it be another one-off arrangement dictated by the Department of Finance and Treasury? Also, when is there likely to be a statement on funding levels for local government, realising that these points are quite important as far as forward planning for local government is concerned? I believe the Government ought to give urgent consideration to it.

—Local government shares in Commonwealth revenue. Of course, that has its relationship to State government revenue which is made available on an annual basis. I know of no steps which the Government contemplates to change either the ratio or those arrangements. However, I will seek an opinion from the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services to see whether it is contemplated that any legislation is proposed. I have not heard of it in respect of the current session but I imagine that the existing arrangements will continue and the matters will be determined in the 1986-87 Budget for context.

—I ask a supplementary question. I am not sure whether the Minister got the full impact of my question. I asked whether the Government will introduce legislation before the end of the autumn session to replace the Local Government (PIT) Sharing Act and establish a general revenue sharing arrangement?

—I have no knowledge of it at all. Members of Cabinet may have different views. Certainly I have not been advised of any steps in that direction. Again, I will seek the opinion of the Minister as to whether it is contemplated. I have not seen it listed in any of the suggested legislation for this session.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, relates to the disposal of surplus migrant centres announced as part of the May 1985 economic statement. What progress has been made in identifying surplus centres and disposing of these assets as part of the 1985-86 Budget strategy?

answer.speaker: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

talk.start.para: —As a result of the 1985-86 Budget savings the Government decided to dispose of surplus land and buildings at various migrant centres around Australia. Four centres were found to be surplus to our requirements and are to be sold in their entirety. I am advised that they are Fairy Meadow and Cabramatta in New South Wales and Eastbridge and Wiltona in Victoria. The hostels were declared surplus to requirements by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in August 1985. As the honourable senator would be aware, the disposal will come within the responsibility of the property section of the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services. The revenue generated from these disposals will contribute to the Government's general economic objectives of offsetting capital expenditure on redevelopment and rationalisation, as well as providing improved transit accommodation for new arrivals in Australia.

answer.para: The standing policy for the disposal of surplus Commonwealth property, which was established by the previous Government, is that surplus property is first offered on sale to the State and then to local government bodies before it is made available for public sale on the open market. I am advised that the Department is negotiating with the New South Wales Department of Housing for the purchase of both Fairy Meadow and Cabramatta hostels and that that Department has carried out a feasibility study of the likely cost of converting the hostels into public housing-a much needed amenity. In Victoria, the Ministry of Housing is currently undertaking a detailed investigation of the possibility of converting the units at Eastbridge migrant centre to self-contained accommodation. As there appears to be no State or local government interest in the Wiltona migrant centre, it will be offered for sale on the open market in the near future to realise the financial objectives of the 1985-86 Budget.

interject.speaker: The PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —Honourable senators will be aware that the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings met yesterday morning and determined that an additional condition 5A should be inserted in the guidelines governing the access to proceedings of the Senate and the House of Representatives for the purpose of recording and broadcasting excerpts. The new condition is to the effect that material constituting part of a debate or proceeding in either House that was subsequently withdrawn would not be available for rebroadcast. I add that the Committee was of the opinion that to rebroadcast material that was subsequently withdrawn was not in accordance with guideline No. 5, which states that fairness and accuracy must be observed. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the adoption of guideline 5A places rebroadcast of material in a slightly different position from that adopted by the written record as appears in Hansard.

interject.para: The Committee was of the opinion that Madam Speaker should make a statement on this matter and that a copy of the statement should be forwarded to the broadcasters mentioned by the Leader of the National Party in the House of Representatives in the matter of privilege he raised in that House on Tuesday of this week. The Speaker indicated in her statement yesterday that the Presiding Officers would be seeking discussions with representatives of the Press Gallery as to the operation and observance of the guidelines generally. This meeting subsequently took place late yesterday afternoon. In the course of that meeting some areas of concern on the new guideline 5A were put to us. The Speaker and I informed the media representatives that they should put these matters in writing. The Speaker and I undertook that, upon receipt of this written material, we would convene a further meeting of the Committee to consider the matters raised.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —by leave-I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the statement.
I note that this statement is in the nature of an interim statement in that the matter of the new guideline is still under consideration.

talk.start.para: —I interrupt the honourable senator to say that the new guideline exists now.

—That is understood, Mr President. But the matter is not closed as far as the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings is concerned because I note that, at the end of your statement, you say that you and the Speaker have informed the media representatives that they should put their concerns in writing. I think it is appropriate that there should be that further consideration because, as the statement points out, the addition of guideline 5A puts the rebroadcasting of material in the electronic media in a position different from that adopted with respect to newspapers. I have expressed what is essentially a personal view in this matter in previous discussions in this chamber. It is certainly my personal view that, as far as possible, we should be putting the electronic media in the same position as the print media with respect to the coverage of Parliament. I think it is particularly important because of the very important role the electronic media-both radio and television-now play in the dissemination of information and news in the community. If access to the Parliament by the electronic media is limited the influence of this Parliament is limited, and that is a bad thing.

speech.para: Having said that, I in no way adopt on behalf of the Opposition a firm view on the new guideline. I think it is a matter which needs some consideration at the party level. The possibility of thoroughly offensive material which, under the direction of the Speaker or of the President of the Senate, is withdrawn as being unparliamentary for whatever reason being rebroadcast over and over again in unvarnished form and without any reference to the fact that it was withdrawn gives rise to doubts, certainly in my mind and, I am sure, in the minds of some other senators and members, and I think we have to look at the significant problems which could emerge if there was an unlimited power to rebroadcast material which was offensive and which was withdrawn.

I think the Committee has come to grips with a difficult situation. It has taken perhaps a more cautious course by putting in a new guideline whilst it is still to receive the final views of the media representatives who have met with the Committee. In the interests of seeing the growing access of electronic media to the Parliament advance in a steady way, I think that caution is probably justified. Mr President, if members and senators lose confidence in the changes that have been instituted under your presidency and under the Speaker with the active involvement of the Committee we might go backwards even further. I commend the cautious stance that you have taken but I look forward to the Committee giving these very important issues closer consideration. Certainly the Opposition parties will want to consider the implications for the operation of the Parliament. I will not seek leave to continue my remarks because I know that Senator Chipp is interested and has some views on this matter, but it is a matter which we may wish to debate further at a later time.
Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings
Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings

speech.speaker: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

talk.start.para: —I concur largely with most of what Senator Chaney has said. I also have not had time to put the matter to my Party. Therefore, at this stage, I put forward only my views, which I regret to say-with ultimate respect to you, Mr President, and to the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings-I put in much stronger terms than did Senator Chaney. I vigorously disagree with the recommendation or the decision that you have made and the guidelines that you have placed on the electronic media.

speech.para: I find it not only inconsistent but also-again with ultimate respect to the Committee-absurd that words can be said in this chamber or the other chamber and then members or senators can ask for them to be withdrawn, the print media can reprint those words and use them in cartoons, yet the electronic media cannot rebroadcast them. I find it even more extraordinary that the very words which will subsequently be forbidden to be used by the electronic media have already been on the electronic media if the proceedings of that chamber happened to be broadcast on that day. An incident occurred in the House of Representatives yesterday when the proceedings were not being broadcast. My distinguished friend Senator Chaney was called a name. The Minister who called him a name-not a very flattering name-was quite properly asked by the Speaker to withdraw, which he did. Mr President, under the guidelines that you have brought down, as I understand them, an excerpt of that Minister calling a distinguished member of this chamber a name cannot be rebroadcast. But it appears on whatever the page is of the Sydney Morning Herald this morning, with that incident being told over and over again. I believe that that Minister should be able to be exposed on the electronic media for the wrong thing he did in the same way that he has been exposed in the print media. I believe that by denying the electronic media the right to do this, we are abusing the very high privilege we have in this place. I know that this is not the intention of the Committee, but the effect on the media towards us must be `Those people down there can misbehave, they can put on a terrible performance in front of school children and whatever and bring this place into disrepute', which we do from time to time, and I include myself in that. But then we say, `But we will not let the electronic media rebroadcast it because it might look bad to the people out there'.

We are having a bit each way on that. If we misbehave in this place, why deny the free press, free radio and free television the opportunity of exposing that misbehaviour to the people of Australia? The material can be reprinted in full in a newspaper. A summary, including a quotation, may be given on television but the actual excerpt may not be, while at the same time the entire incident now being banned could well have been broadcast over the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, if that chamber happened to be broadcast at the time. There are people, even in this hallowed chamber, who sometimes offend Standing Orders. There is one Minister here-I will not name him-whose behaviour in terms of personal abuse leaves a lot to be desired. I am sure that Minister, who gives as good as he gets, would not mind himself being broadcast or rebroadcast. He would probably enjoy it. But why are we protecting people like that? I myself, I freely admit, have transgressed Standing Orders, and quite properly have been called to order by you, Mr President, or by your Deputies. There is no reason why I should be protected by the Standing Orders. I feel very strongly about this and I intended to move that the matter be referred back to the Committee for further consideration. But as Senator Chaney has foreshadowed that he will take the matter to his Party and I will take it to mine, it may be that we shall have an opportunity to debate the matter again in this chamber at a future time.

speech.speaker: Coleman Sen R.N.

talk.start.para: —I am sure that members of the Senate are aware that I am a member of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings, and we discussed this matter for quite some time prior to the making of the statement by the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The matter is still before the Committee. The matter will not just pack up and go away; it will be constantly before us. How we get around it is yet to be determined by the Committee to the full extent. I simply take this opportunity to move:

speech.para: That the debate be now adjourned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —During Question Time Senator Kilgariff asked me about Government support through the International Year of Peace program for the visit to Australia by Dr Caldicott. I am able to advise him and the Senate that the Foreign Affairs Department has now advised me that the Australian Government has not been asked to provide, and has not provided, any financial assistance under the IYP to Dr Caldicott for her visit to Australia or travel within Australia. I believe that the record should be set straight on that point.
—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present a report of the Auditor-General on an efficiency audit dated March 1986.

debate.title: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

speech.speaker: Colston Sen M.A.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, I present the fifth report on the examination of annual reports dated March 1986, together with the transcript of evidence.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave-I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

On behalf of the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts I table the fifth report arising from the Committee's examination of annual reports, pursuant to the provisions of sessional order 7. During 1985, the Committee reported to the Senate on several important issues. Honourable senators will recall that the Committee's first report dealt with the timeliness of reporting to Parliament by Government departments and authorities. The second report considered standards of presentation and information which should be in annual reports. The third report concentrated on children's television standards. The fourth report examined the 1983-84 annual report of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority and, in particular, assessment procedures used in Australian Capital Territory secondary colleges.

The report I table today is sub-titled `another look at children's television'. As that title indicates, this Committee has shown a long standing interest in children's television. This is its fourth report on the subject. In 1978 the Committee tabled a report on ``the impact of television on the development and learning behaviour of children''. In 1981 the Committee tabled another report entitled `children and television revisited'. In August 1985 the Committee reported on children's television standards.

In this report, the Committee examines in detail the development of the Australian Children's Television Foundation and the Children's Program Committee of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The Committee also considers the activities of the government-owned television broadcasters in the field of children's television and discusses some other issues relevant to the future of this important aspect of Australian television. There is no doubt that television monopolises the lives of most Australian children. On average, children view approximately 24 hours of television a week. Some children view television from 40 to 50 hours a week.

At the time of the Committee's first inquiry into this matter in 1978, concern about what children were viewing on television was widespread and acute. The situation had not changed significantly in 1981. Few quality children's programs were being produced and those that were lacked variety. In 1985 the Committee was pleased to hear and see evidence of significant improvements that have recently been made in the quality of children's programs.

In taking another look at children's television, the Committee has reviewed the work of the Australian Children's Television Foundation. In 1981 this Committee strongly supported the establishment of, and Commonwealth financial support for, the Foundation. The Foundation, which was incorporated as a company in 1982, was intended by the Government to play a `catalytic role in the development of quality children's television programs by bringing together the industry's best resources'.

The Committee's report gives details of recent developments within the Foundation. It concludes that the Foundation has contributed significantly to the production of high quality children's television in Australia. The Committee was particularly impressed with the quality of the `Winners' series, which was the first of the Foundation's major undertakings as an executive producer. This impression no doubt is shared by the many thousands of Australian parents and children who have enjoyed these excellent programs.

The Foundation, regrettably, has experienced some funding problems. When the Foundation was set up, it was envisaged that, after three years of operation, it would be self-sufficient. The Foundation, however, remains totally dependent on government funding. It receives grants from the Commonwealth and all the States and Territories, with the notable exception of Queensland.

The Committee was told by representatives of the ACTF that the procedures for raising funds from eight different governments on a yearly basis are cumbersome and time consuming. The Foundation is bound by the requirements of different ministerial departments, both State and Commonwealth, when making its annual requests for finance. It is worth noting that donations to the Foundation are not tax deductible-a fact that has probably impeded the original goal of financial self-sufficiency. The Committee believes that the present arrangements for financing the ACTF lead to uncertainty and a lack of confidence in the plan ahead. Accordingly, the Committee recommends that the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) should review the present funding position of the Foundation in the light of the difficulties noted in the Committee's report.

The Committee's report also examines the development of the Children's Program Committee of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. This Committee advises the Tribunal on all aspects of children's television including the classification of children's programs. It comprises four members drawn from the public and three members from the television and advertising industries. From the evidence before it, the Committee considers that the members of the Children's Program Committee are competent, dedicated and enthusiastic. There was no evidence available to the Committee to suggest that a more effective body could be found to classify children's programs.

The report also discusses four issues that the Committee believes are important for the future of children's television in Australia. These issues relate to: Children's viewing patterns and `C' time; programs for six to nine-year-olds; formula programming; and children's drama. Children constitute a significant segment of the total television audience. The peak viewing time for children aged 5 to 12 is between 6 p.m. and 9.30 p.m. At 7.45 p.m. almost 50 per cent of children are watching television. Information presented in annual reports of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal reveals that the number of children viewing television during `C' time-that is, the hour between 4 p.m. and 5 p.m. on weekdays-in metropolitan areas decreased from 265,000 in 1977 to 163,000 in 1985. Various reasons have been advanced for this decrease, one of which was that 4 p.m. to 5 p.m. may not be the most desirable period for `C' time. The Committee considers that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's review of children's television standards should include an investigation of when `C' programs should be shown.

There is some evidence which suggests that the television needs of six to nine-year-olds have to some extent been neglected.
