The Committee heard evidence that most children's programs are aimed at the upper end of the six to 13 age group. The Committee would encourage the ABT to consider this issue when it reviews the children's television standards, sometime after 1 July 1986. Nevertheless, it considers it would be unfortunate if regulations became necessary to meet the needs of children in this age group.

Formula programming for the children's hour continues despite the existence of the children's television standards which encourage variety. Formula programs, sometimes referred to as magazine programs, are produced for long periods using the same formula. The Committee was told that it is possible to attract children to `C' programs by broadcasting a diverse and interesting range of programs. The success of a particular television broadcaster in Adelaide lent support to this proposition.
Children's drama is an essential element of television for children and the Committee strongly supports the ABT's regulations encouraging the local production of children's drama.

No report on children's television would be complete without a discussion of the roles of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service. The Committee found that the ABC continues to provide a diverse range of quality children's programs. Many see the ABC's children's programs as the yardstick by which others can be measured. The Committee trusts that the ABC's high priority to the production of these programs will continue. The role of the SBS in children's television is more modest than that of the ABC. The SBS does not have in-house production departments and relies heavily on overseas programs. This reliance creates several problems which are detailed in the report. SBS children's programs rate poorly and SBS is reviewing its role in children's television. Nevertheless, the Committee's view is that children's programs reflecting cultural and ethnic diversity have a place on Australian television.

The Committee welcomes the widespread recognition within the industry that the children of Australia have special television needs. This recognition has not always been evident in the past. The Committee trusts that quality children's television will soon become the norm, rather than the exception. Recent developments in the field of children's drama suggest that this is possible. The Committee is confident that firm foundations have been laid for the industry to produce innovative, exciting and entertaining programs for the benefit of our children and the nation. I commend the report to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —by leave-I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

The report I have just tabled describes the work of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee during a 12-month period from July 1984 to June 1985 last year. A report on the period July 1985 to June 1986 is under preparation. During the period covered by this report, Senator Coates was the Chairman of the Committee. He deserves great credit for the courteous, efficient and committed way in which he led the Committee through its scrutiny of many hundreds of instruments of delegated legislation. I also pay tribute to the other senators who have served with dedication and without complaint on this busy Committee. All have acted in keeping with its long-established tradition of bipartisanship.

The Committee has been in existence for over 50 years examining delegated legislation to ensure that it is in an appropriate form and does not infringe on accepted rights and liberties. As the 77th report will demonstrate, the need for a vigilant scrutiny committee is as strong today as it ever was. Delegated legislation represents an enormous growth of executive law-making. The sheer volume and complexity of many of these instruments can lead to infringement of rights and curtailment of liberties. The day-to-day mechanisms of government administration are built on instruments of delegated legislation. But the ever increasing complexity of government can result in the deliberate or inadvertent reduction of freedoms without express parliamentary sanction.

The Committee is a watchdog. It exists as the eyes and ears of the Senate chamber in scrutinising executive laws that the Senate itself cannot possibly find time to examine and debate. The Committee's responsibility is to the Senate. I am pleased to say that the Committee has long enjoyed the consistent support and encouragement of senators on both sides of the chamber, who recognise the Committee's highly developed sense of bipartisanship in performing the task of legislative scrutiny. I would ask Ministers and their officials responsible for preparing delegated legislation to read the Committee's 77th report. It will reveal certain themes which reflect the Committee's concern to protect rights by upholding the principles which are its terms of reference. The report will be of assistance to Ministers and officials preparing legislation who wish to avoid the pitfalls pointed out by the Committee report. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

talk.start.para: —The Academic Salaries Tribunal report may well be considered as unimportant by many people. I suggest that it be read by honourable senators because it is not necessarily the level of salaries that it recommends but the reasoning and the development of the philosophy that are important as far as many people in this type of occupation receiving this type of remuneration are concerned. speech.para: There have been suggestions quite regularly that some of these officers should be paid on a post-tax or non-tax basis. Should there be a reconsideration of attitudes by governments on the relativity question as well as on allowances and entitlements generally? I think that changes to the tax laws that are under consideration mean that quite a few of these remuneration schedules and scales should be looked at. Clearly, it is not the quantum but the method and the recommendations put forward by Mr Justice Ludeke that demonstrate the maze of considerations for the academic area only. While the recommendations will help to rectify many complaints, just as surely they will open up many others. speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —I join my colleague Senator Archer in speaking to the Academic Salaries Tribunal report. We have had the experience over the last few years of seeing universities and colleges of advanced education punished by the Government whenever they decide to pay salaries at the level they think appropriate to the most senior officers of their organisations. I refer, of course, to the salaries paid to vice-chancellors and principals of colleagues. I put to the Senate the proposition that it should be a matter for the institutions as to what they think should be the salary for the chief executive officer whom they employ. We frequently criticise our tertiary institutions for the quality of their management. One of the determinants of that quality is the stature and capacity of the person selected to fill the most senior post in the university or college.

speech.para: Yet the salary scale is determined centrally and rigidly administered. We inflict upon the institutions a punishment if they dare go outside that salary scale, particularly if they pay more. It seems to me that we should be saying to the universities and colleges: `You have a total budget. You manage that budget. If within that budget you wish to employ a person on a higher salary scale, that is your judgment. You live with it. You take the consequences.' Instead, we have had the practice over some years-I have been able to examine it a little more carefully in Opposition than I could when in government-where we require compliance with that pay scale and we punish the institutions if they go outside it, as some have tried to do and some wish to do. Let us look at the way the North Americans operate their universities and colleges. They have no doubt that if they wish to get top people they will have to pay top salaries. There is no reason why universities and colleges should not be able to determine pay scales for their staff according to merit as they see it and to appeal to a wider group of scholars and administrators, not only in this country, but throughout the world.

It is quite clear that the report of the Academic Salaries Tribunal is necessary because of the rigidities that we have built into the tertiary system and higher education in this country. The question before us all is whether that rigid system is appropriate, efficient or optimal. The more I examine it, the more I conclude that it is not efficient or optimal and even if it were appropriate once it is not appropriate now and will be less appropriate in the future. My colleagues and I would be much more disposed to look at a system which gave greater flexibility and autonomy to colleges of advanced education and universities to let them work out, in accordance with their needs and the type of people they wish to employ, who would be the most appropriate person and what salary would have to be paid.

For example, the modern vice-chancellor above all has to be a manager with good academic standing-certainly a scholar-and with scholarly standing if possible. But the vice-chancellor of a university has to be a manager. If we look at the salaries for top managers in the private sector, what is offered through the Academic Salaries Tribunal by our universities is not sufficient to attract the top managers in this country and certainly not the top managers from overseas. The same thing applies to the colleges of advanced education. Some of them are very large business undertakings. The chief executive of any of those organisations should be a person of absolutely top management skill and capacity. They will not be obtained and held in our tertiary institutions while this rigid system continues. It is my understanding that our parties will be seeking to provide a more flexible arrangement in government when it is our turn again to administer this system and to administer the tertiary and higher education systems.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I rise to make a few comments concerning the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Hon. Bill Hayden. The statement gives an account of his recent visit to a number of South East Asian countries. The Minister refers in the statement to the need for Australia to recognise the significance of this region to our future. I certainly agree with the Minister on that point. Of course, in some areas of South East Asia I believe Australia must pick up its act because it has been shown in some of the islands that there is a tendency now to look to Australia as the big brother, and not in a nice way.

speech.para: The statement also refers to the Minister's visit to the Philippines following the fall of the Marcos Government and the advent of the Aquino Government. Mr Hayden has outlined plans in this document for an increase in the level of Australian aid to the Philippines. I commend the Government for making this move, as I commend the Government for being amongst the first countries to recognise, on behalf of Australia, the new administration of Mrs Corazon Aquino. Along with many, I was amazed at the developments in the Philippines which led to the downfall of the Marcos regime. It was quite remarkable to see the people of the Philippines effect that change with such a minimal amount of injury and loss of life, particularly when one considers the density of the population and the strength of feeling of the Filipino people, with the abuse of human rights and the heavy-handed use of the police and the military which had prevailed under Mr Marcos. It was a remarkable revolution, perhaps I should say, a national uprising.

As many commentators have pointed out and, indeed, as the Minister pointed out in his statement, the euphoria has now died down. Now the real task of rebuilding the country begins, which will be a very long road. Mrs Aquino and her Government must now bring the people back to earth so that together they can implement realistic programs to get the country back on track and relieve the dismal conditions of so many Filipino people. The Minister makes the point in this statement that there is a great need to ensure that stability is maintained in the South East Asian area. It is of benefit, of course, to the countries themselves for with stability comes a better opportunity for economic development and growth. It also benefits Australia because it is in our interests that we are part of a stable region.

I am concerned about recent reports in the Press, specifically the article in the Australian on Wednesday, 19 March. There are other articles which indicate that the New People's Army is persisting with its guerrilla activities in certain provinces of the Philippines. The article in the Australian of 19 March states:
Guerilla activity by the Philippines' communist insurgents is on the rise, belying claims by the Aquino Government that it is close to negotiating a nationwide ceasefire with the rebels.
Members of the New People's Army (NPA) have carried out at least 10 operations during the past week, indicating the onset of a major new offensive.
The guerillas have conducted raids in eight provinces, including two where government officials had said the NPA was observing an unofficial ceasefire.
The report continues:
The death toll from rebel activities during the past week-
this is this last week-
stands at 60, with the biggest loss of life reported after a raid on a National Food Authority warehouse in the north-eastern province of Cagayan where 23 people were killed.
Another attack, in which 10 Government militiamen died, occurred in the island province of Bohol, one of the provinces where the NPA was reportedly observing a ceasefire.

It is interesting to note that the numbers of deaths by the communist insurgents in this last week is far more than the number of people who lost their lives in the national uprising. The article continues:
The Aquino Government's pledge to act quickly to solve the insurgency problem has been largely discredited by the upsurge in guerrilla attacks.

Although NPA spokesmen have consistently said that the insurgents are prepared to consider a ceasefire, the terms they set as a pre-condition for negotiations have cast doubts on the sincerity of their offer.

The rebels have insisted that President Aquino terminate the United States bases agreement, launch a comprehensive land-reform program, withdraw the army from insurgency prone provinces and make other major concessions.
In return, the NPA has offered to observe a truce for a limited period while retaining possession of its weapons.
The Defence Minister, Mr Enrile, has publicly expressed scepticism over the NPA ceasefire offer.
I will briefly read other parts of that article, which I think are quite significant:
Although NPA regional commanders in some areas have commented on the ceasefire proposal there has been no official response from the Communist Party's central committee.

Although Mrs Aquino won an important propaganda victory during her first few days in office by honouring a pledge to release all political prisoners, including hardline communists and former guerrillas, it has become obvious that her honeymoon with the Left is over.

We must take note of these reports because Mrs Aquino will require much fortitude, strength and assistance now to ensure that her Government comes through with developments peacefully. One must realise too, when one sees the support that communist insurgents get in the battles and fighting in other countries very close to the Philippines and in South East Asia, that we must be very wary. I believe that at this time, when Mrs Aquino is endeavouring to get her Government and the country back on its feet, it is very susceptible to guerrilla and communist insurgency action.

talk.start.para: —by leave-Forest and forest-based industries have an important role to play in the overall economy of Australia and I think it is rather disappointing that the only time we hear anything about our forests is when they are razed by bushfires or are going to be raided by opposing armies, according to the conservationists, of forestry workers or road building groups. We must acknowledge that only a very small area of Australia is suitable for the growth of new forests and an even smaller area is natural rainforest. To that extent, the latter should be preserved. That means that the Federal and State governments must work alongside private enterprise and the conservation movement to ensure that we make the most of our resource, while at the same time protecting the environment and our national heritage. In other words, we have to establish a better balance between the demands of the environmental control and economic viability.

speech.para: The report by the various States regarding forestry and forest products clearly indicates that attempts are being made to try to keep this balance. In my own State of Tasmania a Forest Practices Act, the first of its kind in Australia, was passed in May last year to ensure that timber harvest is conducted in an environmentally acceptable manner and in accordance with approved timber harvesting plans. I commend to the Senate the major objectives of the national forestry strategy for Australia, as outlined on page 19 of the report, which seeks to gain a commitment from all parties involved in forest industries to treat forests in a manner that maximises their benefit to the community in the long term and to recognise the importance of multiple use management on a sustained basis. What concerns me is the Government's lack of interest in the growing of more and better forests, borne out by what I believe is a lack of intelligent forward planning, lack of money put aside for research and legislation that is determined to drive the private forester and developer out of business. Forests do not grow overnight. Even a softwood pine plantation takes up to 20 years to reach maturity. So it is important to invest and to encourage private sector investment in research and development.

I note the concerns expressed in the report about long term funding for the national bushfire research unit. speech.speaker: Archer Sen B.R.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate condemns the Hawke Labor Government for-
(a) plunging the housing of Australian families into the worst position in 50 years by doctrinaire and unbalanced policies;
(b) creating and maintaining a high interest, high tax economy that makes home ownership an unattainable goal for many young Australian families;
(c) presiding over and causing a rapid decline in the availability of rental housing, causing extreme hardship to low income families in particular;
(d) creating uncertainty by not releasing after 6 months, details concerning taxation policy on investment property; and
(e) destabilising the finance market by artificial and sectoral constraints which will have long-term detrimental effects on home ownership funding.

There is so much wrong with housing that it is difficult to know where to start. At the moment the Government seems to have about 10 spokesmen on housing. What they say seems to vary quite a lot. I was impressed to read in a transcript of the World Today what a Mr Duncan was reported to have said in answer to a question along the lines of `What do you believe the Government should be doing to resolve this housing crisis?' He said:
. . . I think we haven't got quite to a housing crisis yet.

I wish we could all agree that that was the case. But clearly it is not the case, and it is not the way the situation is seen by some of the Government spokesmen who are talking so much about it. Of all the problems that there are, not one has been caused by the weather, by international events, by the America's Cup, by Halley's Comet or anything else but the implementation of the crazy policies of the Government. Never-not even under Mr Whitlam-were the results of government policies so totally predictable and so absolutely inevitable.

To evaluate the position fully we must consider the home owners, the rental property owners, the would-be home owners, the tenants, the building industry, the industries that live from the housing industry and the finance people. Every single one will suffer from now on from trouble that has been engineered by the Government. Two major components have produced the present disaster. One component is the so-called dollar float, the Clayton float, the component from which we get all the disadvantages but none of the advantages because of the intrusion of the Government with artificial interest intervention. The second component is the media failure to report. It strikes me as being quite amusing that, in spite of the fact that those of us who have an association with the housing industry and with housing generally have been talking since September last year about the problems that have been arising, the media discovered housing only yesterday. One has only to look at the amount of headline print that brought housing to the fore yesterday and again today to see what I mean. I do not know why it has taken the media so long to realise that the things we have been saying and the predictions we have been making should have been given due publicity. The signs are absolutely clear.

There is a recognised market in Australia for approximately 130,000 new houses a year, give or take a few. That position prevailed over the seven years the Liberal-National Party Government was in office. Whenever there is a shortfall there will be a catch-up. Whenever there is an oversell, a borrow on the future, there will be a recession. No one who has followed housing over the last 20 or 30 years will argue about that for a minute. We were promised 500,000 jobs. It became necessary for the Government to buy those jobs, irrespective of the future cost. The building industry, being the easy industry to prime, took on 80,000 of those jobs-80,000 temporary jobs, I regret.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics commencement figures that were released yesterday barely touch the position. The figures that were produced were for January. What about February and March? What about the pipeline effect that goes with figures of this sort? We need to remember that March decisions are probably not statistics until June to September. Information obtained from some of the project builders about inquiries indicates that the figures for March are down as much as 60 per cent so far. This is no longer a slide; it is a precipice. Something has to be done by the Government. At present all we hear is what the Government is not going to do. I realise that it is confronted with various alternatives. There are political alternatives, economic alternatives, philosophical alternatives and, I suppose, one would have to throw in the election alternative. The problems will not go away. We are way past the stage where band-aids will help. There are no scapegoats at this stage. The reality must be faced. The phoney float we have learnt to live with over the last year or two has to go and the results faced up to. The Government's hope that the half-float would do enough good to enable it to back off in due course has failed. The devaluation of our currency failed to slow imports significantly, curtail borrowings, increase export income, tidy up the balance of payments, increase Australian profitability generally, slow the deficit growth, reduce inflation significantly or improve long term unemployment.

Referring to employment, what about those 80,000 people who look like being only very temporary additions to the work force? I refer to the carpenters, the bricklayers, the tilers, the glaziers, the plasterers, the manufacturers of white goods or furniture or carpets or curtains. What will happen to these as we watch the slide go on? The projection errors have been obvious to the people who watch the housing market since at least last September. When I asked a question of the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, even a month ago, on 14 February 1986, recorded at page 390 of the Senate Hansard, she made the comments:
Earlier this week Senator Archer asked a question relating to the state of the housing industry. I now have information in response to that question.
She then cited 1984-85 figures of 152,700 dwellings having been commenced, an 11-year high. She continued:

Dwelling commencements were maintained at a high level in the September quarter of 1985 and dwelling approvals data indicate that this level held through the December quarter. Some decline is now expected but the forecast of 140,000 dwelling commencements in 1985-86 still holds.

The Government acknowledges the effect that interest rates are having on the availability of housing finance. It is essential to keep money supply growth under control and to support the Australian dollar. Clearly this policy is working.
I underline those words:
Clearly this policy is working.
She continued:

We recognise that high interest rates and tight availability of housing finance are likely to cause housing activity to decline starting in the March quarter. However, we must get the fundamentals right. The housing industry can then look forward to a bright future under the Hawke Labor Government's strategy for growth. In the meantime the Government is closely watching the situation and, if necessary, will consider appropriate remedial policies for the housing industry.

Over the last few days the revisions have been coming from everywhere. Everybody is now saying: `Oh yes, but we think we will have another look at those figures'. I find that we are getting revisions of 30,000 or more from different people and that those who were saying that 140,000 is a reasonable figure to expect, as a drop of only 12,000 from last year, are now saying that they think it may be 110,000 or somewhere between 100,000 and 110,000.

What about jobs? What about investment? I noticed in a paper that turned up on my desk only this morning-a paper called Property Review of 20 March under the heading of `Lean year for suppliers', `Housing sector trough bodes ill for supply stocks'-the article by Robyn Goodfellow which starts off:
Sell building material supply stocks which rely heavily on the local housing industry, is the share tip from leading stock broker, Ord Minnett and Co. Ltd.

In a circular to clients, Ord Minnett which is 50 per cent owned by Westpac Banking Corporation advised clients to sell their holdings in Brick and Pipe Industries Ltd, Brickworks Ltd, Bristile Ltd, Bunnings Ltd, Calsil Ltd, Clifton Brick Ltd, Jennings Industries Ltd and Softwood Holdings Ltd.

I am afraid that that sort of prediction bodes ill all round. Then we come to the finance. The savings bank interest limit is an absolute farce. People with long bank histories and plenty of collateral and in reasonably comfortable circumstances may still get savings bank loans. But what about the new customers? I refer to those with $10,000, $15,000, $20,000 or $25,000 of their own, who probably have a wife and two or three children at home and earn $400 to $450 a week. Do honourable senators want to know what happens to them? I can tell them that they have no hope in the world of getting a savings bank loan. But on occasions they have been able to get what is now referred to as a cocktail loan. They may get $20,000 or $30,000 at 13 1/2 per cent and then $10,000, $20,000 or $30,000 at about 17 per cent to 19 per cent from the bank; they may get it from a permanent building society at 14 per cent, 16 per cent or more, and recently they may have been able to get it from the fringe finance companies at anything from 16 per cent to 20 per cent.

We piously carry on about 13 1/2 per cent being the housing rate ceiling. That is rubbish unless the policy of this Government can deny that the poor miss out and that the two-income, middle-income and better-off-income families get the funds. But now those funds are running out. This is because the Government's policy has made it happen. The savings banks have no money. The building societies have no money. The housing recession is unquestionably roaring on.

The housing market, as reported by the unthinking and uninitiated journalists, has been written up as being buoyant and one of the great successes of the Hawke Labor Government. Weekly sales reports have shown rising prices and large auction clearances. But what is it that underlies these figures and statements? Of course, the rental return on housing is poor. Historically, and with interest from managed funds being usually about double that of rental housing, returns from those sources are often, say, double the rent. So the owners of necessity started selling off where the income was important and where the costs were getting too high. As the Government started supporting the dollar float with interest rates, it became necessary for them to do so. Then it became clear that the Government's basic philosophy of attacking property owners was still alive and well. Then we got capital gains taxes and negative gearing provisions, and so the housing started to slow. For one or other reason, thousands of rental units around Australia have been sold and thousands of tenants have been forced to seek alternative accommodation. In actuality there are virtually no vacancies of rental properties in Australia. A rental vacancy of less than one per cent is full occupancy; that is the way it is in all the major centres.

In my notice of motion I raised the issue of funding. The figures were released after I put down that notice. They show that since last month savings bank loans have been reduced by 15 per cent, trading bank loans by 20.8 per cent and permanent building society loans by 13.6 per cent. Only the fringe lenders showed a slightly upward trend. The figures showed the sixth consecutive monthly decline and the lowest number of home loans in a month for over three years. All this has been brought about by the policies of this Government. Loans for the purchase of newly-erected houses are the lowest ever recorded by the Australian Statistician. The situation of project builders, large and small, spec builders and contract builders is critical. Bankruptcies in established and smaller firms have already started, and I regret that there will be plenty more of both builders and subcontractors.

What will the Government do? Will it unprop the overall interest rate? No, it will not, because as the Treasurer, Mr Keating, rightly said, if it lets the dollar find its true level of, say, plus or minus 60c the electorate would throw it out. Will the Government borrow huge amounts of overseas money for more props so that overseas interest payments will further erode our debt structure and further increase our consumer price index? I do not think it would want to do that. Will the Government have a proper look at the sham that we have had in the last three years of its pretending that the economy is lovely while all the time we have seen our reserves destroyed, our balance of payments lose ground, our debts mounting daily and a huge and inevitable day of reckoning just around the corner? No, I do not think the Government could face its masters in the Australian Council of Trade Unions on that one either. Will it tear up its stupid prices and incomes accord and get some system that the country can afford to live with? Again, I do not think so.

Even half a look at the latest Indicative Planning Council projections and the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for January as released yesterday must jerk the Government into action and out of the droll complacency so evident in answers given to me by the Minister for Housing and Construction, Mr West, and by Senator Ryan. The Indicative Planning Council is a very skilled group but totally constrained under its guidelines. It gave a clear warning when in Professor Gruen's letter of 1 November he told the Minister:
However, for the first time in over two years, the cost and availability of housing finance is likely to have some restraining influence on activity.
The tenor of their warning appeared several times through that report. However, the gung ho ministerial approach raced on like the Titanic.

Let us look at the rental position. There has always been an Australian Labor Party obsession with property owners and those who make provision for retirement income and who become second property owners for whatever reason. There are distinctly two classes of investment property owners. Firstly, there is the investor who is now selling out because of the Government's attitudes, actions and charges. Secondly, there are those people who become owners and stay with their property. It may be that a unit has been brought to house an aged single parent. A unit may have been bought for a student family, especially in a university area. A house may have been received by bequest. It may be that a house or unit could not be sold when desired. It may be that a house was kept when a new one was built. A house may have been held when on away postings-and Canberra is the prime example of where that sort of thing happens. All those people may become investment home owners for all those reasons. Traditionally in the past they have provided a very large portion of rental accommodation. The Government cannot afford to lose private rental owners. It has to encourage private sector owners to provide an ever increasing share. The Government's 4 per cent depreciation allowance will get it nowhere.

Universally the return on rental housing is less than that available from other sources. The Government can never meet the demand for housing if it loses these owners. To provide around 30,000 rental houses, which will be this year's current shortfall, would cost in the order of $2 billion. I would be very surprised if the Government's priorities are such that it can afford to put up $2 billion just to meet the shortfall. Clearly, the Government's philosophy is to sock the savers and to encourage people to spend it all and join the race for the social security queue.

I have a few suggestions to offer. Firstly, I suggest that the Government let the dollar float and I mean really float. Secondly, the interest rate for housing will then return to its proper and rightful level. Thirdly, I suggest the removal of all obstacles to secondary finance. Fourthly, I suggest that the Government reverse and withdraw the tax nonsense against those who provide rental housing. Fifthly, I suggest that the Government get greater use of the most efficient users of housing funds, for example, the co-operatives and the community groups which provide aged person housing and so on. Sixthly, I suggest that the Government follow some of the advice from the many reports on housing-for a start, the housing costs inquiry.

If honourable senators think, as various media gurus try to portray, that the only problem is in regard to housing I would suggest that they look again. That may be the problem that is most obvious this week. However, I ask honourable senators to look at the rural sector as a whole; I ask them to look at the mining sector. I ask honourable senators opposite to phone some of their friends in the manufacturing area where costs have gone through the roof. Retail orders in the last six or eight weeks have stopped coming through, and threatened added interest costs, taxes and charges have really caught them. I ask honourable senators to think of those businesses which traditionally, and, I add, quite safely in the past, have used high gearing funds for their operations and which now find that their average interest rates are 22 or 23 per cent. They are all in trouble. The loss of confidence that will flow on from housing will go right through business. There is no J curve. We lost the value of our dollar and got nothing in return. The Government must face the problem sooner or later. The longer the Government leaves it, the worse it becomes. Every day that no action is taken means days longer taken to recover. The Government's interest prop-up policy is the key to it all.

I am not one who spends time attacking or worrying about the media but on this occasion the media deserves a bit of a blast. It has toed the Government line. The media would not print or listen to the warnings we were giving on the very clear signs ahead. The media failed to research the issues. The media would not listen and then, strangely enough, yesterday it found housing. There was the big expose; the big banner page. The issue was certainly ready to go because the Government has done nothing of any consequence about it for so long. The media is there to produce the information, not just to represent the Government.

There is a crisis. It is a disaster. Action cannot be delayed. The loss of employment, bankruptcies and the disruption caused cannot be allowed to happen. The causes are totally clear. They represent the fulfilment of government policy. It is up to the Government to fix it. The Government stands condemned for the state to which it has reduced housing.

speech.speaker: Childs Sen B.K.

talk.start.para: —We are discussing an Opposition motion censuring the Hawke Government on housing. It is a very audacious motion. It is very audacious for the Opposition to be criticising the Hawke Labor Government. I will deal with that in some detail later. However, at the moment I am interested in Senator Archer's statement that the Press discovered housing only yesterday. The Opposition, of course, has asked only three miserable questions this session on this so-called crisis in housing. The Opposition has thought the issue so important that it has asked only three questions this session. Of course, one of the questions to which Senator Archer referred was asked by him. The situation is that the Liberal Party of Australia has decided that there is a crisis. Of course, Senator Archer has, in the usual Liberal fashion, started to talk down the economy. He referred to the suffering of people from now on as he made his prediction of doom and gloom, which is typical of the Liberal Party.

speech.para: I would like to remind Senator Archer of the facts. Those facts are unpalatable to the Liberal Party but they show that the general economy in this country is particularly prosperous. They show that despite the circumstances applying when this Government came to power the economy has prospered. The figures show, for example, that the growth in the gross domestic product in the year 1983-84 was 4.9 per cent. In the year 1984-85 the growth in the GDP was 4.8 per cent. They were two very substantial years of growth. Those figures compare with two years of the Fraser Government when the growth in the gross domestic product was 0.6 per cent-a shocking thing as far as the economy in the year 1982-83 was concerned. In 1981-82, under the Liberal Government, the growth in the gross domestic product was 2.8 per cent.

Unemployment in the country has fallen from 9 per cent in 1982-83 to 8 per cent now. In 1982-83 under the Liberal Government, the consumer price index was running at 11.5 per cent. In 1985 it was down to 8.2 per cent. That was a direct result of the prices and incomes accord which the Hawke Government has with the trade union movement. We have created 600,000 jobs in this country since March 1983. Employment is up and unemployment in the housing and construction industry is only 4.8 per cent. Honourable senators opposite can ask building tradesmen in Australia what the changes have been. The building tradespeople throughout Australia know that under the Hawke Government there has been a tremendous turnaround in the economy. This general milieu in which the housing industry in this country at present finds itself shows that we are in a very good position.

In regard to industrial relations, we have the best figures for 17 years. Of course, this Government decided that it was most important to have a strong building industry. We realised that it is based on Australian produce and Australian tradespeople and that it has a very effective labour multiplier effect. Right at the moment this Government has the question of housing under active consideration. Both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) have indicated that we will consider the matter in the Budget context, just as we will consider any matter that needs to be looked at. We realise that it is a matter which has to be under constant review.

Let us contrast what happened under the Hawke Government and what happened under the previous Liberal Government. This Government has a great record in housing. When in government in 1982-83, the Opposition had the housing industry on its knees. As a result of our policies, such as the first home owners scheme, by the stimulation of public housing and the general lift in the level of economic activity we have been able to raise the number of housing commencements from 105,000 to 137,000 in our first year and to 153,000 in the second year. The level of housing commencements will be 137,000 in the financial year 1985-86. These are the facts, which cannot be talked down. Our economic performance, the stimulation of industry in the private sector through the first home owners scheme and our increased efforts in public housing are significant. By the end of this financial year 210,000 families will have been successful in moving into their first homes as a result of our first home owners scheme. As a result of those approvals, the existing and ongoing commitment will be $870m.

As organisations within the building industry have stated, this scheme is the most successful home ownership program produced in this country. That is a statement of industry organisations such as the Housing Industry Association and the Master Builders Federation of Australia Inc. If honourable senators opposite compare that scheme with their miserable scheme when they were in office, they will see that their home deposit assistance program assisted only 82,000 families up until the time this scheme was abolished. When the Government knocked it off in December 1985, only $170m had been paid out. They are the facts again. I ask honourable senators to make the comparison. It is no wonder that we have lifted the number of commencements from 105,000 to 153,000 in just two years.

Some reference has been made to interest rates. I wish to set the matter straight as far as what exists at the moment and what happened under the former Government. The housing loan interest rate for savings banks is now 13 1/2 per cent. In the December quarter of 1981-82 interest rates for savings bank housing loans were 12 1/2 per cent. In the March quarter of 1981-82 interest rates rose to 13 1/2 per cent and stayed that way for four consecutive quarters. We are now into the second quarter of the period in which interest rates are at a peak of 13 1/2 per cent. I believe that there is every indication that those interest rate figures will come down in the foreseeable future. I am fortified by quite a bit of long term prediction taking place, believing that interest rates will drop a number of percentage points before the middle of this year.

Despite what Senator Archer said, housing loans have increased. If we look at the 1982-83 quarters we will see that major lenders lent money for 52,000 new housing loans for the first quarter, 55,000 in the second quarter, 60,000 in the third quarter and 65,000 in the last quarter. When the Government achieved office in the March quarter of 1983 the number of housing loans rose from 55,000 to 79,000 and subsequently they varied from 81,000 to 85,000, 84,000, 80,000 and 82,000 until the December quarter of last year when the number of loans fell to 71,000; a slight reduction. Nevertheless, the overall program is working favourably for our Government. In contrast, in 1982-83 the number of housing loans for the four quarters were 52,000, 55,000, 60,000 and 65,000. In the December quarter last year 71,000 housing loans were granted.

When we talk about private housing we see that the inept economic policies of the Fraser Government cut private dwelling approvals to a record low at the end of 1982. The approvals dropped to 8,000 in the last quarter and they are currently around 11,000 for the last quarter for which we have figures. This indicates the priority which the Liberals gave to housing. In contrast, the Hawke Government re-negotiated the Commonwealth-State housing agreement and doubled the funds in one year. We introduced the first home owners scheme which led to a dramatic recovery in the housing sector.

The Opposition's motion criticises, among other things, the capital gains tax. Of course, the Liberals have been very upset by the correction of an anomaly that existed and developed under the Liberal Government where people did not pay a fair share of tax and there was no adequate coverage of people who took all their profit in capital gains. That certainly distorted our economy. The Government's capital gains tax-despite the Opposition's claim that there is some confusion-is very clear. The tax has been outlined already in the draft white paper and anybody who can read should know the essential details of that tax. It will have little or no impact on rental housing. Firstly, it applies to real capital gains. In Sydney for the past five years there has been no real rise in house prices. Therefore, the capital gains tax will not apply. Secondly, the fact that losses on rental properties can be carried forward and offset against future profits means that no one will be affected by capital gains on rental housing.

The abolition of negative gearing may have an initial impact. Its essential aim will be to rid the market of speculators. Negative gearing is essentially a rort. I disagree with Senator Archer, because I believe that negative gearing has been a way in which people have artificially avoided tax. We have allowed doctors, lawyers, pilots and all sorts of other people not to pay taxation. Ordinary wage and salary earners are sick and tired of subsidising people in a scheme such as negative gearing as it applied to the building industry.
Senator Archer referred to six or seven proposals of the Liberal Party. Many people may not understand the final paragraph of the motion, which states:
(e) destabilising the finance market by artificial and sectoral constraints which will have long-term detrimental effects on home ownership funding.

Of course, that is the sting in the motion, because it relates to the Liberal Party's policy of deregulation. The motion does not put it as clearly as the Liberal Party's platform in which, under a rather strange heading `Goal Two: Encouraging Families' and a sub-heading `Home Ownership', the key provision of the Liberal Party's housing program states:
As such, further deregulation of our financial market will play a vital role.

That is the goal of the Liberal Party. John Olsen, the South Australian Liberal leader, knows that the deregulation goal of the Liberal Party is an own goal; a goal which John Howard kicked against his own side when he introduced this deregulation idea when he was in South Australia; a place where people could test out the deregulation idea on a rather doctrinaire and unbalanced people, to take some words out of the Opposition's motion. It is doctrinaire and unbalanced to believe that home owners should be subject to all the expressions of the market which represent vast repayment increases in the home loans of ordinary people. In criticising the motion, I do not know whether I should refer to Senator Archer's comments, when he said that the Government in some ways was gung ho, racing ahead like the Titanic. I did not quite get what he meant by that. But if ever there were a policy that was gung ho, doctrinaire, unbalanced and racing ahead like the Titanic-I defer to the Opposition's knowledge of bottom of the harbour matters-its policy would be. It is unacceptable, doctrinaire and unbalanced. I use as an authority a statement by Mr Shield in this morning's Sydney Daily Telegraph where Mr Shield expressed a view on behalf of the St George Building Society in an article headed `Society hits out over loan funds'. The article states:
St George Building Society accused major banks of withholding funds for home lending and claimed that they had lost the purpose for which they were developed-to lend for housing.
The article continues:
Mr Shield, expressing the Society's opposition to any move to deregulate home lending, said banks would raise interest rates on home loans by 3 per cent if the ceiling was removed.
This would add about $100 a month to average repayments.
Mr Shield said plans by the banks to defer the effects of higher interest rates meant people would never be able to pay off their home loans.

Mr Shield, of the St George Building Society, pointed out that it will mean $100 per month more on an average home repayment or, alternatively, home repayments will go on for many years more under the proposed Liberal-type policy that Senator Archer has supported here today. When we look at what that would do to the same people for whom Senator Archer was crying crocodile tears we realise just how serious it is. For example, what would happen to home loan repayments if the ceiling were not maintained? The impact of a one per cent rise in interest rates on a $50,000 home loan would be significant. Information provided by the St George Building Society indicates the impact of a one per cent rise in interest rates on a 25-year repayment period of a $50,000 home loan. Present interest repayments on a $50,000 loan at 15 per cent over a period of 25 years currently stand at $604.42 per month. If the same loan were secured at 16 per cent and monthly repayments remained the same, the period of repayment would stretch beyond 50 years. In short, it would be impossible to repay the loan under those conditions. However, if repayments were raised to $668 a month it would take a period of 47.8 years to repay the $50,000 loan. That is the situation we would have under the deregulated scheme that has been advocated by Mr Howard for the Opposition and repeated in this chamber by Senator Archer.

My personal view, of course, is that the banks have grown rich on the backs of the home buyers. Last year they recorded profits which totalled $1 billion. They should now be prepared to be socially responsible. The answer to the current dilemma facing the housing industry is not to remove the ceiling but to reduce interest rates and introduce innovative new packages to attract funds into housing, such as the recently announced rental housing trust. Succumbing to bank pressure and lifting the ceiling would only jeopardise the housing industry, cut jobs in all areas of the economy and eliminate home ownership aspirations for hundreds of thousands of Australians. I know that the Government, the Minister for Housing, Mr West, and the Prime Minister are very concerned about the current situation in this country and they are making every effort to ensure that, if there is any short term problem, it will certainly be addressed by this Government.

I would like to refer to paragraph (c) of the motion moved by Senator Archer on behalf of the Opposition because it refers to public housing. I think I should mention this for the record so that those people who are listening to this debate might realise that the Fraser-Howard Government cut the amount of funds for public housing in real terms by two-thirds. If the level of funding had been maintained, an extra 15,000 homes would have been built in New South Wales alone. So that is the price we had to pay in New South Wales for the effects of the cutting of public housing funds by the Fraser Government. Australia-wide there are now 150,000 people on waiting lists for public housing. I am very concerned about that and I know the Government is. These people are the victims of the disastrous Fraser-Howard period of Government, which forced up unemployment and ignored housing needs. We have had a herculean task to try to redress the situation that we inherited from that Government.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I would just like to remind you and honourable senators that Australian families are now in very good hands as far as housing in this country is concerned. The Government has a program that it is preparing for the Budget and I am absolutely certain that it will act before that if it is necessary. I believe that we have shown that we do not have a doctrinaire and unbalanced program, but this is certainly the record of the Liberal Howard-Fraser regime of the past. The Opposition has adopted an even more doctrinaire and unbalanced program which relies for its success on the law of the jungle, the law of deregulation and the prevention of the protection of home payments that people have had under this Government.

As I have said, the State Liberals in South Australia have learnt what this means in practice. They have been defeated by Mr Howard's doctrinaire and unbalanced approach and Mr Howard's popularity is reflected in the way that the Australian people see these policies. The wisest thing for the Opposition to do would be, in shame, to withdraw this motion. The wisest thing for it to do would be to examine genuinely the housing problems and to strike out that platform point in which it proposes to deregulate the housing industry as it would make so many Australians suffer.

speech.speaker: Haines Sen J.

talk.start.para: —Today we have before us a motion which centres on the problems in the housing industry, ranging from issues such as interest rates through to the decline in the availability of rental housing and presumably also the decline in the number of approvals being given for home loans. During the debate Senator Archer said that there was so much wrong with housing that it was hard to know where to start. I can give Senator Archer a couple of pointers in that direction. He could start with what happened during the last years of the Fraser Government. He could start, if he wanted to, with the fact that the banks are making record profits. Indeed, Australian banks are among the most profitable organisations in the world; yet they are still demanding the right to make even greater profits, regardless of whatever social responsibilities one might believe they should have. If neither of those two positions suits him he can come back to the fact that we have in power at the moment a conservative Labor Government which has a string of broken promises behind it, not the least of which is the promise to double public housing stock in the first 10 years of its existence. That promise looks like going much the same way as its promise to provide 20,000 new child care places in an even smaller amount of time.

speech.para: It is interesting that Senator Archer did not make these same sorts of criticisms about high interest rates and the problems that they were causing in the community back in 1981-82 when, under the previous Fraser Government, interest rates rose almost monthly until they reached what I guess is an equal record high with this Government's limit of 13 1/2 per cent in June 1982. Undoubtedly, that was also a factor in the Fraser Government's defeat at the 1983 election. But Senator Archer was not concerned with hitting out at the monetary policies of the Fraser Government in those years, nor of blaming the Federal Government then for the fact that interest rates were going sky high and were causing enormous pressures, not only on the building industry in Australia but also on ordinary Australian families, their security and the security of other industries peripheral to those of the building industry and the housing market. In 1982 he was blaming not the Federal Government, but State government and local government policies and their zoning methods.

I suggest that in looking at two years in which housing interest rates hit 13.5 per cent, when people are facing forced sales, are unable to get loans, when rental housing in the private market is rocketing and public housing is diminishing rapidly, Senator Archer should be consistent in his criticism. Certainly I intend to be. I criticised the Government then for its blinkered policy, for not accepting the fact that housing loans, the buildings and furnishings that flow from those loans are an important factor in the economy. They are a major part of people's plans for their future and their family's future.

It is not accidental that problems in the housing area affect elections. If one looks at a sine curve of what has been happening over the last few years, one sees that when housing interest rates go up and approvals for dwellings go down and an election occurs, the Government in power inevitably loses. It certainly happened with the Fraser Government. If the current Hawke Government does not do something about the matter quickly, I suggest that it should not contemplate an early election, because it will need all the time it can get before people realise that it is not a government that is committed to the needs of people at all, despite its rhetoric to the contrary.

Access to housing, both privately owned and public, is regarded very highly by the electorate. No matter what other issues politicians push or like to pretend are important, that issue alone will frequently dictate how people vote. There is no doubt that it happened in the 1980 election when Malcolm Fraser won, because interest rates were considerably less than they were a few years later and housing approvals were considerably higher. In fact, housing approvals in 1979-80 had leapt to an almost record level of just over 145,000 from a figure of 127,000 only 12 months previously. Housing interest rates at the time ranged between 9 1/4 and 10 1/2 per cent. That was a significant factor in the successful election of the Fraser Government in 1980. Unfortunately, interest rates began to rise almost immediately after that election, going from 10 1/2 per cent in late 1980 to 11 1/2 per cent in mid-1981 and to 12 1/2 per cent at the end of that same year, hitting the peak of 13 1/2 per cent-the same peak we have now-in the middle of 1982. At the same time, housing loan approvals were dropping, reaching a decade low of just over 116,000 by the financial year 1982-83.

When one combines high interest rates, inaccessibility of housing loans and, hence, limited housing loan approvals, one finishes up with a very disgruntled electorate. Other issues tend to take very much a back seat when people are worried about their security, the roof over their heads, and how they can pay for other necessary items when increasing mortgage repayments are eating into their family budgets and when their family security is genuinely in jeopardy.

It was not surprising that in the 1983 election Malcolm Fraser and the Liberal coalition Government was resoundingly beaten. By 1984 interest rates had dropped to 12 1/2 per cent, housing loan approvals had risen to almost 151,000. Again not surprisingly, by the time the 1984 election came around the Government that had produced the drop in interest rates and the increase in housing loan approvals was returned to power. Eighteen months later, unfortunately, we have a situation that is very much reminiscent of what faced the Fraser Government in 1982-83-rising interest rates which equal the Fraser Government's record level and housing loan approvals which are dropping.

If anybody needs a more recent indication that the question of housing and access to housing and to reasonably priced loans is an electoral issue, he can turn his mind back to the 1985 South Australian State election, when the Liberals' popularity plummeted after the Liberal Leader federally, and to a lesser extent the Liberal Leader in South Australia, had trumpeted that what was necessary was deregulation in the housing loan market. Most of the electorate can add up and most people, particularly in the mortgage belts, realised that they would be significantly worse off under deregulation. Even if people cannot remember what had happened back in the deregulation period of the previous Fraser Government, they are certainly capable of working out that deregulation means that the ceiling comes off and that before too long 13 1/2 per cent will be a fond memory.

The Government has done nothing to ameliorate this problem through any other measures. It has not increased the amount of money it has contributed to the public housing sector. It has made some attempt through rental subsidy schemes to assist those people who are in the private rental market, but when one considers that that is an extremely expensive place to be and that the supplementary rent assistance goes only to those people who are already on pensions, one realises that there is a large percentage of the community who are not being catered for by a government which is allegedly committed to social justice, social welfare and social issues generally. If Senator Archer wants to know where to start, I suggest he go back to the problems facing the Fraser Government in 1982-83.

The problem is compounded by the attitude taken by the banks. Senator Childs said that the private banking sector is pressuring the current Government to do something. I would go so far as to say that the private banks are attempting to blackmail this Government into doing something. I find it outrageous that one sector of the private business community can seek to blackmail a government into correcting the damage that that sector's predatory behaviour has caused to another section of the private sector-namely, the building industry. I find it extraordinary to hear people on the one hand complaining about excessive government expenditure and arguing that this should be cut back in the interests of the national economy and national development, and then screaming that the Government should deregulate interest rates so that profits can go even higher. They then on the other hand demand that the Government do something to subsidise the building industry and those people who have need of the building industry-namely, those who want to build a home. It is not possible to want both things and still expect one's credibility to be particularly high. The Australian banking community has been making record profits for the last few years. According to an article in the Australian Financial Review in November last year, the first half of 1985 saw the National Australia Bank lift net profit 32.3 per cent to $144.9m while Westpac's earnings grew 29.2 per cent to $185.4m. The article further said:
Both banks enjoyed-
and that is their verb, `enjoyed'-
good margins and deposit growth during the half, to March 31.
The article went on to say:
Annual growth of savings bank deposits in the year to September grew 7.3 per cent, compared with 10.8 per cent in the year to September 1984.

Other newspaper articles since then have indicated that it is not just those two banks that are making significant and record profits, but others as well. A few days later, again in the Australian Financial Review, we read that the Commonwealth Bank, in the year to June, had an increase of 24 per cent in its profits; and the National Australia Bank was referred to again, as was Westpac's after tax earnings figure, which was shown as having grown by 20.2 per cent to $367.6m in the year to 30 September. Furthermore, the rate of increase in profitability for banks was higher than for any other industry in Australia. For them to turn around and claim that they need assistance because their loans area for housing is not making the same sort of profits as other areas is ludicrous. The banks' housing loan areas are making a profit; they are just not making as big a profit as everywhere else. I would have thought that it would be incumbent upon those organisations to be prepared to offset their large profit areas against their lower profit areas. Nobody is expecting them to make a loss. At the moment they are still making significant profits and should not be grasping for more.

I think that those of us who are concerned about the sort of debate we have before us today, the sort of problem that Senator Archer has raised in his notice of motion, should be starting from the position that most Australians deserve a roof over their heads-either the assistance they need to own their own home or the concerned assistance from governments to put them into the public housing sector until they can afford to purchase their own homes, assuming that they so wish. It is time, too, that people remembered that governments in fact subsidise private home ownership to a much greater extent than they subsidise people in the public housing sector. Notwithstanding that fact, we have something like another 700,000 householders being forced into poverty because of the high cost of their housing and a government which is not prepared to put into motion measures that will help it to keep the election promise that it made to double the proportion of public housing stock in its first 10 years in office.

The simple fact of the matter is that State housing authorities have not been provided with adequate funding levels to meet the demand for public housing. The Federal Government is aware of this fact. Its own research tells it what the problems are and the fact that there is something like-from memory-159,000 unsatisfied applications for people to go into the public housing sector. We must remember that these unsatisfied applications are coming from the very lowest economic sector in the community, the group which needs the most assistance if poverty is not to become rife in this country.

Assuming, then, that we start from a position that most Australians are entitled to a roof over their heads, whether privately owned or not, we have to realise that a deregulated free market approach to housing will achieve neither of those things. In a deregulated economy, investment obviously will flow to the areas where there is the highest return, the highest profit opportunities and the highest profit margin. It will not go into the areas of greatest social priority. I repeat: Governments of all persuasions need to look back over the last 10 years and remember what happens at elections when the electorate feels threatened, insecure and uncertain about how to provide for itself and its families. The question then, I would suggest, is not whether government interference is needed to house all Australians in an affordable manner. It is, I suggest, a question of how best to assist or subsidise Australians into affordable, quality housing. So far, neither the previous Fraser Government nor the current Hawke Government has been prepared to make housing the priority that it deserves to be. Again I say that the Government will continue down that track at its electoral cost.

There has been some talk today about the fact that the Government's tax policies are likely to cause havoc and insecurity in the market and that that, indeed, is being seen already. Those people who are complaining about the fact that a highly equitable and rather watered-down capital gains tax will destroy the housing market are really living in some odd sort of cloud-cuckoo-land. For a start, it is a very limited form of capital gains tax. Secondly, why is it affecting people so dramatically if, as they believe, it will drive the current Government out of office? If it drives the current Government out of office, presumably the Howard Liberal Party will come into office and, equally presumably, it will take away this allegedly iniquitous capital gains tax.

All the astute business people in the world cannot be thinking too far down the track if they are panicking over what is effectively a pathetic capital gains tax package. Also, as far as the negative gearing proposals are concerned, I wonder why we all think it appropriate that the best way of providing cheaper rental accommodation is to provide a tax incentive to those who are on the highest marginal tax rates, because they are on the highest incomes. It seems like a double inequity to go about it that way. Why must we subsidise the wealthiest people in the community in order to provide private rental accommodation so that those on lower incomes can get a roof over their heads? Why do we not, for example, look at the British system of providing taxation assistance, which is across the board and non-discriminatory, and which seems to be housing at least as high a percentage of the British population as we do of ours and which, even more importantly, is keeping interest rates down?

If outright tax deductibility or partial tax deductibility of interest rates does not suit the Government's purposes at the moment, it should look again, I suggest, at a scheme we suggested some five years ago-a scheme which would encourage Australian savers to put their money into building society and savings bank accounts paying less than top interest rates. At the moment, Australian taxpayers go looking for the highest possible interest rate that they can get for savings, because they know that they are going to lose a significant portion of interest in taxation. Why do we not do away with all sorts of inequitable assistance and subsidies, such as the negative gearing proposal on the one end of the scale and the first home owners scheme on the other, and instead look to encouraging people to put their money in bank and building society savings accounts paying, say, less than 10 per cent per annum, and to encourage them to do that, offer-do more than offer; legislate, because it is necessary, after all to legislate for this-legislate so that the first $1,000 of any interest they earn on that money is not taxed? People who put their savings in an account paying, for example, 10 per cent, who do not have to pay tax on the first $1,000 of interest they earn, will get an effective rate of just over 14 per cent. It would give the banks a pool of lower interest money on which to draw for equally low interest rate housing loans. It would certainly take away any excuse to cry poor and weep crocodile tears all over various government's heads as banks attempt to blackmail governments into letting them have a free rein in the market-place whilst shoring up the very seriously damaged building industry.

We need to remember too that it is not just the building industry that suffers when housing loans figures go down. For every house that is built, carpets, curtains and white goods are bought; everything from large items to shrubs and lawn seeds are bought. There is a tremendous ripple effect in the community from the purchase or building of a home.

talk.start.para: —It started to ripple.

—Yes, it started to ripple in 1982 and rippled the Fraser Government right out of office. If this Government is not careful precisely the same thing will happen to it, although where the electorate has to go I am not sure. At the moment it seems to believe its only choice is between an inept Labor government that sort of promises to take social issues into account but does not and a deregulation-spouting Liberal Government that can, at the very best, promise rocketing interest rates and an increase in the problem.

speech.para: We need to be aware of the fact that not only is there a significant positive impact in the business community for every house which is built, but also there is an equally serious and significant impact in those same industries when people are forced to sell their homes or are not able to get loans to build them in the first place. It is not surprising to see that there is a significant amalgamation in certain industrial areas, such as the whitegoods area and so on, because demand is simply not as high as it could or should be.

Senator Archer's motion is worthy of debate. The issues certainly need to be aired. Solutions need to be canvassed. It is sad that it is five years since I first proposed across the board assistance to people to encourage them to use savings bank accounts and building society accounts so that those institutions could lend at lower rates than they currently do.

We are still on a path to a housing crisis which could well cause a general social crisis if it is not ended. Interest rates must come down. Housing loans must increase. Banks will have to accept the fact that they simply cannot use the community to make massive profits without giving something back. This Government has to be aware of following the same track to electoral defeat that the previous Fraser Government went down. The only way that it can avoid that is by accepting the responsibility that it has to the Australian electorate, the community generally and families in particular.

speech.speaker: Reid Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —Senator Haines said that the motion is worthy of debate. It certainly is. It is more than that. It is absolutely essential that we look at the plight of many Australians as they face problems with housing. Despite all the facts and figures that are given, talk of bank profits and everything else that we have heard, the reality is that human beings, families, need to house themselves and want homes. Many of them want to own their own home but are not able to do so. For that reason it was disappointing that the first Australian Labor Party speaker to contribute to the debate dealt very much with matters of historical interest. Many of them are good points worthy of debate and capable of challenge. But what of the future and what of the people who are now in difficulties with housing and who are unable to obtain housing?

speech.para: The previous Labor speaker, near the end of his speech, indicated that the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) are concerned about the situation. I was encouraged to hear that. I would have hoped they would be a great deal more than concerned, because I certainly am. In a wide-ranging review of the past, that speaker hit upon one figure and boasted that the present industrial relations figures were the best in 17 years. Of course, he was talking about strike action. Presumably the figures that he was looking at are accurate. What people do not bother to take into account when looking at this matter are the number of bans placed on work at present. It is a fairly new thing. The concept of work bans has happened quite recently. The effect on the economy is just as bad as that of strikes, but somehow people do not really keep track of the number of days lost through work bans. If we added the number of days and the number of jobs affected by work bans, the figure would be very different. I do not need to quote the old saying about figures and what they can do, but in this instance there is no doubt.

I have kept a chart in my office from December 1984 until February 1986 and just in the Australian Capital Territory there have been 77 incidents-very few of them were strikes, but they were significant work bans-that have had a great effect on sections of this community. We should hear no more of that sort of nonsense and manipulation of figures in the industrial scene by not comparing things that, in reality, are similar.

Undoubtedly the housing industry is an important part of the economy. If it goes down there is a recession; if it goes up there is a resurgence. It certainly went up after this Government came in, but it was artificially propped up with public funds. But other significant things were not controlled. The cost of housing escalated. Interest rates escalated and the sorts of economic decisions which should have been made and which would have kept these at different levels were not made, with the inevitable consequences which are now occurring. Home ownership is fast moving out of the reach of many Australians. It has always been prized as an important aspect of Australian life, certainly by the Liberal Party and more recently by the Labor Party. The Labor Party introduced the first home owners scheme when it came into office and put money into housing and the creation of jobs in the housing industry. But the interesting thing to look at is what has actually happened to the Australian dream over the years.

In some respects to compare Singapore and the United Kingdom with Australia is a distortion. However, Singapore went from a home ownership rate of 22 per cent to 62 per cent between 1966 and 1985. In a similar period, the United Kingdom went from 47.8 per cent to 60.2 per cent. Of course, one would welcome that. In 1966 Australia was far ahead of both countries at 71.4 per cent home ownership. It had dropped and was 70.4 per cent, one percentage point down, in 1981 and it has slipped away by 0.4 per cent from then to 1985. The significance is not very great. Considering population growth during that time we are talking about a lot of families. Whatever we might say about the figures, there is a tendency downward and not upwards as one would have hoped.

People simply cannot afford to purchase homes as they have in the past. Over the past five years the gap has narrowed between the median weekly income and the average monthly loan repayment and in some States the two have merged. There was a time when 25 per cent of the single bread winner's income was regarded as about the right amount to be paid for shelter, for a home. Now, of course, one really needs two adult working wages to be able to contemplate the sort of mortgage repayments that most people in this country are now faced with, certainly if they have purchased houses in the last three years. One might well ask how they manage and how they survive.

I want to divert just a moment to refer to two or three constituent representations I have had in this area because we should not forget that it is real people and real families we are talking about. A letter which has come to me quite recently says:
I wish to bring to your notice the anomalous situation which at present prevails with regard to current interest rates . . .
She goes on:

In April last year I undertook a housing loan with a building society for $70,000 with low-start provisions, ie repayments start 4 per cent below the current level and increasing by half a per cent each year. However in the last eleven months, because of the increases in interest rates, my repayments have increased five times, from $579 per month to $747. In the event of any lowering of interest rates my repayments will NOT be decreased. This sort of increase, for which I was not given any warning whatsoever, in such a short period of time makes a mockery of any sort of budgeting. As a divorced parent with a nine-year-old son with an income $25,264 I am at the point of having to sell at a loss as the loan repayments are becoming prohibitive.

That is a quite reasonable salary. It is not the lower end of the salary range, but she is in the position where she is considering selling her house. She has sent me a copy of a Press release relating to the tax concessions which were provided in Western Australia during the time of the election there. She refers to that and she concludes by saying:
