The present instability in interest rates, besides doing irreparable harm to countless numbers of ordinary hard-working citizens like myself, will certainly grow into a serious political handicap as so many people are affected.

She asked what could be done. I raised a similar matter in the Senate on 4 December 1985 when I incorporated in Hansard a letter I had received from a constituent in similar vein relating to a house she had purchased in December 1984 for herself and her two dependent children. She set out the way that her payments had increased-of course, her repayments would have gone up again since then-and she set out in detail her financial situation. She also, on a similar sort of salary, was faced as she saw it with the prospect of having to sell her house. All these people who have to sell their houses will be looking for rental accommodation which also is now not available or they will have to join the ever-increasing queue of people looking for public housing.

Yet another letter was from a single woman who lives in Kambah and who purchased a house for $79,000, borrowed $60,000 12 months ago and the repayments on the easy start basis were to have been $505 a month. She is now paying $655 a month for her house. As the other writer said, it makes a mockery of budgeting when that sort of thing can happen.

We are talking about real people's lives which are affected. In the Australian Capital Territory, of course, in addition to all this we had the complete fiasco of the Commissioner for Housing loans scheme a couple of years ago-I have dealt with that before and it has been aired several times so I shall not go into the details of that-when people were significantly affected by the collapse of the scheme and were not able to buy houses. Many of those who had been on the list at the time and who believed they would have got loans stayed on the list and 12 months later, when the scheme started off again, found that under the new rules they were no longer eligible. Can honourable senators imagine how the people who were left in that situation felt?

It is not only those who own homes or those who wish to own homes who are particularly affected. The rental market is also in chaos. The investors in rental properties by and large are ordinary people who are indulging in forced savings to try to get ahead a bit. They are not the big investors, as the Government seems to think. Interest rates have affected them. They are affected by the withdrawal of the negative gearing provision and they are affected by the threatened capital gains tax. Many of those properties are now on the market which means there will be fewer rental properties available for people to purchase. If the Government does not wish to persist with those tax schemes which it is abolishing, it will need to think of some way of encouraging rental accommodation in the market-place or else there will be more and more people without housing.

It is not just the wealthy people who are in the business of renting. As Senator Archer said, there are a lot of people who, for a time, come by properties. A parent may die and leave it to them. There are a number of reasons why people have a house and rent it, but now it will not be worth their while to do so. This has contributed already to the incredible demands being made on public housing. In my own electorate, over 25 per cent of the constituent contact which I receive relates to housing problems, either in terms of mortgage repayments, the need for rental accommodation and not being able to get it at a price they can afford and problems within the welfare housing area. Of course, there are those who do not fit within the means test of the welfare housing area and who cannot afford the rate which is applicable at the time because of the drying up of the market.

At present Canberra has a slightly higher percentage of rental accommodation available than some other parts of Australia, and it is bad enough here. There were 143,000 applications for public rental housing at 30 June 1985. Senator Childs, the Australian Labor Party senator who spoke before me, referred to the public rental housing list. He seems not to have heard of the actual growth in that list over the last six months. He did not mention anything that happened more than three years ago. I was going to suggest that the figure had grown in that six months to 156,000 people but Senator Haines just referred to the number as 159,000 people awaiting public housing at present. Whichever figure is correct, it is alarming to know that in six months that number has been added to that list.

When one talks about housing one cannot escape looking at unemployment. With the high unemployment-8 per cent-one can be certain that a very large number of those people are on the list for public housing. There is no possibility that they would be able to afford any other type of housing. Those who have been unemployed for a long time have no prospect of being able to purchase or retain a home for which they have to make mortgage repayments. The facts speak for themselves in respect of this Government's answerability in the employment area.

In 1970 to 1972 the average rate of unemployment was 1.3 per cent. During the next three years, peaking in 1975 at 3.1 per cent, the average was 1.9 per cent. During the period 1976 to 1982 it rose to 5.8 per cent and in these last three years it has risen to an average of 9.1 per cent. It is presently at a rate of over 8 per cent. The Government cannot escape from its responsibility in the area of those who are unemployed and, as a consequence, the growing number of people who are looking for public housing and who are suffering. Families are not able to obtain the type of accommodation that they are entitled to be able to expect to obtain for themselves and their children. As a consequence of having to move frequently, their children are dragged from one school to another and their education is disrupted. The total consequence of unemployment and not being able to have stable housing is absolutely enormous. It puts a great strain on parents and marriages. It does not give children the start in life they are entitled to have. The Government must consider the economic policies it is pursuing and address their consequences. The end result is that they affect the lives of people in this country. I have referred to the wage that is now needed to provide shelter. It is regrettable that it is necessary for two parents to work to purchase a home. I have no objection to both mothers and fathers working. I encourage it, as long as people are, as a consequence, enjoying and enriching their lives. If they work merely to provide shelter and the pressures are totally economic, it is time the situation is looked at.

We hear about the ceiling of 13.5 per cent on housing loans. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) was on television some weeks ago-I think in February-and referred to wage earners being protected by the 13.5 per cent ceiling. I received a number of telephone calls that evening and the next day. Some of my constituents were so incensed as to suggest that the Treasurer had lied. Strictly speaking, the Treasurer was correct in what he said. But to talk about a 13.5 per cent interest rate ceiling on mortgage repayments is an absolute joke to the constituents out there who want home loans to purchase houses. Some money has been available at that rate. But how much can one get now, and where from? Who can get it? The people who most need money at that rate of interest cannot get it. It is a joke to them, so much so that one person suggested to me that the Treasurer had actually lied about it. That is how far from reality the Treasurer's attitude to housing loans is.

There is a crisis in housing. The situation will get worse. We are not talking down the economy. We are trying to alert the Government to the serious plight of many Australians who want to live differently from the way they live now. The Government may not feel comfortable having to acknowledge that it has to embark on economic policies which will cause interest rates to fall so that genuine people can buy homes again. The Government has to do something to encourage the provision of rental housing because-let us face it-it is better for rental housing to be provided by sources other than by government. It is much more expensive for the Government to provide it. The Government cannot ignore the fact that at least 156,000 people are on the welfare housing list at present, most of whom should not be on it. They should be able to contemplate life as owners of their own homes, able to purchase and provide for their families in the way they would want. I support the motion before the Senate.

speech.speaker: Jones Sen G.N.

talk.start.para: —First, I think we should consider the clauses in the motion moved by Senator Archer. Looking at the first clause of the motion, it is quite obvious that the motion has been put forward under a false premise. Senator Archer's motion condemns the Hawke Labor Government for:

speech.para: plunging the housing of Australian families into the worst position in 50 years by doctrinaire and unbalanced policies . . .

In considering the statement `the worst position in 50 years', it is quite easy to go through the records of this Government and the previous Government and make some comparisons which show that that statement is not the case. Clause (b) states:
creating and maintaining a high interest, high tax economy that makes home ownership an unobtainable goal for many young Australian families . . .

If we consider the statement made today by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in relation to lifting the ceiling on interest rates clause (b) does not hold water in relation to maintaining the high interest rate level Senator Archer has been speaking about. Clause (c) states:
presiding over and causing a rapid decline in the availability of rental housing causing extreme hardship to low income families in particular . . .
Clause (d) states:
creating uncertainty by not releasing after six months, details concerning taxation policy . . .
I will deal with those matters in a few moments. Clause (e) states:
destabilising the finance market by artificial and sectoral constraints which will have long-term detrimental effects on home ownership funding.

As has been pointed out by previous speakers, clause (e) shows very clearly that the Liberal Party of Australia is talking about deregulation. It argues against clause (b), which talks about high interest rates, because deregulation would cause a situation where not just good or great profits would be made by the banking institutions and lending authorities for housing, but enormous profits would be made. It seems to me that honourable senators opposite agree with some of the remarks made by the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia during the election campaign; they support the deregulation proposition.

To set the record straight, particularly in relation to the first clause of the motion, we ought to consider the access to housing and compare this Government's record with the previous Government's record. In 1983 industry activity was at an all time low. The 105,000 new dwellings commenced in 1982-83 represented a 20-year low. In other words, it was the lowest level for 20 years. Access to home ownership was declining. It was declining for a number of reasons, including high interest rates-which I think one of the previous speakers spoke about-and increased housing prices, which excluded many low income householders from home ownership. It was very clear to everyone that they were the problems at that time. The Hawke Government decided that a range of initiatives should be introduced to ensure an adequate supply of affordable housing for the community. Policies set by the Hawke Government were aimed at restoring confidence amongst home buyers, increasing the availability of housing finance, providing more effective assistance to first home buyers, increasing the supply of housing through the public sector and increasing the assistance available to needy private renters.

To achieve these goals, a number of specific campaigns and policies were initiated by the Government. One of the actions taken by the Government was to make access to home ownership easier. The Government increased assistance to first home buyers. One of the effects of the introduction of the first home owners scheme on 1 October 1983 was that the saving eligibility criterion was removed from the home deposit assistance scheme to ensure that assistance helped people into home ownership, rather than merely rewarding them for having a good saving record. It was a worthwhile action by the Government to remove that provision and allowed for a good saving record, rather than allowing people an increase in the deposit or amount of money they needed to move into a home.

The Government introduced the first home owners scheme on 1 October 1983, recognised as being the most effective housing assistance scheme ever. It is quite clear to everyone listening to this debate that the first home owners scheme provided the finance which allowed a large number of people in the community to gain the deposits they required to find their way into their first homes. There was also an increase in the funding for public housing. The Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement was renegotiated to remove all the inequities of previous agreements and to ensure a guaranteed base for the level of funding. If we look at the table of figures for the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement we find that in 1980-81, $437.5m was set aside for Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement funding. In 1985-86, the Government of the day-the Hawke Government-allowed nearly 50 per cent more, or $654.4m. In other words, 50 per cent more Commonwealth money was made available under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. That 50 per cent increase certainly went a long way towards allowing the States to make an increase in the funding available for housing. If one were to look to go through the various States, one would see that during that period there was an increase in housing activity.

At this stage it is worth while to run very quickly through some of the statistics for the housing industry. In 1984-85 there were 152,700 commencements, which was a record 11-year high. In other words we can compare that figure with the 1982-83 figure of 105,000 commencements. By quarter, commencements dropped to 24,500 in December 1982, 25,700 in September 1982 and 25,900 in March 1983. That compares with 36,000 a quarter in 1984-85 and 37,900 in the September quarter 1985.

Strong activity is still predicted for 1985-86. A figure of 137,000 commencements is predicted by the Indicative Planning Council. If we are to set the record straight, we have to say that that figure certainly varies according to the reference at which one is looking. Other papers predict 120,000, others predict 110,000 and others 105,000. So there is some difference of opinion about whether it will be as high as 137,000 or as low as 105,000. I see that Senator Archer is nodding his head, indicating that what I am stating is correct.

We should look at the area of finance. There were 323,400 loans from major lenders in 1984-85, with a total of $12.9 billion for housing. That compares with 229,000 loans in 1981-82 with a total of $6.5 billion, and 234,000 loans in 1982-83, with a total of $7.1 billion. That shows very clearly that the Government did recognise the fact that there was a problem with housing and that it undertook steps to increase the number of loans taken out from the major lenders. The Government set up the first home owners scheme and tried to create confidence within the building industry. If one compares the figures for loans in 1984 with the figures for 1982-83, it is quite obvious that the figure of 323,400 loans from major lenders in 1984-85 was a large increase.

Since its inception 186,000 grants have been approved under the first home owners scheme. Over $867m was committed for that scheme and over $596m of that $867m has already been paid out. Under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, in 1985-86 the total amount from the Commonwealth, including nominated funds and grants, was $1.14 billion. This compares with the figures for 1982-83 of $260m in grants, $146m in loans and $145 million in nominated funds, making a total of $551m. That total compares with the 1985-86 total of $1.14 billion. In real terms that represents $654m in Federal funding compared with $363m in 1981-82. One could continue to go through the figures but I will not spend too much time doing that at this stage because I believe a number of speakers before me outlined some of the figures. But it is fairly important to emphasise the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made a renewed pledge on home loans and has said that the 13.5 per cent interest rate ceiling on bank home loans will stay. That is fairly important in the context of this debate.

talk.start.para: —It is no help if they cannot get the money.

—Let us look at the interest rate at the moment and look at what happened with interest rates under the previous Government. The Opposition is claiming at the moment that the interest rate is too high. But it has maintained itself at 13.5 per cent. If we can hold the interest rate at that level--
—There is no money.

—Let us look at the answer given by Senator Walsh today in answer to a question. He said that there is a movement in interest rates-they are starting to go down. If there is a downward movement of interest rates, some of the finance will move back across and it will be a better proposition for the lending authorities to start to lend money for housing again. I refer to an answer given to a question relating to rental housing. The question was asked by Mr Beale in the other place on 18 March 1986 and was directed to the Minister for Housing and Construction, Mr West. The Minister said:

speech.para: Let us look at what negative gearing, as it affected investment in the private rental accommodation market, meant.

That was one of the points raised by Senator Archer when he said that we were presiding over and causing a rapid decline in the availability of rental housing. That is one of the clauses in the motion put forward by Senator Archer. The Minister, in answer to the question about negative gearing and rental accommodation, said:
Let us look at what negative gearing, as it affected investment in the private rental accommodation market, meant.

It simply meant that a doctor, a Qantas pilot, or whoever, could, say, borrow half a million dollars and invest it in a block of flats, chalk up an interest repayment bill of about $80,000 a year, get about $30,000 or $40,000 in rental income from it, and then write off the other $40,000 or $50,000 at 60c in the dollar against their other income as a Qantas pilot, doctor, specialist, lawyer, barrister or whatever. The fundamental point that those honourable members opposite ought to remember is that it was the ordinary wage earners of Australia who had to pay for all that. If we want to stimulate the private rental market, we will do it by legitimate means. We have announced the quarantining of negative gearing in this area. We have also simultaneously announced, for which legislation will be introduced this session, the introduction of a 4 per cent depreciation allowance for investment in new rental property and for extensions to old rental properties.

It needs to be remembered that negative gearing has no effect on properties purchased prior to 17 July 1985. In other words, the rental market now available is not being decreased in the way that the Opposition claims. The negative gearing is not having the sort of effect that the Opposition claims on rental properties purchased prior to 17 July 1975.

Let us look at vacancy rates. One of the claims made related to rental accommodation. If we look further at the answer given by the Minister, we should be able to get some figures on vacancy rates. In talking about rental accommodation available he said:

The vacancy rate in Sydney in March 1982 was 1.7 per cent. Today Sydney is the city in conjunction with Perth where there is a fall. Sydney is tight-1.1 per cent. Let us have a look at Brisbane. Back in March 1982 Brisbane had a vacancy rate of 0.9 per cent; today, it is 4.2 per cent. The vacancy rate in Adelaide in March 1982 was one per cent; today it is 3.2 per cent. The vacancy rate in Melbourne in March 1982 was one per cent; today it is 2.2 per cent.

In other words, the Minister is saying that the only place which is really affected is probably Sydney, which has been affected by the shortage of rental accommodation. I know that there is a shortage of rental accommodation there and I know that we have not caught up that shortage. I am saying, however, that negative gearing has not had the effect that honourable senators opposite claim it has had. That is clearly shown in the figures put forward by the Minister in answer to a question in the House of Representatives.

I turn to interest rates, a subject on which we have spoken before. Senator Archer said that we were presiding over high interest rates, but let us look at what happened to interest rates under the former Government. The housing loan interest rate for savings banks is now 13 1/2 per cent. If we go back we see that in the December quarter of 1981-82 the interest rate for savings bank loans was 12 1/2 per cent. In the March quarter of 1981-82 interest rates rose to 13.5 per cent. Interest rates stayed that way for four consecutive quarters. We are now in the second quarter of the period of interest rates being at a peak of 13.5 per cent. In other words, what has happened is that there has been a slight movement in interest rates which has caused some problems for people who have purchased houses. However, we are not presiding over a period of high interest rates, as was claimed by Senator Archer, because the interest rate now is similar to the interest rate when his party was in power. What we have done is create some sort of confidence in the building industry. We have created a situation where, because of the allocation of money from our first home buyer's scheme, and because of the added money being given to the States for housing, a situation has been created in which the 26 trades allied with the building industry can perform with some sort of confidence, and can continue to build and keep up the supply of accommodation and employment in that area.

I know-certainly everyone in the Government knows-that there are some problems in the housing industry, that the Government has to look at the housing problem. What I am saying is that in actual fact the policy we have put forward up to this point has been working well. As I said before, the Indicative Planning Council has predicted that there will be 137,000 building commencements next year. There is a discussion through a number of avenues to the effect that that figure may be reduced to 105,000 or even to as low as 100,000. It remains to be seen whether that prediction of 137,000 new commencements is achieved or whether, as is predicted by some, housing commencements will fall to 105,000 or lower. That is something at which the Government is looking, about which the Government is concerned and about which the Minister for Housing and Construction is talking to the Prime Minister.

One of the things I should say in closing is that the Labor Government is concerned about housing. It is concerned about those predictions. It is concerned about the difference between the high prediction and the low prediction. The Minister for Housing and Construction, the Prime Minister, the Cabinet and members of the Government certainly are discussing what is happening and trying to create a situation in which a peak in housing commencement may be achieved, rather than the lower prediction.

speech.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: —There would be few members of this Parliament who would have a greater knowledge of the housing industry than Senator Archer. When Senator Archer brings forward a notice of motion in relation to a matter of such gravity as housing, I believe that not only the Senate but also the Government and the whole of Australia should sit up and start taking notice. I notice that each honourable senator who has spoken for the Australian Labor Party in this debate has looked into the historical situation in relation to housing and has compared statistics under a Liberal Party Government for a certain period with those under a Labor Party Government. I believe that Senator Walsh has been particularly successful in doing this in relation to other areas, and I intend to embark on the same sort of program tonight.

speech.para: If we look back to less than two years ago we notice that May building approvals were at their highest levels since 1973. This was shortly after the Labor Party took office. At that time, savings banks and trading banks also were continuing to lend strongly for housing during the month of May. Private sector house building approvals were then at their highest levels since August 1973. Total public and private sector dwelling approvals were at their highest since November 1973. However, what has happened? There has been a dramatic decline. The longer the Australian Labor Party is in power, the more serious becomes the economic malaise of this country. The higher the interest rates become, the harder it seems to be for everyday Australians to secure housing at reasonable costs.

As a party we were telling the Labor Party of this late last year. Both my colleague Senator Archer and the Opposition shadow Minister, Mr Beale, were warning the Government because the decline was becoming evident towards the end of last year. For example, the annual growth rate of deposits in January fell to 14.9 per cent, compared with 18.9 per cent in December 1985 and 22 per cent in July 1985. Let us look at particular groups that have been disadvantaged in society by the Government's high interest rate policy and its tight monetary policy. That is what is causing the problems. The government's over-concentration on monetary policies is causing Mr and Mrs Australia to go into bankruptcy to sell their homes. Let us look at one particularly disadvantaged group which has not been referred to to date. I refer to university students. Some 46 per cent of full time Melbourne University undergraduates are reported as having significant difficulties because of high rents. A similar percentage of students were spending more than 30 per cent of their income on rent.

However, there is a further problem associated not only with the government's tight monetary policy but also with the implications of negative gearing. The standard of accommodation is becoming poorer and poorer as rents become higher and higher for the disadvantaged. Therefore, while the Australian Labor Party has its ideological blinkers on in trying to attack the capitalist sector-that sector which is providing housing-it is actually disadvantaging its base support in Australian society. Because of the Government's ideological blindness in attacking one sector, it is actually disadvantaging the poor. I believe that we now have in Australia a Labor Party which is basically ideological and which has deserted its traditional base support. I believe that this is a tragedy for any party. I believe it will not be long before even the previous supporters of the Labor Party will be looking to a new party to try to look after this particular segment.

Each of the honourable senators opposite who spoke previously spent some time in attacking the Liberal's Party deregulation policies. However, under the camouflage of this sort of attack, the Labor Party, in regard to the deregulation issue, in effect is stealing a march on the Liberal Party. Its record shows that. So while the Labor Party continues to attack us openly on so-called deregulation, that party itself is stealing a march on the Liberal Party, unbeknown to the great majority of its supporters. I believe the Left should take particular note of that situation.

I mentioned earlier the wonderful situation we had for housing and the growth in savings banks deposits-the traditional base from which housing loans came. I mentioned that that growth started to dissipate late last year. If we look at the situation today, the severity of the slump facing the industry is brought to our notice very vividly by the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures which show a 14.3 per cent fall in January in the home lending market and other financial institutions. So lending for new housing is now at its lowest level since the Bureau started collecting the figures in 1975. Eighteen months ago the level was the highest since 1975 and it is now the lowest since 1975 when the Bureau started collecting figures.

talk.start.para: —That will mean that project builders will all go broke.

—As my colleague Senator Michael Baume said, not only are the borrowers going broke and having to sell their properties but also a lot of evidence is coming forward now about the builders specialising in low cost housing who are starting to go broke because they cannot pay these high interest rates. The situation is so critical that even the Minister for Housing and Construction, Mr West, has predicted that home building could decrease in the next few months because of the decrease in savings banks deposit growth due to the lower lending for new homes. This is serious.

speech.para: While it is true that the Government's 13.5 per cent ceiling on home loan interest rates is affecting the housing industry, I remind honourable senators that the housing industry is at the cutting edge of monetary policy and the importance of this industry is not being acknowledged by the Government. In November the traditional sources of housing finance were beginning to dry up. They had been drained by a continued pressure on interest rates. I believe that the Government has to take steps to try to arrest this trend. It is true that the impact of the firm monetary policy is reflected by the sharp decline in trading bank deposits and advances for January so the savings banks and trading banks are starting to dry up as depositors take funds out of these traditional areas and put them where they can earn higher rates of interest.

I believe that we have come to a crisis point. The Australian Bankers Association has decided to slash bank lending to home buyers by 40 per cent in the first half of 1986, the period we are in now and which has three and a half months to go. The Bankers Association has decided to slash lending to home buyers by 40 per cent because of the effects of the Government's tight monetary policy and high interest rate policy. Why does it have a high interest rate policy? Part of this high interest rate policy is due to the necessity to protect the Australian dollar, because the Australian Labor Party knows that if the dollar falls very much more it will lose office. It is not prepared to lose office, but it is prepared to make Mr and Mrs Australia suffer in terms of high interest rates and in terms of not making houses available to the people who can least afford them. I believe that the Government has abrogated its traditional base of support and I believe that it is a tragedy for all Australians. I conclude my speech to enable my colleague to continue this debate.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —I thank my colleague Senator Watson for leaving me a few moments in which to make a few points. Senator Watson demonstrated ably how the latest statistics show an immense fall in housing activity, particularly housing activity financed by the major lending institutions. Those figures show an approximate 25 per cent fall in dwelling units financed in January-the latest month for which figures are available-compared with January of the previous year. This means that 6,720 fewer people gained loans to purchase homes. In money terms, $271m less was spent on the purchase of dwellings in January this year than in the previous year. We should think about how that relates to jobs for people building new dwellings. The impact of that kind of housing shock on employment is overwhelming.

speech.para: Those figures have been reinforced by statistics on national income and expenditure released today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The national income figures for the December quarter, before the latest figures to which Senator Watson referred, showed that the gross fixed capital expenditure on dwellings fell, meaning that over the past 12 months of 1985 there was a 0.3 per cent fall in dwelling commencements in seasonally adjusted terms and in real terms. That is a real disaster and represents the failure of the Government's policy.

I want to develop a little homily to the Government. One would have thought that by now the Government would have realised that it can control either the supply of money or the price of money but it cannot control both. We have heard lectures from the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who obviously has no support within his Party. He has outlined this truth, but the rest of his Party simply will not accept it. As a result he was rolled-I think that is the polite expression-when he tried to teach the facts of economic life to his Party this week. The consequence of that for home seekers is absolutely disastrous. It will mean an inevitability of the continuation of falling housing purchases and falling new buildings financed by the major lenders.

The statistics are overwhelming. They show, for example, that loans to buy new dwellings fell over the 12 months to January by 30 per cent and loans for existing dwellings fell by 25 per cent, pushing the total number of housing loans down to the lowest level for three years. I remind the Senate that that was the level which existed in the middle of a recession and a major drought, at a time when one could hardly say that Australia was prospering. We have heard those opposite continually trying to blame us for that situation. Now, at a time when we are supposed to be recovering and Australia is supposed to be expanding under its dynamic management, those opposite have pushed this figure back down to the level that it was in the middle of an enormous recession produced by the worst drought we have had since World War II and a world-wide recession. This is supposed to be a successful government policy relating to housing. What a pathetic effort.

The real crunch has come as a result of the Government's refusal to accept economic reality about interest rates. There has been a severe 35 per cent fall in the past 12 months in loans at the regulated end of the market-savings banks and building societies-but lending at the non-regulated, dearer end of the market has gone up by 12 per cent in the past year. One cannot borrow cheap money but one can borrow dear money, and that is a direct consequence of this Government's policies. I hope that all home seekers in Australia recognise that the drought of cheap money from the building societies, and particularly from the savings banks, is a direct consequence of governmental policy. Holding down housing interest rates only reduces the amount of money available at controlled levels, pushes people into higher cost loans and leaves home seekers worse off. There is no doubt that interest rates on cocktail loans, if I can call them that-loans where people can get only a little bit of their money at low interest rates and have to depend on the rest from the general market, financed at enormously high interest rates-will work out far higher than if the savings bank loan rates were deregulated.

debate.title: PROTECTION OF THE SEA (PREVENTION OF POLLUTION FROM SHIPS) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

proctext.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a first time.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to enable coverage of all ships in the territorial sea and coastal waters of Australia by Federal marine pollution legislation. It represents a further step in the legislative process leading to the ratification by Australia of the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973, as amended by the Protocol of 1978. The Convention and Protocol, often referred to as MARPOL 73/78, will be implemented chiefly by the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983.

The Bill for that Act passed through the Parliament during the Autumn sittings in 1983 with bipartisan support. It was essentially the same as one introduced by the former Government, which lapsed as a result of the dissolution of Parliament.

The purpose of the MARPOL Convention is to control operational discharges of oil and other harmful substances from ships and to minimise the possibility of accidental discharges of such substances. In practical terms the aim of early Australian ratification is to prohibit discharges of oil and noxious chemicals within the Great Barrier Reef Region and other areas protected by the Convention. It will also allow Australia to enforce more stringent construction and operating standards on visiting ships, for example, segregated ballast tank and crude oil washing requirements.

The Government is committed to giving effect to international conventions in the transport field and related areas involving the protection of the environment. Our policy calls for the promotion of ``. . . the conclusion, ratification and application of transport conventions under the auspices of the United Nations and its specialised agencies''.

Australia has an extensive coastline and spread of territorial waters. It is fundamentally important that we be able to demonstrate to ourselves and the international community that we take our responsibility for this national and global resource seriously, and that we are committed to its protection. This is especially the case in relation to the Great Barrier Reef for which special provision is made in the MARPOL Convention itself.

The MARPOL Convention represents only one aspect, though an extremely important one, of the Government's commitment to give effect to international conventions promoted by the International Maritime Organization (IMO).

As honourable senators will be aware, the IMO is a specialised agency of the United Nations, concerned with promoting the safety of shipping and the protection of the marine environment. Its main objective is to provide a forum for co-operation among its members and to develop appropriate legislation and practices.

Australia is a foundation member of the Organization and has been active in developing many Conventions. It has recently been elected to the Council of the IMO. The Hawke Government's active participation in the Organization's work is demonstrated by Australia becoming party to the following Conventions.
International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea, 1974 and its 1978 Protocol;
the 1983 Amendment to the International Convention on Load Lines 1966;

the International Convention Relating to Intervention on the High Seas in Cases of Oil Pollution Casualties, 1969 and the Protocol Relating to Intervention on the High Seas in Cases of Pollution by Substances other than Oil, 1973;
the International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage, 1969 and its 1976 Protocol;
the International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Seafarers, 1978;
the International Convention of Maritime Search and Rescue, 1979; and
the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter, 1972.
It is important that Australia remains in the forefront of international initiatives relating to the protection of the marine environment. This object can be achieved by supporting the Bill.

In my second reading speech of 4 May 1983 on the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Bill, I noted the jurisdictional arrangements recommended by the then Marine and Ports Council of Australia. These arrangements required the enactment of complementary Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory legislation before Australia could ratify MARPOL.

Let me now turn to the Bill itself. As I have previously stated its sole object is to enable the early Australian implementation of the MARPOL Convention by extending the Federal marine pollution legislation to cover all ships in the territorial sea and the sea on the landward side of the territorial sea.

This section has become necessary because of the significant and continuing delay which has occurred in the enactment of the complementary State and Territory legislation which is at present needed to enable the implementation of this Convention.

I can assure the Senate that the present Bill does not infringe the rights of any State or Territory because it contains a saving provision which will ensure that the Commonwealth legislation will not apply when appropriate State or Territory legislation is in force to cover areas within the relevant jurisdiction.

I must make it clear that State and Territory Ministers responsible for Transport and Marine matters have been kept informed of these developments through their membership of the Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC).

When ATAC met at Canberra on 10 April 1985, the Federal Minister for Transport informed Ministers that, if complementary legislation was not in place by the end of 1985, the Commonwealth would legislate to implement the Convention. This statement followed a series of requests that the Minister had made at previous meetings and in correspondence with Ministers that their legislation be enacted as quickly as possible. The matter also raised at the meetings ATAC held at Perth on 28 June 1985 and at Hobart on 6 December 1985. On those occasions my colleague again emphasised that the Federal Government was anxious to ratify the MARPOL Convention at the earliest opportunity.
No objection was raised by any member of the Council at any meeting to the proposed action by the Federal Government.
However, good intentions notwithstanding, by the end of 1985, no Bill relating to the implementation of the MARPOL Convention had been placed before the legislature of any State or Territory.

The delay in becoming party to this Convention has placed Australia in an embarrassing situation internationally. The majority of foreign flag shipping using Australian waters is currently subject to more stringent operational controls, particularly in the Great Barrier Reef Region, than are Australian vessels.

The subject matter of MARPOL, dealing as it does with measures for preventing marine pollution, is often very complex. The need to keep up with constantly changing technical standards leads to quite frequent amendments proposed by the International Maritime Organization.

In order to ensure that the Australian legislation gives full effect to the Convention, it is necessary to ensure that the enabling Act remains consistent with the Convention as it is in force internationally.

It thus becomes essential to amend the Federal Act from time to time. The Bill before the Senate would enable amendments made by the International Maritime Organization, agreed to by ATAC and endorsed by the Federal Government, to take effect throughout Australia until such time as the individual State and Territory Governments amend their own legislation. For this reason alone, I am confident that the principles embodied in this Bill will be readily accepted by all concerned in the development and enforcement of marine pollution legislation.
Further details of the provisions of this Bill are contained in the Explanatory Memorandum which has been circulated to honourable Senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

debate.title:
HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION BILL 1985
HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1985
HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985
AUSTRALIAN BILL OF RIGHTS BILL 1985

proctext.para: Consideration resumed.

talk.start.para: —The Committee is considering clause 8 of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill. The question is that Article 5 stand as printed.

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —Article 5, as I read it, is almost identically worded to Article 27 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. I want to raise several questions. I want to ask the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) the meaning of the phrase `in community with other members of their own group'. Let me explain that. Article 5, as printed in the Bill of Rights, states:

speech.para: Persons who belong to an ethnic, religious or linguistic minority have the right, in community with other members of their own group, to enjoy their own culture, to profess and practice their own religion, or to use their own language.

I raise that query with the Minister because that, in itself, is a limiting thing, as I read it, in terms of a group. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that Article 18 of the International Covenant is very specific. It states that there should be freedom of religion et cetera, either individually or in community. If the Minister looks at each of the first three paragraphs in Article 18 he will see that they relate to the individual. I wonder at the difference. I wonder at what appears to be a conflict in that regard and I seek the Minister's explanation. But I go further and I query what appears to me to be a conflict. Article 5 is unqualified. It states:
Persons who belong to an ethnic, religious or linguistic minority have the right . . . to enjoy their own culture, to profess and practice their own religion, or to use their own language.
When I turn to Article 13 I see that paragraph (b) of that Article states:
no marriage shall be entered into without the free and full consent of the intending spouses.

I just mention this as an illustration. The Minister will be very well aware that, if one is allowed to practice one's culture in a community, Aboriginal tribal leaders, for example, will have the right-which they now possess-to indicate who shall be their spouse and that becomes compulsory. I do not need to remind the Minister that, under Islamic law, parents can instruct their daughters as to whom they shall marry. This happens under certain Greek social values. There is a whole range of matters and I simply take this one as an example. It seems to me that one needs to know how we should read this Article in the first place. Do we read it as an unqualified situation or must we move to qualify it when we get to other articles?

Again I am puzzled as to what is meant by the phrase `in community with other members of their own group'. I ask the Minister whether the phrase `in community' has a legal meaning? Does it mean communing with other groups or does it mean a physical grouping as the word `communing' has one meaning? Does it mean that one cannot practice if one is away from a group? Incidentally, the words `belonging to a minority' interest me. It is possible for a person to be a member of a particular culture or race and yet not belong in the full sense. I do not want to nit-pick, I want to get to an understanding--

talk.start.para: —You could have fooled me.

—If the Minister does not mind, that would not be difficult. I am trying very hard to take a sensible approach. There are two kinds of rules that we can follow and I understand the Minister's very fully. How does the Minister want to play it? If in this journey the Minister can find that I have been in any way trying not to put forward sensible arguments, he is nothing loth to get on his feet and say so. But if he wants to play little games, which is his natural characteristic, let him play and let him take the consequences. How are we to do it? May we not have this confrontation now and not in future? Let us have our temper tantrums now and not in future because every now and again they have to happen.
—Let us be gentle with each other, as the actress said to the bishop.
—Let us be gentle with each other? The devil can cite scripture for his purpose. After all, who was the ungentle?
—Come on. I have an answer for you. I was waiting to get on with it.

—No, you were not. You were waiting to try to be clever. Indeed, that is an appalling kind of act from someone whose intelligence should give him better judgment. Let me put that fairly and squarely. Having done that and since we must do this every now and again cyclically as a form of sedation--
—Stop working us all up into a lather and get on to the substantive point, and I shall be delighted to answer you.

—It is a very soporific lather, if I may mix my metaphors. I come to it and I simply ask those questions I have put forward. How does one interpret the phrase, how does one relate it to another article? Since the explanatory notes direct us to Article 27, I ask why did not the explanatory notes direct us to Article 18? I am told, and I may be wrong, that the explanatory notes have some kind of status in a court appeal. Presumably, one can use them in an argument that that was the intention of what the Bill means. If that is so, how can it have a plain meaning in Article 27 and another plain but different meaning in Article 18? I invite the Minister to comment.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: — The issue adverted to by Senator Sir John Carrick is one of which the drafters of this legislation and indeed the Government were very conscious. The right set out in Article 5 is an unusual one as compared with the others in the Bill of Rights because it is essentially collective in character. It is not an individual right. It is a collective right that is being articulated. That is the best shorthand way of describing the meaning of that expression `in community with other members of their own group'. The rights here acknowledged and identified are rights which, by their very character, are enjoyed by groups rather than by individuals. There is a contrast between group and individual right and Article 18 is one clear example of such a contrast being evident. I accept the reference to Article 18 which Senator Sir John Carrick offered as a clear contrast with the approach taken in Article 18 of the Covenant, that is, with the approach taken in Article--
—You nearly had me on my feet-ABR Article 18.

—I appreciate that any reference to Article 18 is like ringing the bell for Pavlov's dog. Just relax; we will get to that in due course. I acknowledge that there is that distinction and that Article 5 is about collective rights and just about every other article in the Bill of Rights is about individual rights. That does create certainly the possibility of conflicts arising in the real world application of these provisions. Senator Sir John Carrick gave a good example when he referred to the marriage right in Article 13 (b) of the Bill which talks in terms of `free and full consent of the intending spouses', which may indeed be at odds with some of the cultural norms prevailing in minority communities in this country as elsewhere.

speech.para: How does one resolve that kind of conflict should it arise in a marriage context or religious exercise context or any one of a number of others one could readily dream up? The way in which the drafters have approached the resolution of these matters is by using the balancing device set out in sub-clause 4 (5) of the Bill itself, which is set out on page 7. It says:
Where a law-
(a) promotes, enhances or secures a right or freedom set out in the Bill of Rights, but infringes, or authorises the infringement of, another right or freedom set out in the Bill of Rights; or

(b) promotes, enhances or secures . . . a right or freedom set out in the Bill . . . but, in relation to another person, infringes, or authorises the infringement of, a right or freedom set out in the Bill of Rights.
In other words, to paraphrase all that, where there is some conflict of rights that emerges from contrasting positions of the Bill:

it is the intention of the Parliament that the law shall not be determined to be in conflict with the Bill of Rights unless such a determination would further the objects of this Act, and in particular the paramount objectives referred to in paragraph 3 (d), to a greater extent than a determination that the law is not in conflict with the Bill of Rights.

What all that means is that when there is a conflict, one goes back to the objectives clause 3 (d) of the Bill, and looks at the values or class of rights which are given paramount importance by the operation of 3 (d). It will be seen in reading 3 (d) that the list is as follows:

to promote, enhance and secure as paramount objectives, the freedom and dignity of the human person, equality of opportunity for all persons and full and free participation by all Australians in public affairs and public debate.

What is being done there, and it is being done by reference to values which are apparent in the Covenant itself-that is the language that appears in the preamble to the Covenant-is to identify the three most basic rights of all. I refer to those going to freedom and dignity of the human person, that is to say, the human person as an individual, then after that equality rights, and then after that the democratic rights of full and free participation.

talk.start.para: —That is the heirarchy.

—That is the hierarchy and there are other rights as well which are not here identified. There are not here identified in this list the collective rights in Article 5 that we are talking about. What that all means is that where one has a conflict between the collective right in Article 5 and some claim of individual right as in the marriage case, to take the most classic example, the full and free consent clause, the claim of individual right is squarely identified as paramount. The collective claim of right would have to be subsumed, subordinated, to the individual claim of right. That might be a slightly circuitous journey, to use Senator Sir John Carrick's familiar metaphor, but it is nonetheless a journey with a clear end and there are clear signposts, I suggest, along the way. The problem he has identified, and it is a real one, in the drafting of this part of the Bill, has been squarely addressed and has, I believe, been resolved.

—The point I wish to raise is general but is the first one that has come to my attention. In the Covenant itself there are a number of prohibitions as well as a number of rights which are designated. To refer to this clause, if one looks for example, at Article 20 in the Covenant, one finds that there is a prohibition on the advocacy of national, racial or religious hatred. Are these types of prohibition, particularly on the generation of religious and racial hatred which are fairly obviously a counter to the operations of a right-the right being here a collective thing which seems to me is more clearly designated as an individual right one holds in common with others of the group-in terms of the wording the Government has chosen to use from Article 27 meant to pick up that prohibition which exists in clause 20 of the Covenant?

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —I do not think that we had any intention of picking that up through Article 27. The way in which this question of prohibitions is dealt with is explained in paragraph 39 of the explanatory memorandum. It is there stated that in the context of Article 20 of the Covenant, which deals with propaganda for war and incitement to racial and religious hatred, that is being deliberately excluded from our draft of a Bill of Rights for the reason that it is something that is far more appropriately addressed by particular legislation-legislation which, in terms, would arguably be consistent with the overarching statements of right. What one is, in effect, talking about is a curious kind of limitation on a right, rather than a statement of the right itself.

speech.para: The problem of legislation prohibiting incitement to war and incitement to race hatred is peculiarly difficult because, as we have acknowledged many times across the chamber, it squarely raises the issue of the dimensions of freedom of speech and the propriety and sense of imposing that kind of limitation on freedom of speech. I suspect that it is an issue of principle that was rather fudged by the drafters of the Covenant. It may have been one of those areas-there are not too many; there may be one or two elsewhere in the Covenant-where, in all the sorts of compromises that were arrived at to get a clear articulation in the Covenant of rights, this was one of the trade-offs that occurred to get some specific reference to the legitimacy of these kinds of provisions. The other conceptual reason, I suppose, and perhaps the more immediately obvious one, is that what we are talking about here is some kind of provisions regulating the conduct of individuals rather than the conduct of governments itself.

talk.start.para: —I am not sure. We are talking about governments and government instrumentalities. We presume that they will not engage in that, but if one makes a presumption that we shall never deny a right, we would not even be having a Bill, would we?

—I understand the point that Senator Macklin is making. Many of these things can be perpetrated by governments. But the instruction in Article 20 is that any advocacy of religious hatred, or whatever, shall be prohibited by law-the implication being that a government's responsibility here is not just one of not doing something itself but, rather, of acting in a positive way to restrain individuals and organisations from so acting; and, as such, that sits again outside the basic framework of the Bill of Rights, which is directed to setting restraints on government rather than urging a government to do something that itself constitutes a restraint.

speech.para: For all those reasons, and not least also because of the delicacy of the policy issue involved here, it was thought better to address this issue in separate legislation. To the extent that we had an obligation under the Covenant to so act, it was an obligation which could be more appropriately met in a separate piece of legislation, such as the Racial Discrimination Act, with a possible amendment to that, if, on balance, we decided to go down that particular track. Whether we should go down the track is an issue that continues to be under review by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). I wrestled with it for a couple of years, I must confess, and I ended up leaving it in the too hard basket, and I suspect that my successor is doing the same, because there are many arguments on both sides of the fence, including the argument that legislation of this kind may be counterproductive in terms of generating semi-martyrdom for those whom one is seeking to restrain. They are the variety of policy issues and conceptual reasons why that does not appear. Article 5 is not intended to cover that track.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Minister for that explanation. It is just that when I was looking at the extent of this right for people to profess and practise their own religion, it seemed to me that in using their own language or enjoying their own culture people are up against matters such as racial defamation. It seems to run counter to the profession that a person will actually have a right to enjoy his own culture when in fact the Government is leaving people alone to engage in the circumscribing of that right by racial defamation.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: — With the utmost respect, I think it is a large step to move from the language of Article 5, which talks about the right of people in community with others to enjoy their own culture and to profess and practise their own religion or use their own language, and to say that this amounts to some kind of tacit encouragement for such groups to engage-I quote from Article 20-in:

speech.para: . . . advocacy of national, racial or religious hatred that constitutes incitement to discrimination, hostility or violence.
I understand the thought processes that seem to have worked their way around Senator Macklin's mind, but I suggest that he is drawing a long bow on that one.

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —Following upon the Minister's explanation to me, I want to follow on from what I said previously. We go one step further if we need to publish the 32 Articles of this Bill. Not only have we got to draw attention to Article 3 (2) and to publish as an addendum the International Covenant, but now, according to the Minister, we must say that in reading the clauses people, and particularly Aborigines who want to know something about marriage, must go back to the Bill itself, not the articles, look at clause 4 (5) and then go back to Article 3. If they do all those things, they may understand what Article 5 and the Article on marriage may mean.

speech.para: With the best good will in the world, this document becomes an impossibility. It is no good the Minister telling us that one can derive all these nuances and refinements by this treasure hunt that we go on. A Bill of Rights is surely supposed to have a plain meaning. It is supposed to be something which stands up on its own values, and which can be read in plain words and understood. Now here we are just dealing with one of a multitude of problems. Our multicultural society and, indeed, our Aboriginal society have enough difficulties in any case in understanding our laws and the English language, and suddenly we are confronting them with the fact that plain meanings for them mean nothing at all. As I say, on this understanding now, they will have to move away from the articles themselves and not only go back to the Covenant, and understand when they read the Covenant that there is an apparent conflict between Article 27 and Article 18, but then be advised that they must go back and look at the clauses of the Bill itself.

All of this, as the Minister said the other day, is for presentational purposes. With great respect, we cannot have an effective presentation if the plain meaning is not available, if the presentation itself is not the true meaning. I ask again: How does the Minister obviate that?

talk.start.para: — Senator Sir John Carrick's argument would have more force if the Bill of Rights were full of prohibitions, if it contained a set of regulations of behaviour that people needed to know about in order to know what they could do and could not do. But that is not what the Bill of Rights is about. The Bill of Rights is a statement of rights that need to be respected by governments, and, as such, it is an instruction to governments. The other role that it plays is to create opportunities for individuals who fear that their rights may have been infringed. As such, it is sufficient that the broad general thrust of what the document is about be readily understandable. If an individual wants to take advantage of it and go down the various legal paths that are open by way of enforcement, obviously then it is a matter of coming to grips with these niceties and journeys of the kind that we have been through. But it is a matter of distinguishing once again between the dual objectives of this legislation, as with most other pieces of legislation, of, on the one hand, conveying on its face the broad thrust of what it is about in intelligible language-and I suggest that this Bill does it a lot better than most others ever enacted that affect people's rights-and, on the other hand, giving detailed and precise instructions to those who have to apply and make effective the law. I suggest that the provisions I have mentioned do that very well.

talk.start.para: —I raise this evening a matter about which I believe this Government should be completely ashamed, and as a consequence of this matter I believe that the Australian public should be absolutely disgusted with the performance of the Government in this particular area. It is my view that the Labor Government has now elevated the suppression of information to its number one priority. I say that because of a refusal by a Minister, the details of which I will elaborate shortly, to provide me with certain information. I believe Labor is committing two sins: Firstly, it is evading parliamentary scrutiny and it is doing this by committing a second sin, namely, refusing information to senators and members and thereby effectively restricting the capacity of senators and members to do their job for the taxpayer. The situation is simply this: I asked for a simple list of community employment program projects in my State of South Australia. In the past I have been given such a list and I was seeking to continue the assessment of that program that I commenced early last year. I have not used this information irresponsibly. I have not picked out the worst of the schemes and sought headlines from them. The document read as follows-

As a consequence of being the youngest Senator I felt compelled in my maiden speech to address the disillusionment of Australia's young people. The prospect of unemployment contributes in no small way to this disillusionment.

As liberals we believe that a person's opportunities should be limited only by his or her competence, ambitions and willingness to work. Harsh economic reality has caused many of today's youth to perceive these ideals as unrealistic.
Unemployment is one, if not the most important problem faced in Australia today.

Schemes to provide jobs and experience to the unemployed are a feature of our political horizon. It is essential that they provide opportunities to individuals that are more than band-aid, short term relief.

I have undertaken this detailed analysis of the CEP scheme in South Australia so that as a Federal Parliamentarian I will be able to make an informed contribution to discussions about Federally funded initiatives and responsibilities in this area.

All too often it is tempting for politicians and commentators alike to take the path that leads to the quick headline and the superficial judgment rather than the informed evaluation of the objects and operation of a government programme.

It is my hope that it will contribute to a wider, informed appreciation of the operation of the CEP and the needs of the unemployed.

talk.start.para: —If people take the time to read that statement they will note that, as a consequence of being the youngest senator, I felt compelled in my maiden speech to address the disillusionment of Australia's young people. The prospect of unemployment contributes in no small way to that disillusionment. Unemployment is one of the most important problems, if not the most important problem, faced in Australia today. People reading the incorporated statement will see also that I was seeking to make an informed contribution to discussions about federally funded initiatives and responsibilities in this area. I said in that statement:

speech.para: All too often it is tempting for politicians and commentators alike to take the path that leads to the quick headline and the superficial judgment rather than the informed evaluation of the objects and operation of a government program.

In that light I sought updated information of a type that I had been given in the past. I was refused that information, so I asked why I was refused that information. I understand that in a number of places resources are limited, but I would have thought that a Minister who had a Bill before parliament relating to a program in his portfolio would have taken care to see that that relevant information was available to interested senators and members so that they could do a proper job in scrutinising the legislation, and do a proper job in reporting to their electorates and in the comments they may choose to make in parliament.

I received a letter from the Job Creation and Youth Programs Division of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, which gave me the same answer as I got from the Minister's Office. That letter states:
The Department has received a number of requests similar to your own from Senators and Members. These requests are placing considerable demands on available staff and ADP resources.

and we all know how long they take to get answered-
or under the provisions of the Freedom of Information legislation be directed through the Minister's Office . . .
